00001 /*
00002 ** 2001 September 15
00003 **
00004 ** The author disclaims copyright to this source code.  In place of
00005 ** a legal notice, here is a blessing:
00006 **
00007 **    May you do good and not evil.
00008 **    May you find forgiveness for yourself and forgive others.
00009 **    May you share freely, never taking more than you give.
00010 **
00011 *************************************************************************
00012 ** This header file defines the interface that the SQLite library
00013 ** presents to client programs.  If a C-function, structure, datatype,
00014 ** or constant definition does not appear in this file, then it is
00015 ** not a published API of SQLite, is subject to change without
00016 ** notice, and should not be referenced by programs that use SQLite.
00017 **
00018 ** Some of the definitions that are in this file are marked as
00019 ** "experimental".  Experimental interfaces are normally new
00020 ** features recently added to SQLite.  We do not anticipate changes
00021 ** to experimental interfaces but reserve the right to make minor changes
00022 ** if experience from use "in the wild" suggest such changes are prudent.
00023 **
00024 ** The official C-language API documentation for SQLite is derived
00025 ** from comments in this file.  This file is the authoritative source
00026 ** on how SQLite interfaces are suppose to operate.
00027 **
00028 ** The name of this file under configuration management is "sqlite.h.in".
00029 ** The makefile makes some minor changes to this file (such as inserting
00030 ** the version number) and changes its name to "sqlite3.h" as
00031 ** part of the build process.
00032 */
00033 #ifndef _SQLITE3_H_
00034 #define _SQLITE3_H_
00035 #include <stdarg.h>     /* Needed for the definition of va_list */
00036

00038 ** Make sure we can call this stuff from C++.
00039 */

00042 #endif

00057 /*
00058 ** These no-op macros are used in front of interfaces to mark those
00059 ** interfaces as either deprecated or experimental.  New applications
00060 ** should not use deprecated interfaces - they are support for backwards
00061 ** compatibility only.  Application writers should be aware that
00062 ** experimental interfaces are subject to change in point releases.
00063 **
00064 ** These macros used to resolve to various kinds of compiler magic that
00065 ** would generate warning messages when they were used.  But that
00066 ** compiler magic ended up generating such a flurry of bug reports
00067 ** that we have taken it all out and gone back to using simple
00068 ** noop macros.
00069 */
00070 #define SQLITE_DEPRECATED
00071 #define SQLITE_EXPERIMENTAL
00072 
00073 /*
00074 ** Ensure these symbols were not defined by some previous header file.
00075 */
00076 #ifdef SQLITE_VERSION
00077 # undef SQLITE_VERSION
00078 #endif
00079 #ifdef SQLITE_VERSION_NUMBER
00080 # undef SQLITE_VERSION_NUMBER
00081 #endif
00082 
00083 /*
00084 ** CAPI3REF: Compile-Time Library Version Numbers
00085 **
00086 ** ^(The [SQLITE_VERSION] C preprocessor macro in the sqlite3.h header
00087 ** evaluates to a string literal that is the SQLite version in the
00088 ** format "X.Y.Z" where X is the major version number (always 3 for
00089 ** SQLite3) and Y is the minor version number and Z is the release number.)^
00090 ** ^(The [SQLITE_VERSION_NUMBER] C preprocessor macro resolves to an integer
00091 ** with the value (X*1000000 + Y*1000 + Z) where X, Y, and Z are the same
00092 ** numbers used in [SQLITE_VERSION].)^
00093 ** The SQLITE_VERSION_NUMBER for any given release of SQLite will also
00094 ** be larger than the release from which it is derived.  Either Y will
00095 ** be held constant and Z will be incremented or else Y will be incremented
00096 ** and Z will be reset to zero.
00097 **
00098 ** Since version 3.6.18, SQLite source code has been stored in the
00099 ** <a href="http://www.fossil-scm.org/">Fossil configuration management
00100 ** system</a>.  ^The SQLITE_SOURCE_ID macro evaluates to
00101 ** a string which identifies a particular check-in of SQLite
00102 ** within its configuration management system.  ^The SQLITE_SOURCE_ID
00103 ** string contains the date and time of the check-in (UTC) and an SHA1
00104 ** hash of the entire source tree.
00105 **
00106 ** See also: [sqlite3_libversion()],
00107 ** [sqlite3_libversion_number()], [sqlite3_sourceid()],
00108 ** [sqlite_version()] and [sqlite_source_id()].
00109 */
00110 #define SQLITE_VERSION        "3.7.3"
00111 #define SQLITE_VERSION_NUMBER 3007003
00112 #define SQLITE_SOURCE_ID      "2010-10-08 02:34:02 2677848087c9c090efb17c1893e77d6136a9111d"
00113 
00114 /*
00115 ** CAPI3REF: Run-Time Library Version Numbers
00116 ** KEYWORDS: sqlite3_version, sqlite3_sourceid
00117 **
00118 ** These interfaces provide the same information as the [SQLITE_VERSION],
00119 ** [SQLITE_VERSION_NUMBER], and [SQLITE_SOURCE_ID] C preprocessor macros
00120 ** but are associated with the library instead of the header file.  ^(Cautious
00121 ** programmers might include assert() statements in their application to
00122 ** verify that values returned by these interfaces match the macros in
00123 ** the header, and thus insure that the application is
00124 ** compiled with matching library and header files.
00125 **
00126 ** <blockquote><pre>
00127 ** assert( sqlite3_libversion_number()==SQLITE_VERSION_NUMBER );
00128 ** assert( strcmp(sqlite3_sourceid(),SQLITE_SOURCE_ID)==0 );
00129 ** assert( strcmp(sqlite3_libversion(),SQLITE_VERSION)==0 );
00130 ** </pre></blockquote>)^
00131 **
00132 ** ^The sqlite3_version[] string constant contains the text of [SQLITE_VERSION]
00133 ** macro.  ^The sqlite3_libversion() function returns a pointer to the
00134 ** to the sqlite3_version[] string constant.  The sqlite3_libversion()
00135 ** function is provided for use in DLLs since DLL users usually do not have
00136 ** direct access to string constants within the DLL.  ^The
00137 ** sqlite3_libversion_number() function returns an integer equal to
00138 ** [SQLITE_VERSION_NUMBER].  ^The sqlite3_sourceid() function returns 
00139 ** a pointer to a string constant whose value is the same as the 
00140 ** [SQLITE_SOURCE_ID] C preprocessor macro.
00141 **
00142 ** See also: [sqlite_version()] and [sqlite_source_id()].
00143 */
00144 SQLITE_API SQLITE_EXTERN const char sqlite3_version[];
00145 SQLITE_API const char *sqlite3_libversion(void);
00146 SQLITE_API const char *sqlite3_sourceid(void);
00147 SQLITE_API int sqlite3_libversion_number(void);
00148 
00149 /*
00150 ** CAPI3REF: Run-Time Library Compilation Options Diagnostics
00151 **
00152 ** ^The sqlite3_compileoption_used() function returns 0 or 1 
00153 ** indicating whether the specified option was defined at 
00154 ** compile time.  ^The SQLITE_ prefix may be omitted from the 
00155 ** option name passed to sqlite3_compileoption_used().  
00156 **
00157 ** ^The sqlite3_compileoption_get() function allows iterating
00158 ** over the list of options that were defined at compile time by
00159 ** returning the N-th compile time option string.  ^If N is out of range,
00160 ** sqlite3_compileoption_get() returns a NULL pointer.  ^The SQLITE_ 
00161 ** prefix is omitted from any strings returned by 
00162 ** sqlite3_compileoption_get().
00163 **
00164 ** ^Support for the diagnostic functions sqlite3_compileoption_used()
00165 ** and sqlite3_compileoption_get() may be omitted by specifying the 
00166 ** [SQLITE_OMIT_COMPILEOPTION_DIAGS] option at compile time.
00167 **
00168 ** See also: SQL functions [sqlite_compileoption_used()] and
00169 ** [sqlite_compileoption_get()] and the [compile_options pragma].
00170 */
00171 #ifndef SQLITE_OMIT_COMPILEOPTION_DIAGS
00172 SQLITE_API int sqlite3_compileoption_used(const char *zOptName);
00173 SQLITE_API const char *sqlite3_compileoption_get(int N);
00174 #endif
00175 
00176 /*
00177 ** CAPI3REF: Test To See If The Library Is Threadsafe
00178 **
00179 ** ^The sqlite3_threadsafe() function returns zero if and only if
00180 ** SQLite was compiled mutexing code omitted due to the
00181 ** [SQLITE_THREADSAFE] compile-time option being set to 0.
00182 **
00183 ** SQLite can be compiled with or without mutexes.  When
00184 ** the [SQLITE_THREADSAFE] C preprocessor macro is 1 or 2, mutexes
00185 ** are enabled and SQLite is threadsafe.  When the
00186 ** [SQLITE_THREADSAFE] macro is 0, 
00187 ** the mutexes are omitted.  Without the mutexes, it is not safe
00188 ** to use SQLite concurrently from more than one thread.
00189 **
00190 ** Enabling mutexes incurs a measurable performance penalty.
00191 ** So if speed is of utmost importance, it makes sense to disable
00192 ** the mutexes.  But for maximum safety, mutexes should be enabled.
00193 ** ^The default behavior is for mutexes to be enabled.
00194 **
00195 ** This interface can be used by an application to make sure that the
00196 ** version of SQLite that it is linking against was compiled with
00197 ** the desired setting of the [SQLITE_THREADSAFE] macro.
00198 **
00199 ** This interface only reports on the compile-time mutex setting
00200 ** of the [SQLITE_THREADSAFE] flag.  If SQLite is compiled with
00201 ** SQLITE_THREADSAFE=1 or =2 then mutexes are enabled by default but
00202 ** can be fully or partially disabled using a call to [sqlite3_config()]
00203 ** with the verbs [SQLITE_CONFIG_SINGLETHREAD], [SQLITE_CONFIG_MULTITHREAD],
00204 ** or [SQLITE_CONFIG_MUTEX].  ^(The return value of the
00205 ** sqlite3_threadsafe() function shows only the compile-time setting of
00206 ** thread safety, not any run-time changes to that setting made by
00207 ** sqlite3_config(). In other words, the return value from sqlite3_threadsafe()
00208 ** is unchanged by calls to sqlite3_config().)^
00209 **
00210 ** See the [threading mode] documentation for additional information.
00211 */
00212 SQLITE_API int sqlite3_threadsafe(void);
00213 
00214 /*
00215 ** CAPI3REF: Database Connection Handle
00216 ** KEYWORDS: {database connection} {database connections}
00217 **
00218 ** Each open SQLite database is represented by a pointer to an instance of
00219 ** the opaque structure named "sqlite3".  It is useful to think of an sqlite3
00220 ** pointer as an object.  The [sqlite3_open()], [sqlite3_open16()], and
00221 ** [sqlite3_open_v2()] interfaces are its constructors, and [sqlite3_close()]
00222 ** is its destructor.  There are many other interfaces (such as
00223 ** [sqlite3_prepare_v2()], [sqlite3_create_function()], and
00224 ** [sqlite3_busy_timeout()] to name but three) that are methods on an
00225 ** sqlite3 object.
00226 */
00227 typedef struct sqlite3 sqlite3;
00228 
00229 /*
00230 ** CAPI3REF: 64-Bit Integer Types
00231 ** KEYWORDS: sqlite_int64 sqlite_uint64
00232 **
00233 ** Because there is no cross-platform way to specify 64-bit integer types
00234 ** SQLite includes typedefs for 64-bit signed and unsigned integers.
00235 **
00236 ** The sqlite3_int64 and sqlite3_uint64 are the preferred type definitions.
00237 ** The sqlite_int64 and sqlite_uint64 types are supported for backwards
00238 ** compatibility only.
00239 **
00240 ** ^The sqlite3_int64 and sqlite_int64 types can store integer values
00241 ** between -9223372036854775808 and +9223372036854775807 inclusive.  ^The
00242 ** sqlite3_uint64 and sqlite_uint64 types can store integer values 
00243 ** between 0 and +18446744073709551615 inclusive.
00244 */
00245 #ifdef SQLITE_INT64_TYPE
00246   typedef SQLITE_INT64_TYPE sqlite_int64;
00247   typedef unsigned SQLITE_INT64_TYPE sqlite_uint64;
00248 #elif defined(_MSC_VER) || defined(__BORLANDC__)
00249   typedef __int64 sqlite_int64;
00250   typedef unsigned __int64 sqlite_uint64;
00251 #else
00252   typedef long long int sqlite_int64;
00253   typedef unsigned long long int sqlite_uint64;
00254 #endif
00255 typedef sqlite_int64 sqlite3_int64;
00256 typedef sqlite_uint64 sqlite3_uint64;
00257 
00258 /*
00259 ** If compiling for a processor that lacks floating point support,
00260 ** substitute integer for floating-point.
00261 */
00262 #ifdef SQLITE_OMIT_FLOATING_POINT
00263 # define double sqlite3_int64
00264 #endif
00265 
00266 /*
00267 ** CAPI3REF: Closing A Database Connection
00268 **
00269 ** ^The sqlite3_close() routine is the destructor for the [sqlite3] object.
00270 ** ^Calls to sqlite3_close() return SQLITE_OK if the [sqlite3] object is
00271 ** successfully destroyed and all associated resources are deallocated.
00272 **
00273 ** Applications must [sqlite3_finalize | finalize] all [prepared statements]
00274 ** and [sqlite3_blob_close | close] all [BLOB handles] associated with
00275 ** the [sqlite3] object prior to attempting to close the object.  ^If
00276 ** sqlite3_close() is called on a [database connection] that still has
00277 ** outstanding [prepared statements] or [BLOB handles], then it returns
00278 ** SQLITE_BUSY.
00279 **
00280 ** ^If [sqlite3_close()] is invoked while a transaction is open,
00281 ** the transaction is automatically rolled back.
00282 **
00283 ** The C parameter to [sqlite3_close(C)] must be either a NULL
00284 ** pointer or an [sqlite3] object pointer obtained
00285 ** from [sqlite3_open()], [sqlite3_open16()], or
00286 ** [sqlite3_open_v2()], and not previously closed.
00287 ** ^Calling sqlite3_close() with a NULL pointer argument is a 
00288 ** harmless no-op.
00289 */
00290 SQLITE_API int sqlite3_close(sqlite3 *);
00291 
00292 /*
00293 ** The type for a callback function.
00294 ** This is legacy and deprecated.  It is included for historical
00295 ** compatibility and is not documented.
00296 */
00297 typedef int (*sqlite3_callback)(void*,int,char**, char**);
00298 
00299 /*
00300 ** CAPI3REF: One-Step Query Execution Interface
00301 **
00302 ** The sqlite3_exec() interface is a convenience wrapper around
00303 ** [sqlite3_prepare_v2()], [sqlite3_step()], and [sqlite3_finalize()],
00304 ** that allows an application to run multiple statements of SQL
00305 ** without having to use a lot of C code. 
00306 **
00307 ** ^The sqlite3_exec() interface runs zero or more UTF-8 encoded,
00308 ** semicolon-separate SQL statements passed into its 2nd argument,
00309 ** in the context of the [database connection] passed in as its 1st
00310 ** argument.  ^If the callback function of the 3rd argument to
00311 ** sqlite3_exec() is not NULL, then it is invoked for each result row
00312 ** coming out of the evaluated SQL statements.  ^The 4th argument to
00313 ** to sqlite3_exec() is relayed through to the 1st argument of each
00314 ** callback invocation.  ^If the callback pointer to sqlite3_exec()
00315 ** is NULL, then no callback is ever invoked and result rows are
00316 ** ignored.
00317 **
00318 ** ^If an error occurs while evaluating the SQL statements passed into
00319 ** sqlite3_exec(), then execution of the current statement stops and
00320 ** subsequent statements are skipped.  ^If the 5th parameter to sqlite3_exec()
00321 ** is not NULL then any error message is written into memory obtained
00322 ** from [sqlite3_malloc()] and passed back through the 5th parameter.
00323 ** To avoid memory leaks, the application should invoke [sqlite3_free()]
00324 ** on error message strings returned through the 5th parameter of
00325 ** of sqlite3_exec() after the error message string is no longer needed.
00326 ** ^If the 5th parameter to sqlite3_exec() is not NULL and no errors
00327 ** occur, then sqlite3_exec() sets the pointer in its 5th parameter to
00328 ** NULL before returning.
00329 **
00330 ** ^If an sqlite3_exec() callback returns non-zero, the sqlite3_exec()
00331 ** routine returns SQLITE_ABORT without invoking the callback again and
00332 ** without running any subsequent SQL statements.
00333 **
00334 ** ^The 2nd argument to the sqlite3_exec() callback function is the
00335 ** number of columns in the result.  ^The 3rd argument to the sqlite3_exec()
00336 ** callback is an array of pointers to strings obtained as if from
00337 ** [sqlite3_column_text()], one for each column.  ^If an element of a
00338 ** result row is NULL then the corresponding string pointer for the
00339 ** sqlite3_exec() callback is a NULL pointer.  ^The 4th argument to the
00340 ** sqlite3_exec() callback is an array of pointers to strings where each
00341 ** entry represents the name of corresponding result column as obtained
00342 ** from [sqlite3_column_name()].
00343 **
00344 ** ^If the 2nd parameter to sqlite3_exec() is a NULL pointer, a pointer
00345 ** to an empty string, or a pointer that contains only whitespace and/or 
00346 ** SQL comments, then no SQL statements are evaluated and the database
00347 ** is not changed.
00348 **
00349 ** Restrictions:
00350 **
00351 ** <ul>
00352 ** <li> The application must insure that the 1st parameter to sqlite3_exec()
00353 **      is a valid and open [database connection].
00354 ** <li> The application must not close [database connection] specified by
00355 **      the 1st parameter to sqlite3_exec() while sqlite3_exec() is running.
00356 ** <li> The application must not modify the SQL statement text passed into
00357 **      the 2nd parameter of sqlite3_exec() while sqlite3_exec() is running.
00358 ** </ul>
00359 */
00360 SQLITE_API int sqlite3_exec(
00361   sqlite3*,                                  /* An open database */
00362   const char *sql,                           /* SQL to be evaluated */
00363   int (*callback)(void*,int,char**,char**),  /* Callback function */
00364   void *,                                    /* 1st argument to callback */
00365   char **errmsg                              /* Error msg written here */
00366 );
00367 
00368 /*
00369 ** CAPI3REF: Result Codes
00370 ** KEYWORDS: SQLITE_OK {error code} {error codes}
00371 ** KEYWORDS: {result code} {result codes}
00372 **
00373 ** Many SQLite functions return an integer result code from the set shown
00374 ** here in order to indicates success or failure.
00375 **
00376 ** New error codes may be added in future versions of SQLite.
00377 **
00378 ** See also: [SQLITE_IOERR_READ | extended result codes]
00379 */
00380 #define SQLITE_OK           0   /* Successful result */
00381 /* beginning-of-error-codes */
00382 #define SQLITE_ERROR        1   /* SQL error or missing database */
00383 #define SQLITE_INTERNAL     2   /* Internal logic error in SQLite */
00384 #define SQLITE_PERM         3   /* Access permission denied */
00385 #define SQLITE_ABORT        4   /* Callback routine requested an abort */
00386 #define SQLITE_BUSY         5   /* The database file is locked */
00387 #define SQLITE_LOCKED       6   /* A table in the database is locked */
00388 #define SQLITE_NOMEM        7   /* A malloc() failed */
00389 #define SQLITE_READONLY     8   /* Attempt to write a readonly database */
00390 #define SQLITE_INTERRUPT    9   /* Operation terminated by sqlite3_interrupt()*/
00391 #define SQLITE_IOERR       10   /* Some kind of disk I/O error occurred */
00392 #define SQLITE_CORRUPT     11   /* The database disk image is malformed */
00393 #define SQLITE_NOTFOUND    12   /* NOT USED. Table or record not found */
00394 #define SQLITE_FULL        13   /* Insertion failed because database is full */
00395 #define SQLITE_CANTOPEN    14   /* Unable to open the database file */
00396 #define SQLITE_PROTOCOL    15   /* Database lock protocol error */
00397 #define SQLITE_EMPTY       16   /* Database is empty */
00398 #define SQLITE_SCHEMA      17   /* The database schema changed */
00399 #define SQLITE_TOOBIG      18   /* String or BLOB exceeds size limit */
00400 #define SQLITE_CONSTRAINT  19   /* Abort due to constraint violation */
00401 #define SQLITE_MISMATCH    20   /* Data type mismatch */
00402 #define SQLITE_MISUSE      21   /* Library used incorrectly */
00403 #define SQLITE_NOLFS       22   /* Uses OS features not supported on host */
00404 #define SQLITE_AUTH        23   /* Authorization denied */
00405 #define SQLITE_FORMAT      24   /* Auxiliary database format error */
00406 #define SQLITE_RANGE       25   /* 2nd parameter to sqlite3_bind out of range */
00407 #define SQLITE_NOTADB      26   /* File opened that is not a database file */
00408 #define SQLITE_ROW         100  /* sqlite3_step() has another row ready */
00409 #define SQLITE_DONE        101  /* sqlite3_step() has finished executing */
00410 /* end-of-error-codes */
00411 
00412 /*
00413 ** CAPI3REF: Extended Result Codes
00414 ** KEYWORDS: {extended error code} {extended error codes}
00415 ** KEYWORDS: {extended result code} {extended result codes}
00416 **
00417 ** In its default configuration, SQLite API routines return one of 26 integer
00418 ** [SQLITE_OK | result codes].  However, experience has shown that many of
00419 ** these result codes are too coarse-grained.  They do not provide as
00420 ** much information about problems as programmers might like.  In an effort to
00421 ** address this, newer versions of SQLite (version 3.3.8 and later) include
00422 ** support for additional result codes that provide more detailed information
00423 ** about errors. The extended result codes are enabled or disabled
00424 ** on a per database connection basis using the
00425 ** [sqlite3_extended_result_codes()] API.
00426 **
00427 ** Some of the available extended result codes are listed here.
00428 ** One may expect the number of extended result codes will be expand
00429 ** over time.  Software that uses extended result codes should expect
00430 ** to see new result codes in future releases of SQLite.
00431 **
00432 ** The SQLITE_OK result code will never be extended.  It will always
00433 ** be exactly zero.
00434 */
00435 #define SQLITE_IOERR_READ              (SQLITE_IOERR | (1<<8))
00436 #define SQLITE_IOERR_SHORT_READ        (SQLITE_IOERR | (2<<8))
00437 #define SQLITE_IOERR_WRITE             (SQLITE_IOERR | (3<<8))
00438 #define SQLITE_IOERR_FSYNC             (SQLITE_IOERR | (4<<8))
00439 #define SQLITE_IOERR_DIR_FSYNC         (SQLITE_IOERR | (5<<8))
00440 #define SQLITE_IOERR_TRUNCATE          (SQLITE_IOERR | (6<<8))
00441 #define SQLITE_IOERR_FSTAT             (SQLITE_IOERR | (7<<8))
00442 #define SQLITE_IOERR_UNLOCK            (SQLITE_IOERR | (8<<8))
00443 #define SQLITE_IOERR_RDLOCK            (SQLITE_IOERR | (9<<8))
00444 #define SQLITE_IOERR_DELETE            (SQLITE_IOERR | (10<<8))
00445 #define SQLITE_IOERR_BLOCKED           (SQLITE_IOERR | (11<<8))
00446 #define SQLITE_IOERR_NOMEM             (SQLITE_IOERR | (12<<8))
00447 #define SQLITE_IOERR_ACCESS            (SQLITE_IOERR | (13<<8))
00448 #define SQLITE_IOERR_CHECKRESERVEDLOCK (SQLITE_IOERR | (14<<8))
00449 #define SQLITE_IOERR_LOCK              (SQLITE_IOERR | (15<<8))
00450 #define SQLITE_IOERR_CLOSE             (SQLITE_IOERR | (16<<8))
00451 #define SQLITE_IOERR_DIR_CLOSE         (SQLITE_IOERR | (17<<8))
00452 #define SQLITE_IOERR_SHMOPEN           (SQLITE_IOERR | (18<<8))
00453 #define SQLITE_IOERR_SHMSIZE           (SQLITE_IOERR | (19<<8))
00454 #define SQLITE_IOERR_SHMLOCK           (SQLITE_IOERR | (20<<8))
00455 #define SQLITE_LOCKED_SHAREDCACHE      (SQLITE_LOCKED |  (1<<8))
00456 #define SQLITE_BUSY_RECOVERY           (SQLITE_BUSY   |  (1<<8))
00457 #define SQLITE_CANTOPEN_NOTEMPDIR      (SQLITE_CANTOPEN | (1<<8))
00458 
00459 /*
00460 ** CAPI3REF: Flags For File Open Operations
00461 **
00462 ** These bit values are intended for use in the
00463 ** 3rd parameter to the [sqlite3_open_v2()] interface and
00464 ** in the 4th parameter to the xOpen method of the
00465 ** [sqlite3_vfs] object.
00466 */
00467 #define SQLITE_OPEN_READONLY         0x00000001  /* Ok for sqlite3_open_v2() */
00468 #define SQLITE_OPEN_READWRITE        0x00000002  /* Ok for sqlite3_open_v2() */
00469 #define SQLITE_OPEN_CREATE           0x00000004  /* Ok for sqlite3_open_v2() */
00470 #define SQLITE_OPEN_DELETEONCLOSE    0x00000008  /* VFS only */
00471 #define SQLITE_OPEN_EXCLUSIVE        0x00000010  /* VFS only */
00472 #define SQLITE_OPEN_AUTOPROXY        0x00000020  /* VFS only */
00473 #define SQLITE_OPEN_MAIN_DB          0x00000100  /* VFS only */
00474 #define SQLITE_OPEN_TEMP_DB          0x00000200  /* VFS only */
00475 #define SQLITE_OPEN_TRANSIENT_DB     0x00000400  /* VFS only */
00476 #define SQLITE_OPEN_MAIN_JOURNAL     0x00000800  /* VFS only */
00477 #define SQLITE_OPEN_TEMP_JOURNAL     0x00001000  /* VFS only */
00478 #define SQLITE_OPEN_SUBJOURNAL       0x00002000  /* VFS only */
00479 #define SQLITE_OPEN_MASTER_JOURNAL   0x00004000  /* VFS only */
00480 #define SQLITE_OPEN_NOMUTEX          0x00008000  /* Ok for sqlite3_open_v2() */
00481 #define SQLITE_OPEN_FULLMUTEX        0x00010000  /* Ok for sqlite3_open_v2() */
00482 #define SQLITE_OPEN_SHAREDCACHE      0x00020000  /* Ok for sqlite3_open_v2() */
00483 #define SQLITE_OPEN_PRIVATECACHE     0x00040000  /* Ok for sqlite3_open_v2() */
00484 #define SQLITE_OPEN_WAL              0x00080000  /* VFS only */
00485 
00486 /*
00487 ** CAPI3REF: Device Characteristics
00488 **
00489 ** The xDeviceCharacteristics method of the [sqlite3_io_methods]
00490 ** object returns an integer which is a vector of the these
00491 ** bit values expressing I/O characteristics of the mass storage
00492 ** device that holds the file that the [sqlite3_io_methods]
00493 ** refers to.
00494 **
00495 ** The SQLITE_IOCAP_ATOMIC property means that all writes of
00496 ** any size are atomic.  The SQLITE_IOCAP_ATOMICnnn values
00497 ** mean that writes of blocks that are nnn bytes in size and
00498 ** are aligned to an address which is an integer multiple of
00499 ** nnn are atomic.  The SQLITE_IOCAP_SAFE_APPEND value means
00500 ** that when data is appended to a file, the data is appended
00501 ** first then the size of the file is extended, never the other
00502 ** way around.  The SQLITE_IOCAP_SEQUENTIAL property means that
00503 ** information is written to disk in the same order as calls
00504 ** to xWrite().
00505 */
00506 #define SQLITE_IOCAP_ATOMIC                 0x00000001
00507 #define SQLITE_IOCAP_ATOMIC512              0x00000002
00508 #define SQLITE_IOCAP_ATOMIC1K               0x00000004
00509 #define SQLITE_IOCAP_ATOMIC2K               0x00000008
00510 #define SQLITE_IOCAP_ATOMIC4K               0x00000010
00511 #define SQLITE_IOCAP_ATOMIC8K               0x00000020
00512 #define SQLITE_IOCAP_ATOMIC16K              0x00000040
00513 #define SQLITE_IOCAP_ATOMIC32K              0x00000080
00514 #define SQLITE_IOCAP_ATOMIC64K              0x00000100
00515 #define SQLITE_IOCAP_SAFE_APPEND            0x00000200
00516 #define SQLITE_IOCAP_SEQUENTIAL             0x00000400
00517 #define SQLITE_IOCAP_UNDELETABLE_WHEN_OPEN  0x00000800
00518 
00519 /*
00520 ** CAPI3REF: File Locking Levels
00521 **
00522 ** SQLite uses one of these integer values as the second
00523 ** argument to calls it makes to the xLock() and xUnlock() methods
00524 ** of an [sqlite3_io_methods] object.
00525 */
00526 #define SQLITE_LOCK_NONE          0
00527 #define SQLITE_LOCK_SHARED        1
00528 #define SQLITE_LOCK_RESERVED      2
00529 #define SQLITE_LOCK_PENDING       3
00530 #define SQLITE_LOCK_EXCLUSIVE     4
00531 
00532 /*
00533 ** CAPI3REF: Synchronization Type Flags
00534 **
00535 ** When SQLite invokes the xSync() method of an
00536 ** [sqlite3_io_methods] object it uses a combination of
00537 ** these integer values as the second argument.
00538 **
00539 ** When the SQLITE_SYNC_DATAONLY flag is used, it means that the
00540 ** sync operation only needs to flush data to mass storage.  Inode
00541 ** information need not be flushed. If the lower four bits of the flag
00542 ** equal SQLITE_SYNC_NORMAL, that means to use normal fsync() semantics.
00543 ** If the lower four bits equal SQLITE_SYNC_FULL, that means
00544 ** to use Mac OS X style fullsync instead of fsync().
00545 */
00546 #define SQLITE_SYNC_NORMAL        0x00002
00547 #define SQLITE_SYNC_FULL          0x00003
00548 #define SQLITE_SYNC_DATAONLY      0x00010
00549 
00550 /*
00551 ** CAPI3REF: OS Interface Open File Handle
00552 **
00553 ** An [sqlite3_file] object represents an open file in the 
00554 ** [sqlite3_vfs | OS interface layer].  Individual OS interface
00555 ** implementations will
00556 ** want to subclass this object by appending additional fields
00557 ** for their own use.  The pMethods entry is a pointer to an
00558 ** [sqlite3_io_methods] object that defines methods for performing
00559 ** I/O operations on the open file.
00560 */
00561 typedef struct sqlite3_file sqlite3_file;
00562 struct sqlite3_file {
00563   const struct sqlite3_io_methods *pMethods;  /* Methods for an open file */
00564 };
00565 
00566 /*
00567 ** CAPI3REF: OS Interface File Virtual Methods Object
00568 **
00569 ** Every file opened by the [sqlite3_vfs] xOpen method populates an
00570 ** [sqlite3_file] object (or, more commonly, a subclass of the
00571 ** [sqlite3_file] object) with a pointer to an instance of this object.
00572 ** This object defines the methods used to perform various operations
00573 ** against the open file represented by the [sqlite3_file] object.
00574 **
00575 ** If the xOpen method sets the sqlite3_file.pMethods element 
00576 ** to a non-NULL pointer, then the sqlite3_io_methods.xClose method
00577 ** may be invoked even if the xOpen reported that it failed.  The
00578 ** only way to prevent a call to xClose following a failed xOpen
00579 ** is for the xOpen to set the sqlite3_file.pMethods element to NULL.
00580 **
00581 ** The flags argument to xSync may be one of [SQLITE_SYNC_NORMAL] or
00582 ** [SQLITE_SYNC_FULL].  The first choice is the normal fsync().
00583 ** The second choice is a Mac OS X style fullsync.  The [SQLITE_SYNC_DATAONLY]
00584 ** flag may be ORed in to indicate that only the data of the file
00585 ** and not its inode needs to be synced.
00586 **
00587 ** The integer values to xLock() and xUnlock() are one of
00588 ** <ul>
00589 ** <li> [SQLITE_LOCK_NONE],
00590 ** <li> [SQLITE_LOCK_SHARED],
00591 ** <li> [SQLITE_LOCK_RESERVED],
00592 ** <li> [SQLITE_LOCK_PENDING], or
00593 ** <li> [SQLITE_LOCK_EXCLUSIVE].
00594 ** </ul>
00595 ** xLock() increases the lock. xUnlock() decreases the lock.
00596 ** The xCheckReservedLock() method checks whether any database connection,
00597 ** either in this process or in some other process, is holding a RESERVED,
00598 ** PENDING, or EXCLUSIVE lock on the file.  It returns true
00599 ** if such a lock exists and false otherwise.
00600 **
00601 ** The xFileControl() method is a generic interface that allows custom
00602 ** VFS implementations to directly control an open file using the
00603 ** [sqlite3_file_control()] interface.  The second "op" argument is an
00604 ** integer opcode.  The third argument is a generic pointer intended to
00605 ** point to a structure that may contain arguments or space in which to
00606 ** write return values.  Potential uses for xFileControl() might be
00607 ** functions to enable blocking locks with timeouts, to change the
00608 ** locking strategy (for example to use dot-file locks), to inquire
00609 ** about the status of a lock, or to break stale locks.  The SQLite
00610 ** core reserves all opcodes less than 100 for its own use.
00611 ** A [SQLITE_FCNTL_LOCKSTATE | list of opcodes] less than 100 is available.
00612 ** Applications that define a custom xFileControl method should use opcodes
00613 ** greater than 100 to avoid conflicts.
00614 **
00615 ** The xSectorSize() method returns the sector size of the
00616 ** device that underlies the file.  The sector size is the
00617 ** minimum write that can be performed without disturbing
00618 ** other bytes in the file.  The xDeviceCharacteristics()
00619 ** method returns a bit vector describing behaviors of the
00620 ** underlying device:
00621 **
00622 ** <ul>
00623 ** <li> [SQLITE_IOCAP_ATOMIC]
00624 ** <li> [SQLITE_IOCAP_ATOMIC512]
00625 ** <li> [SQLITE_IOCAP_ATOMIC1K]
00626 ** <li> [SQLITE_IOCAP_ATOMIC2K]
00627 ** <li> [SQLITE_IOCAP_ATOMIC4K]
00628 ** <li> [SQLITE_IOCAP_ATOMIC8K]
00629 ** <li> [SQLITE_IOCAP_ATOMIC16K]
00630 ** <li> [SQLITE_IOCAP_ATOMIC32K]
00631 ** <li> [SQLITE_IOCAP_ATOMIC64K]
00632 ** <li> [SQLITE_IOCAP_SAFE_APPEND]
00633 ** <li> [SQLITE_IOCAP_SEQUENTIAL]
00634 ** </ul>
00635 **
00636 ** The SQLITE_IOCAP_ATOMIC property means that all writes of
00637 ** any size are atomic.  The SQLITE_IOCAP_ATOMICnnn values
00638 ** mean that writes of blocks that are nnn bytes in size and
00639 ** are aligned to an address which is an integer multiple of
00640 ** nnn are atomic.  The SQLITE_IOCAP_SAFE_APPEND value means
00641 ** that when data is appended to a file, the data is appended
00642 ** first then the size of the file is extended, never the other
00643 ** way around.  The SQLITE_IOCAP_SEQUENTIAL property means that
00644 ** information is written to disk in the same order as calls
00645 ** to xWrite().
00646 **
00647 ** If xRead() returns SQLITE_IOERR_SHORT_READ it must also fill
00648 ** in the unread portions of the buffer with zeros.  A VFS that
00649 ** fails to zero-fill short reads might seem to work.  However,
00650 ** failure to zero-fill short reads will eventually lead to
00651 ** database corruption.
00652 */
00653 typedef struct sqlite3_io_methods sqlite3_io_methods;
00654 struct sqlite3_io_methods {
00655   int iVersion;
00656   int (*xClose)(sqlite3_file*);
00657   int (*xRead)(sqlite3_file*, void*, int iAmt, sqlite3_int64 iOfst);
00658   int (*xWrite)(sqlite3_file*, const void*, int iAmt, sqlite3_int64 iOfst);
00659   int (*xTruncate)(sqlite3_file*, sqlite3_int64 size);
00660   int (*xSync)(sqlite3_file*, int flags);
00661   int (*xFileSize)(sqlite3_file*, sqlite3_int64 *pSize);
00662   int (*xLock)(sqlite3_file*, int);
00663   int (*xUnlock)(sqlite3_file*, int);
00664   int (*xCheckReservedLock)(sqlite3_file*, int *pResOut);
00665   int (*xFileControl)(sqlite3_file*, int op, void *pArg);
00666   int (*xSectorSize)(sqlite3_file*);
00667   int (*xDeviceCharacteristics)(sqlite3_file*);
00668   /* Methods above are valid for version 1 */
00669   int (*xShmMap)(sqlite3_file*, int iPg, int pgsz, int, void volatile**);
00670   int (*xShmLock)(sqlite3_file*, int offset, int n, int flags);
00671   void (*xShmBarrier)(sqlite3_file*);
00672   int (*xShmUnmap)(sqlite3_file*, int deleteFlag);
00673   /* Methods above are valid for version 2 */
00674   /* Additional methods may be added in future releases */
00675 };
00676 
00677 /*
00678 ** CAPI3REF: Standard File Control Opcodes
00679 **
00680 ** These integer constants are opcodes for the xFileControl method
00681 ** of the [sqlite3_io_methods] object and for the [sqlite3_file_control()]
00682 ** interface.
00683 **
00684 ** The [SQLITE_FCNTL_LOCKSTATE] opcode is used for debugging.  This
00685 ** opcode causes the xFileControl method to write the current state of
00686 ** the lock (one of [SQLITE_LOCK_NONE], [SQLITE_LOCK_SHARED],
00687 ** [SQLITE_LOCK_RESERVED], [SQLITE_LOCK_PENDING], or [SQLITE_LOCK_EXCLUSIVE])
00688 ** into an integer that the pArg argument points to. This capability
00689 ** is used during testing and only needs to be supported when SQLITE_TEST
00690 ** is defined.
00691 **
00692 ** The [SQLITE_FCNTL_SIZE_HINT] opcode is used by SQLite to give the VFS
00693 ** layer a hint of how large the database file will grow to be during the
00694 ** current transaction.  This hint is not guaranteed to be accurate but it
00695 ** is often close.  The underlying VFS might choose to preallocate database
00696 ** file space based on this hint in order to help writes to the database
00697 ** file run faster.
00698 **
00699 ** The [SQLITE_FCNTL_CHUNK_SIZE] opcode is used to request that the VFS
00700 ** extends and truncates the database file in chunks of a size specified
00701 ** by the user. The fourth argument to [sqlite3_file_control()] should 
00702 ** point to an integer (type int) containing the new chunk-size to use
00703 ** for the nominated database. Allocating database file space in large
00704 ** chunks (say 1MB at a time), may reduce file-system fragmentation and
00705 ** improve performance on some systems.
00706 */
00707 #define SQLITE_FCNTL_LOCKSTATE        1
00708 #define SQLITE_GET_LOCKPROXYFILE      2
00709 #define SQLITE_SET_LOCKPROXYFILE      3
00710 #define SQLITE_LAST_ERRNO             4
00711 #define SQLITE_FCNTL_SIZE_HINT        5
00712 #define SQLITE_FCNTL_CHUNK_SIZE       6
00713 
00714 /*
00715 ** CAPI3REF: Mutex Handle
00716 **
00717 ** The mutex module within SQLite defines [sqlite3_mutex] to be an
00718 ** abstract type for a mutex object.  The SQLite core never looks
00719 ** at the internal representation of an [sqlite3_mutex].  It only
00720 ** deals with pointers to the [sqlite3_mutex] object.
00721 **
00722 ** Mutexes are created using [sqlite3_mutex_alloc()].
00723 */
00724 typedef struct sqlite3_mutex sqlite3_mutex;
00725 
00726 /*
00727 ** CAPI3REF: OS Interface Object
00728 **
00729 ** An instance of the sqlite3_vfs object defines the interface between
00730 ** the SQLite core and the underlying operating system.  The "vfs"
00731 ** in the name of the object stands for "virtual file system".
00732 **
00733 ** The value of the iVersion field is initially 1 but may be larger in
00734 ** future versions of SQLite.  Additional fields may be appended to this
00735 ** object when the iVersion value is increased.  Note that the structure
00736 ** of the sqlite3_vfs object changes in the transaction between
00737 ** SQLite version 3.5.9 and 3.6.0 and yet the iVersion field was not
00738 ** modified.
00739 **
00740 ** The szOsFile field is the size of the subclassed [sqlite3_file]
00741 ** structure used by this VFS.  mxPathname is the maximum length of
00742 ** a pathname in this VFS.
00743 **
00744 ** Registered sqlite3_vfs objects are kept on a linked list formed by
00745 ** the pNext pointer.  The [sqlite3_vfs_register()]
00746 ** and [sqlite3_vfs_unregister()] interfaces manage this list
00747 ** in a thread-safe way.  The [sqlite3_vfs_find()] interface
00748 ** searches the list.  Neither the application code nor the VFS
00749 ** implementation should use the pNext pointer.
00750 **
00751 ** The pNext field is the only field in the sqlite3_vfs
00752 ** structure that SQLite will ever modify.  SQLite will only access
00753 ** or modify this field while holding a particular static mutex.
00754 ** The application should never modify anything within the sqlite3_vfs
00755 ** object once the object has been registered.
00756 **
00757 ** The zName field holds the name of the VFS module.  The name must
00758 ** be unique across all VFS modules.
00759 **
00760 ** ^SQLite guarantees that the zFilename parameter to xOpen
00761 ** is either a NULL pointer or string obtained
00762 ** from xFullPathname() with an optional suffix added.
00763 ** ^If a suffix is added to the zFilename parameter, it will
00764 ** consist of a single "-" character followed by no more than
00765 ** 10 alphanumeric and/or "-" characters.
00766 ** ^SQLite further guarantees that
00767 ** the string will be valid and unchanged until xClose() is
00768 ** called. Because of the previous sentence,
00769 ** the [sqlite3_file] can safely store a pointer to the
00770 ** filename if it needs to remember the filename for some reason.
00771 ** If the zFilename parameter to xOpen is a NULL pointer then xOpen
00772 ** must invent its own temporary name for the file.  ^Whenever the 
00773 ** xFilename parameter is NULL it will also be the case that the
00774 ** flags parameter will include [SQLITE_OPEN_DELETEONCLOSE].
00775 **
00776 ** The flags argument to xOpen() includes all bits set in
00777 ** the flags argument to [sqlite3_open_v2()].  Or if [sqlite3_open()]
00778 ** or [sqlite3_open16()] is used, then flags includes at least
00779 ** [SQLITE_OPEN_READWRITE] | [SQLITE_OPEN_CREATE]. 
00780 ** If xOpen() opens a file read-only then it sets *pOutFlags to
00781 ** include [SQLITE_OPEN_READONLY].  Other bits in *pOutFlags may be set.
00782 **
00783 ** ^(SQLite will also add one of the following flags to the xOpen()
00784 ** call, depending on the object being opened:
00785 **
00786 ** <ul>
00787 ** <li>  [SQLITE_OPEN_MAIN_DB]
00788 ** <li>  [SQLITE_OPEN_MAIN_JOURNAL]
00789 ** <li>  [SQLITE_OPEN_TEMP_DB]
00790 ** <li>  [SQLITE_OPEN_TEMP_JOURNAL]
00791 ** <li>  [SQLITE_OPEN_TRANSIENT_DB]
00792 ** <li>  [SQLITE_OPEN_SUBJOURNAL]
00793 ** <li>  [SQLITE_OPEN_MASTER_JOURNAL]
00794 ** <li>  [SQLITE_OPEN_WAL]
00795 ** </ul>)^
00796 **
00797 ** The file I/O implementation can use the object type flags to
00798 ** change the way it deals with files.  For example, an application
00799 ** that does not care about crash recovery or rollback might make
00800 ** the open of a journal file a no-op.  Writes to this journal would
00801 ** also be no-ops, and any attempt to read the journal would return
00802 ** SQLITE_IOERR.  Or the implementation might recognize that a database
00803 ** file will be doing page-aligned sector reads and writes in a random
00804 ** order and set up its I/O subsystem accordingly.
00805 **
00806 ** SQLite might also add one of the following flags to the xOpen method:
00807 **
00808 ** <ul>
00809 ** <li> [SQLITE_OPEN_DELETEONCLOSE]
00810 ** <li> [SQLITE_OPEN_EXCLUSIVE]
00811 ** </ul>
00812 **
00813 ** The [SQLITE_OPEN_DELETEONCLOSE] flag means the file should be
00814 ** deleted when it is closed.  ^The [SQLITE_OPEN_DELETEONCLOSE]
00815 ** will be set for TEMP databases and their journals, transient
00816 ** databases, and subjournals.
00817 **
00818 ** ^The [SQLITE_OPEN_EXCLUSIVE] flag is always used in conjunction
00819 ** with the [SQLITE_OPEN_CREATE] flag, which are both directly
00820 ** analogous to the O_EXCL and O_CREAT flags of the POSIX open()
00821 ** API.  The SQLITE_OPEN_EXCLUSIVE flag, when paired with the 
00822 ** SQLITE_OPEN_CREATE, is used to indicate that file should always
00823 ** be created, and that it is an error if it already exists.
00824 ** It is <i>not</i> used to indicate the file should be opened 
00825 ** for exclusive access.
00826 **
00827 ** ^At least szOsFile bytes of memory are allocated by SQLite
00828 ** to hold the  [sqlite3_file] structure passed as the third
00829 ** argument to xOpen.  The xOpen method does not have to
00830 ** allocate the structure; it should just fill it in.  Note that
00831 ** the xOpen method must set the sqlite3_file.pMethods to either
00832 ** a valid [sqlite3_io_methods] object or to NULL.  xOpen must do
00833 ** this even if the open fails.  SQLite expects that the sqlite3_file.pMethods
00834 ** element will be valid after xOpen returns regardless of the success
00835 ** or failure of the xOpen call.
00836 **
00837 ** ^The flags argument to xAccess() may be [SQLITE_ACCESS_EXISTS]
00838 ** to test for the existence of a file, or [SQLITE_ACCESS_READWRITE] to
00839 ** test whether a file is readable and writable, or [SQLITE_ACCESS_READ]
00840 ** to test whether a file is at least readable.   The file can be a
00841 ** directory.
00842 **
00843 ** ^SQLite will always allocate at least mxPathname+1 bytes for the
00844 ** output buffer xFullPathname.  The exact size of the output buffer
00845 ** is also passed as a parameter to both  methods. If the output buffer
00846 ** is not large enough, [SQLITE_CANTOPEN] should be returned. Since this is
00847 ** handled as a fatal error by SQLite, vfs implementations should endeavor
00848 ** to prevent this by setting mxPathname to a sufficiently large value.
00849 **
00850 ** The xRandomness(), xSleep(), xCurrentTime(), and xCurrentTimeInt64()
00851 ** interfaces are not strictly a part of the filesystem, but they are
00852 ** included in the VFS structure for completeness.
00853 ** The xRandomness() function attempts to return nBytes bytes
00854 ** of good-quality randomness into zOut.  The return value is
00855 ** the actual number of bytes of randomness obtained.
00856 ** The xSleep() method causes the calling thread to sleep for at
00857 ** least the number of microseconds given.  ^The xCurrentTime()
00858 ** method returns a Julian Day Number for the current date and time as
00859 ** a floating point value.
00860 ** ^The xCurrentTimeInt64() method returns, as an integer, the Julian
00861 ** Day Number multipled by 86400000 (the number of milliseconds in 
00862 ** a 24-hour day).  
00863 ** ^SQLite will use the xCurrentTimeInt64() method to get the current
00864 ** date and time if that method is available (if iVersion is 2 or 
00865 ** greater and the function pointer is not NULL) and will fall back
00866 ** to xCurrentTime() if xCurrentTimeInt64() is unavailable.
00867 */
00868 typedef struct sqlite3_vfs sqlite3_vfs;
00869 struct sqlite3_vfs {
00870   int iVersion;            /* Structure version number (currently 2) */
00871   int szOsFile;            /* Size of subclassed sqlite3_file */
00872   int mxPathname;          /* Maximum file pathname length */
00873   sqlite3_vfs *pNext;      /* Next registered VFS */
00874   const char *zName;       /* Name of this virtual file system */
00875   void *pAppData;          /* Pointer to application-specific data */
00876   int (*xOpen)(sqlite3_vfs*, const char *zName, sqlite3_file*,
00877                int flags, int *pOutFlags);
00878   int (*xDelete)(sqlite3_vfs*, const char *zName, int syncDir);
00879   int (*xAccess)(sqlite3_vfs*, const char *zName, int flags, int *pResOut);
00880   int (*xFullPathname)(sqlite3_vfs*, const char *zName, int nOut, char *zOut);
00881   void *(*xDlOpen)(sqlite3_vfs*, const char *zFilename);
00882   void (*xDlError)(sqlite3_vfs*, int nByte, char *zErrMsg);
00883   void (*(*xDlSym)(sqlite3_vfs*,void*, const char *zSymbol))(void);
00884   void (*xDlClose)(sqlite3_vfs*, void*);
00885   int (*xRandomness)(sqlite3_vfs*, int nByte, char *zOut);
00886   int (*xSleep)(sqlite3_vfs*, int microseconds);
00887   int (*xCurrentTime)(sqlite3_vfs*, double*);
00888   int (*xGetLastError)(sqlite3_vfs*, int, char *);
00889   /*
00890   ** The methods above are in version 1 of the sqlite_vfs object
00891   ** definition.  Those that follow are added in version 2 or later
00892   */
00893   int (*xCurrentTimeInt64)(sqlite3_vfs*, sqlite3_int64*);
00894   /*
00895   ** The methods above are in versions 1 and 2 of the sqlite_vfs object.
00896   ** New fields may be appended in figure versions.  The iVersion
00897   ** value will increment whenever this happens. 
00898   */
00899 };
00900 
00901 /*
00902 ** CAPI3REF: Flags for the xAccess VFS method
00903 **
00904 ** These integer constants can be used as the third parameter to
00905 ** the xAccess method of an [sqlite3_vfs] object.  They determine
00906 ** what kind of permissions the xAccess method is looking for.
00907 ** With SQLITE_ACCESS_EXISTS, the xAccess method
00908 ** simply checks whether the file exists.
00909 ** With SQLITE_ACCESS_READWRITE, the xAccess method
00910 ** checks whether the named directory is both readable and writable
00911 ** (in other words, if files can be added, removed, and renamed within
00912 ** the directory).
00913 ** The SQLITE_ACCESS_READWRITE constant is currently used only by the
00914 ** [temp_store_directory pragma], though this could change in a future
00915 ** release of SQLite.
00916 ** With SQLITE_ACCESS_READ, the xAccess method
00917 ** checks whether the file is readable.  The SQLITE_ACCESS_READ constant is
00918 ** currently unused, though it might be used in a future release of
00919 ** SQLite.
00920 */
00921 #define SQLITE_ACCESS_EXISTS    0
00922 #define SQLITE_ACCESS_READWRITE 1   /* Used by PRAGMA temp_store_directory */
00923 #define SQLITE_ACCESS_READ      2   /* Unused */
00924 
00925 /*
00926 ** CAPI3REF: Flags for the xShmLock VFS method
00927 **
00928 ** These integer constants define the various locking operations
00929 ** allowed by the xShmLock method of [sqlite3_io_methods].  The
00930 ** following are the only legal combinations of flags to the
00931 ** xShmLock method:
00932 **
00933 ** <ul>
00934 ** <li>  SQLITE_SHM_LOCK | SQLITE_SHM_SHARED
00935 ** <li>  SQLITE_SHM_LOCK | SQLITE_SHM_EXCLUSIVE
00936 ** <li>  SQLITE_SHM_UNLOCK | SQLITE_SHM_SHARED
00937 ** <li>  SQLITE_SHM_UNLOCK | SQLITE_SHM_EXCLUSIVE
00938 ** </ul>
00939 **
00940 ** When unlocking, the same SHARED or EXCLUSIVE flag must be supplied as
00941 ** was given no the corresponding lock.  
00942 **
00943 ** The xShmLock method can transition between unlocked and SHARED or
00944 ** between unlocked and EXCLUSIVE.  It cannot transition between SHARED
00945 ** and EXCLUSIVE.
00946 */
00947 #define SQLITE_SHM_UNLOCK       1
00948 #define SQLITE_SHM_LOCK         2
00949 #define SQLITE_SHM_SHARED       4
00950 #define SQLITE_SHM_EXCLUSIVE    8
00951 
00952 /*
00953 ** CAPI3REF: Maximum xShmLock index
00954 **
00955 ** The xShmLock method on [sqlite3_io_methods] may use values
00956 ** between 0 and this upper bound as its "offset" argument.
00957 ** The SQLite core will never attempt to acquire or release a
00958 ** lock outside of this range
00959 */
00960 #define SQLITE_SHM_NLOCK        8
00961 
00962 
00963 /*
00964 ** CAPI3REF: Initialize The SQLite Library
00965 **
00966 ** ^The sqlite3_initialize() routine initializes the
00967 ** SQLite library.  ^The sqlite3_shutdown() routine
00968 ** deallocates any resources that were allocated by sqlite3_initialize().
00969 ** These routines are designed to aid in process initialization and
00970 ** shutdown on embedded systems.  Workstation applications using
00971 ** SQLite normally do not need to invoke either of these routines.
00972 **
00973 ** A call to sqlite3_initialize() is an "effective" call if it is
00974 ** the first time sqlite3_initialize() is invoked during the lifetime of
00975 ** the process, or if it is the first time sqlite3_initialize() is invoked
00976 ** following a call to sqlite3_shutdown().  ^(Only an effective call
00977 ** of sqlite3_initialize() does any initialization.  All other calls
00978 ** are harmless no-ops.)^
00979 **
00980 ** A call to sqlite3_shutdown() is an "effective" call if it is the first
00981 ** call to sqlite3_shutdown() since the last sqlite3_initialize().  ^(Only
00982 ** an effective call to sqlite3_shutdown() does any deinitialization.
00983 ** All other valid calls to sqlite3_shutdown() are harmless no-ops.)^
00984 **
00985 ** The sqlite3_initialize() interface is threadsafe, but sqlite3_shutdown()
00986 ** is not.  The sqlite3_shutdown() interface must only be called from a
00987 ** single thread.  All open [database connections] must be closed and all
00988 ** other SQLite resources must be deallocated prior to invoking
00989 ** sqlite3_shutdown().
00990 **
00991 ** Among other things, ^sqlite3_initialize() will invoke
00992 ** sqlite3_os_init().  Similarly, ^sqlite3_shutdown()
00993 ** will invoke sqlite3_os_end().
00994 **
00995 ** ^The sqlite3_initialize() routine returns [SQLITE_OK] on success.
00996 ** ^If for some reason, sqlite3_initialize() is unable to initialize
00997 ** the library (perhaps it is unable to allocate a needed resource such
00998 ** as a mutex) it returns an [error code] other than [SQLITE_OK].
00999 **
01000 ** ^The sqlite3_initialize() routine is called internally by many other
01001 ** SQLite interfaces so that an application usually does not need to
01002 ** invoke sqlite3_initialize() directly.  For example, [sqlite3_open()]
01003 ** calls sqlite3_initialize() so the SQLite library will be automatically
01004 ** initialized when [sqlite3_open()] is called if it has not be initialized
01005 ** already.  ^However, if SQLite is compiled with the [SQLITE_OMIT_AUTOINIT]
01006 ** compile-time option, then the automatic calls to sqlite3_initialize()
01007 ** are omitted and the application must call sqlite3_initialize() directly
01008 ** prior to using any other SQLite interface.  For maximum portability,
01009 ** it is recommended that applications always invoke sqlite3_initialize()
01010 ** directly prior to using any other SQLite interface.  Future releases
01011 ** of SQLite may require this.  In other words, the behavior exhibited
01012 ** when SQLite is compiled with [SQLITE_OMIT_AUTOINIT] might become the
01013 ** default behavior in some future release of SQLite.
01014 **
01015 ** The sqlite3_os_init() routine does operating-system specific
01016 ** initialization of the SQLite library.  The sqlite3_os_end()
01017 ** routine undoes the effect of sqlite3_os_init().  Typical tasks
01018 ** performed by these routines include allocation or deallocation
01019 ** of static resources, initialization of global variables,
01020 ** setting up a default [sqlite3_vfs] module, or setting up
01021 ** a default configuration using [sqlite3_config()].
01022 **
01023 ** The application should never invoke either sqlite3_os_init()
01024 ** or sqlite3_os_end() directly.  The application should only invoke
01025 ** sqlite3_initialize() and sqlite3_shutdown().  The sqlite3_os_init()
01026 ** interface is called automatically by sqlite3_initialize() and
01027 ** sqlite3_os_end() is called by sqlite3_shutdown().  Appropriate
01028 ** implementations for sqlite3_os_init() and sqlite3_os_end()
01029 ** are built into SQLite when it is compiled for Unix, Windows, or OS/2.
01030 ** When [custom builds | built for other platforms]
01031 ** (using the [SQLITE_OS_OTHER=1] compile-time
01032 ** option) the application must supply a suitable implementation for
01033 ** sqlite3_os_init() and sqlite3_os_end().  An application-supplied
01034 ** implementation of sqlite3_os_init() or sqlite3_os_end()
01035 ** must return [SQLITE_OK] on success and some other [error code] upon
01036 ** failure.
01037 */
01038 SQLITE_API int sqlite3_initialize(void);
01039 SQLITE_API int sqlite3_shutdown(void);
01040 SQLITE_API int sqlite3_os_init(void);
01041 SQLITE_API int sqlite3_os_end(void);
01042 
01043 /*
01044 ** CAPI3REF: Configuring The SQLite Library
01045 **
01046 ** The sqlite3_config() interface is used to make global configuration
01047 ** changes to SQLite in order to tune SQLite to the specific needs of
01048 ** the application.  The default configuration is recommended for most
01049 ** applications and so this routine is usually not necessary.  It is
01050 ** provided to support rare applications with unusual needs.
01051 **
01052 ** The sqlite3_config() interface is not threadsafe.  The application
01053 ** must insure that no other SQLite interfaces are invoked by other
01054 ** threads while sqlite3_config() is running.  Furthermore, sqlite3_config()
01055 ** may only be invoked prior to library initialization using
01056 ** [sqlite3_initialize()] or after shutdown by [sqlite3_shutdown()].
01057 ** ^If sqlite3_config() is called after [sqlite3_initialize()] and before
01058 ** [sqlite3_shutdown()] then it will return SQLITE_MISUSE.
01059 ** Note, however, that ^sqlite3_config() can be called as part of the
01060 ** implementation of an application-defined [sqlite3_os_init()].
01061 **
01062 ** The first argument to sqlite3_config() is an integer
01063 ** [SQLITE_CONFIG_SINGLETHREAD | configuration option] that determines
01064 ** what property of SQLite is to be configured.  Subsequent arguments
01065 ** vary depending on the [SQLITE_CONFIG_SINGLETHREAD | configuration option]
01066 ** in the first argument.
01067 **
01068 ** ^When a configuration option is set, sqlite3_config() returns [SQLITE_OK].
01069 ** ^If the option is unknown or SQLite is unable to set the option
01070 ** then this routine returns a non-zero [error code].
01071 */
01072 SQLITE_API int sqlite3_config(int, ...);
01073 
01074 /*
01075 ** CAPI3REF: Configure database connections
01076 **
01077 ** The sqlite3_db_config() interface is used to make configuration
01078 ** changes to a [database connection].  The interface is similar to
01079 ** [sqlite3_config()] except that the changes apply to a single
01080 ** [database connection] (specified in the first argument).  The
01081 ** sqlite3_db_config() interface should only be used immediately after
01082 ** the database connection is created using [sqlite3_open()],
01083 ** [sqlite3_open16()], or [sqlite3_open_v2()].  
01084 **
01085 ** The second argument to sqlite3_db_config(D,V,...)  is the
01086 ** configuration verb - an integer code that indicates what
01087 ** aspect of the [database connection] is being configured.
01088 ** The only choice for this value is [SQLITE_DBCONFIG_LOOKASIDE].
01089 ** New verbs are likely to be added in future releases of SQLite.
01090 ** Additional arguments depend on the verb.
01091 **
01092 ** ^Calls to sqlite3_db_config() return SQLITE_OK if and only if
01093 ** the call is considered successful.
01094 */
01095 SQLITE_API int sqlite3_db_config(sqlite3*, int op, ...);
01096 
01097 /*
01098 ** CAPI3REF: Memory Allocation Routines
01099 **
01100 ** An instance of this object defines the interface between SQLite
01101 ** and low-level memory allocation routines.
01102 **
01103 ** This object is used in only one place in the SQLite interface.
01104 ** A pointer to an instance of this object is the argument to
01105 ** [sqlite3_config()] when the configuration option is
01106 ** [SQLITE_CONFIG_MALLOC] or [SQLITE_CONFIG_GETMALLOC].  
01107 ** By creating an instance of this object
01108 ** and passing it to [sqlite3_config]([SQLITE_CONFIG_MALLOC])
01109 ** during configuration, an application can specify an alternative
01110 ** memory allocation subsystem for SQLite to use for all of its
01111 ** dynamic memory needs.
01112 **
01113 ** Note that SQLite comes with several [built-in memory allocators]
01114 ** that are perfectly adequate for the overwhelming majority of applications
01115 ** and that this object is only useful to a tiny minority of applications
01116 ** with specialized memory allocation requirements.  This object is
01117 ** also used during testing of SQLite in order to specify an alternative
01118 ** memory allocator that simulates memory out-of-memory conditions in
01119 ** order to verify that SQLite recovers gracefully from such
01120 ** conditions.
01121 **
01122 ** The xMalloc and xFree methods must work like the
01123 ** malloc() and free() functions from the standard C library.
01124 ** The xRealloc method must work like realloc() from the standard C library
01125 ** with the exception that if the second argument to xRealloc is zero,
01126 ** xRealloc must be a no-op - it must not perform any allocation or
01127 ** deallocation.  ^SQLite guarantees that the second argument to
01128 ** xRealloc is always a value returned by a prior call to xRoundup.
01129 ** And so in cases where xRoundup always returns a positive number,
01130 ** xRealloc can perform exactly as the standard library realloc() and
01131 ** still be in compliance with this specification.
01132 **
01133 ** xSize should return the allocated size of a memory allocation
01134 ** previously obtained from xMalloc or xRealloc.  The allocated size
01135 ** is always at least as big as the requested size but may be larger.
01136 **
01137 ** The xRoundup method returns what would be the allocated size of
01138 ** a memory allocation given a particular requested size.  Most memory
01139 ** allocators round up memory allocations at least to the next multiple
01140 ** of 8.  Some allocators round up to a larger multiple or to a power of 2.
01141 ** Every memory allocation request coming in through [sqlite3_malloc()]
01142 ** or [sqlite3_realloc()] first calls xRoundup.  If xRoundup returns 0, 
01143 ** that causes the corresponding memory allocation to fail.
01144 **
01145 ** The xInit method initializes the memory allocator.  (For example,
01146 ** it might allocate any require mutexes or initialize internal data
01147 ** structures.  The xShutdown method is invoked (indirectly) by
01148 ** [sqlite3_shutdown()] and should deallocate any resources acquired
01149 ** by xInit.  The pAppData pointer is used as the only parameter to
01150 ** xInit and xShutdown.
01151 **
01152 ** SQLite holds the [SQLITE_MUTEX_STATIC_MASTER] mutex when it invokes
01153 ** the xInit method, so the xInit method need not be threadsafe.  The
01154 ** xShutdown method is only called from [sqlite3_shutdown()] so it does
01155 ** not need to be threadsafe either.  For all other methods, SQLite
01156 ** holds the [SQLITE_MUTEX_STATIC_MEM] mutex as long as the
01157 ** [SQLITE_CONFIG_MEMSTATUS] configuration option is turned on (which
01158 ** it is by default) and so the methods are automatically serialized.
01159 ** However, if [SQLITE_CONFIG_MEMSTATUS] is disabled, then the other
01160 ** methods must be threadsafe or else make their own arrangements for
01161 ** serialization.
01162 **
01163 ** SQLite will never invoke xInit() more than once without an intervening
01164 ** call to xShutdown().
01165 */
01166 typedef struct sqlite3_mem_methods sqlite3_mem_methods;
01167 struct sqlite3_mem_methods {
01168   void *(*xMalloc)(int);         /* Memory allocation function */
01169   void (*xFree)(void*);          /* Free a prior allocation */
01170   void *(*xRealloc)(void*,int);  /* Resize an allocation */
01171   int (*xSize)(void*);           /* Return the size of an allocation */
01172   int (*xRoundup)(int);          /* Round up request size to allocation size */
01173   int (*xInit)(void*);           /* Initialize the memory allocator */
01174   void (*xShutdown)(void*);      /* Deinitialize the memory allocator */
01175   void *pAppData;                /* Argument to xInit() and xShutdown() */
01176 };
01177 
01178 /*
01179 ** CAPI3REF: Configuration Options
01180 **
01181 ** These constants are the available integer configuration options that
01182 ** can be passed as the first argument to the [sqlite3_config()] interface.
01183 **
01184 ** New configuration options may be added in future releases of SQLite.
01185 ** Existing configuration options might be discontinued.  Applications
01186 ** should check the return code from [sqlite3_config()] to make sure that
01187 ** the call worked.  The [sqlite3_config()] interface will return a
01188 ** non-zero [error code] if a discontinued or unsupported configuration option
01189 ** is invoked.
01190 **
01191 ** <dl>
01192 ** <dt>SQLITE_CONFIG_SINGLETHREAD</dt>
01193 ** <dd>There are no arguments to this option.  ^This option sets the
01194 ** [threading mode] to Single-thread.  In other words, it disables
01195 ** all mutexing and puts SQLite into a mode where it can only be used
01196 ** by a single thread.   ^If SQLite is compiled with
01197 ** the [SQLITE_THREADSAFE | SQLITE_THREADSAFE=0] compile-time option then
01198 ** it is not possible to change the [threading mode] from its default
01199 ** value of Single-thread and so [sqlite3_config()] will return 
01200 ** [SQLITE_ERROR] if called with the SQLITE_CONFIG_SINGLETHREAD
01201 ** configuration option.</dd>
01202 **
01203 ** <dt>SQLITE_CONFIG_MULTITHREAD</dt>
01204 ** <dd>There are no arguments to this option.  ^This option sets the
01205 ** [threading mode] to Multi-thread.  In other words, it disables
01206 ** mutexing on [database connection] and [prepared statement] objects.
01207 ** The application is responsible for serializing access to
01208 ** [database connections] and [prepared statements].  But other mutexes
01209 ** are enabled so that SQLite will be safe to use in a multi-threaded
01210 ** environment as long as no two threads attempt to use the same
01211 ** [database connection] at the same time.  ^If SQLite is compiled with
01212 ** the [SQLITE_THREADSAFE | SQLITE_THREADSAFE=0] compile-time option then
01213 ** it is not possible to set the Multi-thread [threading mode] and
01214 ** [sqlite3_config()] will return [SQLITE_ERROR] if called with the
01215 ** SQLITE_CONFIG_MULTITHREAD configuration option.</dd>
01216 **
01217 ** <dt>SQLITE_CONFIG_SERIALIZED</dt>
01218 ** <dd>There are no arguments to this option.  ^This option sets the
01219 ** [threading mode] to Serialized. In other words, this option enables
01220 ** all mutexes including the recursive
01221 ** mutexes on [database connection] and [prepared statement] objects.
01222 ** In this mode (which is the default when SQLite is compiled with
01223 ** [SQLITE_THREADSAFE=1]) the SQLite library will itself serialize access
01224 ** to [database connections] and [prepared statements] so that the
01225 ** application is free to use the same [database connection] or the
01226 ** same [prepared statement] in different threads at the same time.
01227 ** ^If SQLite is compiled with
01228 ** the [SQLITE_THREADSAFE | SQLITE_THREADSAFE=0] compile-time option then
01229 ** it is not possible to set the Serialized [threading mode] and
01230 ** [sqlite3_config()] will return [SQLITE_ERROR] if called with the
01231 ** SQLITE_CONFIG_SERIALIZED configuration option.</dd>
01232 **
01233 ** <dt>SQLITE_CONFIG_MALLOC</dt>
01234 ** <dd> ^(This option takes a single argument which is a pointer to an
01235 ** instance of the [sqlite3_mem_methods] structure.  The argument specifies
01236 ** alternative low-level memory allocation routines to be used in place of
01237 ** the memory allocation routines built into SQLite.)^ ^SQLite makes
01238 ** its own private copy of the content of the [sqlite3_mem_methods] structure
01239 ** before the [sqlite3_config()] call returns.</dd>
01240 **
01241 ** <dt>SQLITE_CONFIG_GETMALLOC</dt>
01242 ** <dd> ^(This option takes a single argument which is a pointer to an
01243 ** instance of the [sqlite3_mem_methods] structure.  The [sqlite3_mem_methods]
01244 ** structure is filled with the currently defined memory allocation routines.)^
01245 ** This option can be used to overload the default memory allocation
01246 ** routines with a wrapper that simulations memory allocation failure or
01247 ** tracks memory usage, for example. </dd>
01248 **
01249 ** <dt>SQLITE_CONFIG_MEMSTATUS</dt>
01250 ** <dd> ^This option takes single argument of type int, interpreted as a 
01251 ** boolean, which enables or disables the collection of memory allocation 
01252 ** statistics. ^(When memory allocation statistics are disabled, the 
01253 ** following SQLite interfaces become non-operational:
01254 **   <ul>
01255 **   <li> [sqlite3_memory_used()]
01256 **   <li> [sqlite3_memory_highwater()]
01257 **   <li> [sqlite3_soft_heap_limit64()]
01258 **   <li> [sqlite3_status()]
01259 **   </ul>)^
01260 ** ^Memory allocation statistics are enabled by default unless SQLite is
01261 ** compiled with [SQLITE_DEFAULT_MEMSTATUS]=0 in which case memory
01262 ** allocation statistics are disabled by default.
01263 ** </dd>
01264 **
01265 ** <dt>SQLITE_CONFIG_SCRATCH</dt>
01266 ** <dd> ^This option specifies a static memory buffer that SQLite can use for
01267 ** scratch memory.  There are three arguments:  A pointer an 8-byte
01268 ** aligned memory buffer from which the scrach allocations will be
01269 ** drawn, the size of each scratch allocation (sz),
01270 ** and the maximum number of scratch allocations (N).  The sz
01271 ** argument must be a multiple of 16.
01272 ** The first argument must be a pointer to an 8-byte aligned buffer
01273 ** of at least sz*N bytes of memory.
01274 ** ^SQLite will use no more than two scratch buffers per thread.  So
01275 ** N should be set to twice the expected maximum number of threads.
01276 ** ^SQLite will never require a scratch buffer that is more than 6
01277 ** times the database page size. ^If SQLite needs needs additional
01278 ** scratch memory beyond what is provided by this configuration option, then 
01279 ** [sqlite3_malloc()] will be used to obtain the memory needed.</dd>
01280 **
01281 ** <dt>SQLITE_CONFIG_PAGECACHE</dt>
01282 ** <dd> ^This option specifies a static memory buffer that SQLite can use for
01283 ** the database page cache with the default page cache implemenation.  
01284 ** This configuration should not be used if an application-define page
01285 ** cache implementation is loaded using the SQLITE_CONFIG_PCACHE option.
01286 ** There are three arguments to this option: A pointer to 8-byte aligned
01287 ** memory, the size of each page buffer (sz), and the number of pages (N).
01288 ** The sz argument should be the size of the largest database page
01289 ** (a power of two between 512 and 32768) plus a little extra for each
01290 ** page header.  ^The page header size is 20 to 40 bytes depending on
01291 ** the host architecture.  ^It is harmless, apart from the wasted memory,
01292 ** to make sz a little too large.  The first
01293 ** argument should point to an allocation of at least sz*N bytes of memory.
01294 ** ^SQLite will use the memory provided by the first argument to satisfy its
01295 ** memory needs for the first N pages that it adds to cache.  ^If additional
01296 ** page cache memory is needed beyond what is provided by this option, then
01297 ** SQLite goes to [sqlite3_malloc()] for the additional storage space.
01298 ** The pointer in the first argument must
01299 ** be aligned to an 8-byte boundary or subsequent behavior of SQLite
01300 ** will be undefined.</dd>
01301 **
01302 ** <dt>SQLITE_CONFIG_HEAP</dt>
01303 ** <dd> ^This option specifies a static memory buffer that SQLite will use
01304 ** for all of its dynamic memory allocation needs beyond those provided
01305 ** for by [SQLITE_CONFIG_SCRATCH] and [SQLITE_CONFIG_PAGECACHE].
01306 ** There are three arguments: An 8-byte aligned pointer to the memory,
01307 ** the number of bytes in the memory buffer, and the minimum allocation size.
01308 ** ^If the first pointer (the memory pointer) is NULL, then SQLite reverts
01309 ** to using its default memory allocator (the system malloc() implementation),
01310 ** undoing any prior invocation of [SQLITE_CONFIG_MALLOC].  ^If the
01311 ** memory pointer is not NULL and either [SQLITE_ENABLE_MEMSYS3] or
01312 ** [SQLITE_ENABLE_MEMSYS5] are defined, then the alternative memory
01313 ** allocator is engaged to handle all of SQLites memory allocation needs.
01314 ** The first pointer (the memory pointer) must be aligned to an 8-byte
01315 ** boundary or subsequent behavior of SQLite will be undefined.</dd>
01316 **
01317 ** <dt>SQLITE_CONFIG_MUTEX</dt>
01318 ** <dd> ^(This option takes a single argument which is a pointer to an
01319 ** instance of the [sqlite3_mutex_methods] structure.  The argument specifies
01320 ** alternative low-level mutex routines to be used in place
01321 ** the mutex routines built into SQLite.)^  ^SQLite makes a copy of the
01322 ** content of the [sqlite3_mutex_methods] structure before the call to
01323 ** [sqlite3_config()] returns. ^If SQLite is compiled with
01324 ** the [SQLITE_THREADSAFE | SQLITE_THREADSAFE=0] compile-time option then
01325 ** the entire mutexing subsystem is omitted from the build and hence calls to
01326 ** [sqlite3_config()] with the SQLITE_CONFIG_MUTEX configuration option will
01327 ** return [SQLITE_ERROR].</dd>
01328 **
01329 ** <dt>SQLITE_CONFIG_GETMUTEX</dt>
01330 ** <dd> ^(This option takes a single argument which is a pointer to an
01331 ** instance of the [sqlite3_mutex_methods] structure.  The
01332 ** [sqlite3_mutex_methods]
01333 ** structure is filled with the currently defined mutex routines.)^
01334 ** This option can be used to overload the default mutex allocation
01335 ** routines with a wrapper used to track mutex usage for performance
01336 ** profiling or testing, for example.   ^If SQLite is compiled with
01337 ** the [SQLITE_THREADSAFE | SQLITE_THREADSAFE=0] compile-time option then
01338 ** the entire mutexing subsystem is omitted from the build and hence calls to
01339 ** [sqlite3_config()] with the SQLITE_CONFIG_GETMUTEX configuration option will
01340 ** return [SQLITE_ERROR].</dd>
01341 **
01342 ** <dt>SQLITE_CONFIG_LOOKASIDE</dt>
01343 ** <dd> ^(This option takes two arguments that determine the default
01344 ** memory allocation for the lookaside memory allocator on each
01345 ** [database connection].  The first argument is the
01346 ** size of each lookaside buffer slot and the second is the number of
01347 ** slots allocated to each database connection.)^  ^(This option sets the
01348 ** <i>default</i> lookaside size. The [SQLITE_DBCONFIG_LOOKASIDE]
01349 ** verb to [sqlite3_db_config()] can be used to change the lookaside
01350 ** configuration on individual connections.)^ </dd>
01351 **
01352 ** <dt>SQLITE_CONFIG_PCACHE</dt>
01353 ** <dd> ^(This option takes a single argument which is a pointer to
01354 ** an [sqlite3_pcache_methods] object.  This object specifies the interface
01355 ** to a custom page cache implementation.)^  ^SQLite makes a copy of the
01356 ** object and uses it for page cache memory allocations.</dd>
01357 **
01358 ** <dt>SQLITE_CONFIG_GETPCACHE</dt>
01359 ** <dd> ^(This option takes a single argument which is a pointer to an
01360 ** [sqlite3_pcache_methods] object.  SQLite copies of the current
01361 ** page cache implementation into that object.)^ </dd>
01362 **
01363 ** <dt>SQLITE_CONFIG_LOG</dt>
01364 ** <dd> ^The SQLITE_CONFIG_LOG option takes two arguments: a pointer to a
01365 ** function with a call signature of void(*)(void*,int,const char*), 
01366 ** and a pointer to void. ^If the function pointer is not NULL, it is
01367 ** invoked by [sqlite3_log()] to process each logging event.  ^If the
01368 ** function pointer is NULL, the [sqlite3_log()] interface becomes a no-op.
01369 ** ^The void pointer that is the second argument to SQLITE_CONFIG_LOG is
01370 ** passed through as the first parameter to the application-defined logger
01371 ** function whenever that function is invoked.  ^The second parameter to
01372 ** the logger function is a copy of the first parameter to the corresponding
01373 ** [sqlite3_log()] call and is intended to be a [result code] or an
01374 ** [extended result code].  ^The third parameter passed to the logger is
01375 ** log message after formatting via [sqlite3_snprintf()].
01376 ** The SQLite logging interface is not reentrant; the logger function
01377 ** supplied by the application must not invoke any SQLite interface.
01378 ** In a multi-threaded application, the application-defined logger
01379 ** function must be threadsafe. </dd>
01380 **
01381 ** </dl>
01382 */
01383 #define SQLITE_CONFIG_SINGLETHREAD  1  /* nil */
01384 #define SQLITE_CONFIG_MULTITHREAD   2  /* nil */
01385 #define SQLITE_CONFIG_SERIALIZED    3  /* nil */
01386 #define SQLITE_CONFIG_MALLOC        4  /* sqlite3_mem_methods* */
01387 #define SQLITE_CONFIG_GETMALLOC     5  /* sqlite3_mem_methods* */
01388 #define SQLITE_CONFIG_SCRATCH       6  /* void*, int sz, int N */
01389 #define SQLITE_CONFIG_PAGECACHE     7  /* void*, int sz, int N */
01390 #define SQLITE_CONFIG_HEAP          8  /* void*, int nByte, int min */
01391 #define SQLITE_CONFIG_MEMSTATUS     9  /* boolean */
01392 #define SQLITE_CONFIG_MUTEX        10  /* sqlite3_mutex_methods* */
01393 #define SQLITE_CONFIG_GETMUTEX     11  /* sqlite3_mutex_methods* */
01394 /* previously SQLITE_CONFIG_CHUNKALLOC 12 which is now unused. */ 
01395 #define SQLITE_CONFIG_LOOKASIDE    13  /* int int */
01396 #define SQLITE_CONFIG_PCACHE       14  /* sqlite3_pcache_methods* */
01397 #define SQLITE_CONFIG_GETPCACHE    15  /* sqlite3_pcache_methods* */
01398 #define SQLITE_CONFIG_LOG          16  /* xFunc, void* */
01399 
01400 /*
01401 ** CAPI3REF: Database Connection Configuration Options
01402 **
01403 ** These constants are the available integer configuration options that
01404 ** can be passed as the second argument to the [sqlite3_db_config()] interface.
01405 **
01406 ** New configuration options may be added in future releases of SQLite.
01407 ** Existing configuration options might be discontinued.  Applications
01408 ** should check the return code from [sqlite3_db_config()] to make sure that
01409 ** the call worked.  ^The [sqlite3_db_config()] interface will return a
01410 ** non-zero [error code] if a discontinued or unsupported configuration option
01411 ** is invoked.
01412 **
01413 ** <dl>
01414 ** <dt>SQLITE_DBCONFIG_LOOKASIDE</dt>
01415 ** <dd> ^This option takes three additional arguments that determine the 
01416 ** [lookaside memory allocator] configuration for the [database connection].
01417 ** ^The first argument (the third parameter to [sqlite3_db_config()] is a
01418 ** pointer to an memory buffer to use for lookaside memory.
01419 ** ^The first argument after the SQLITE_DBCONFIG_LOOKASIDE verb
01420 ** may be NULL in which case SQLite will allocate the
01421 ** lookaside buffer itself using [sqlite3_malloc()]. ^The second argument is the
01422 ** size of each lookaside buffer slot.  ^The third argument is the number of
01423 ** slots.  The size of the buffer in the first argument must be greater than
01424 ** or equal to the product of the second and third arguments.  The buffer
01425 ** must be aligned to an 8-byte boundary.  ^If the second argument to
01426 ** SQLITE_DBCONFIG_LOOKASIDE is not a multiple of 8, it is internally
01427 ** rounded down to the next smaller multiple of 8.  ^(The lookaside memory
01428 ** configuration for a database connection can only be changed when that
01429 ** connection is not currently using lookaside memory, or in other words
01430 ** when the "current value" returned by
01431 ** [sqlite3_db_status](D,[SQLITE_CONFIG_LOOKASIDE],...) is zero.
01432 ** Any attempt to change the lookaside memory configuration when lookaside
01433 ** memory is in use leaves the configuration unchanged and returns 
01434 ** [SQLITE_BUSY].)^</dd>
01435 **
01436 ** </dl>
01437 */
01438 #define SQLITE_DBCONFIG_LOOKASIDE    1001  /* void* int int */
01439 
01440 
01441 /*
01442 ** CAPI3REF: Enable Or Disable Extended Result Codes
01443 **
01444 ** ^The sqlite3_extended_result_codes() routine enables or disables the
01445 ** [extended result codes] feature of SQLite. ^The extended result
01446 ** codes are disabled by default for historical compatibility.
01447 */
01448 SQLITE_API int sqlite3_extended_result_codes(sqlite3*, int onoff);
01449 
01450 /*
01451 ** CAPI3REF: Last Insert Rowid
01452 **
01453 ** ^Each entry in an SQLite table has a unique 64-bit signed
01454 ** integer key called the [ROWID | "rowid"]. ^The rowid is always available
01455 ** as an undeclared column named ROWID, OID, or _ROWID_ as long as those
01456 ** names are not also used by explicitly declared columns. ^If
01457 ** the table has a column of type [INTEGER PRIMARY KEY] then that column
01458 ** is another alias for the rowid.
01459 **
01460 ** ^This routine returns the [rowid] of the most recent
01461 ** successful [INSERT] into the database from the [database connection]
01462 ** in the first argument.  ^If no successful [INSERT]s
01463 ** have ever occurred on that database connection, zero is returned.
01464 **
01465 ** ^(If an [INSERT] occurs within a trigger, then the [rowid] of the inserted
01466 ** row is returned by this routine as long as the trigger is running.
01467 ** But once the trigger terminates, the value returned by this routine
01468 ** reverts to the last value inserted before the trigger fired.)^
01469 **
01470 ** ^An [INSERT] that fails due to a constraint violation is not a
01471 ** successful [INSERT] and does not change the value returned by this
01472 ** routine.  ^Thus INSERT OR FAIL, INSERT OR IGNORE, INSERT OR ROLLBACK,
01473 ** and INSERT OR ABORT make no changes to the return value of this
01474 ** routine when their insertion fails.  ^(When INSERT OR REPLACE
01475 ** encounters a constraint violation, it does not fail.  The
01476 ** INSERT continues to completion after deleting rows that caused
01477 ** the constraint problem so INSERT OR REPLACE will always change
01478 ** the return value of this interface.)^
01479 **
01480 ** ^For the purposes of this routine, an [INSERT] is considered to
01481 ** be successful even if it is subsequently rolled back.
01482 **
01483 ** This function is accessible to SQL statements via the
01484 ** [last_insert_rowid() SQL function].
01485 **
