01486 ** If a separate thread performs a new [INSERT] on the same
01487 ** database connection while the [sqlite3_last_insert_rowid()]
01488 ** function is running and thus changes the last insert [rowid],
01489 ** then the value returned by [sqlite3_last_insert_rowid()] is
01490 ** unpredictable and might not equal either the old or the new
01491 ** last insert [rowid].
01492 */
01493 SQLITE_API sqlite3_int64 sqlite3_last_insert_rowid(sqlite3*);
01494 
01495 /*
01496 ** CAPI3REF: Count The Number Of Rows Modified
01497 **
01498 ** ^This function returns the number of database rows that were changed
01499 ** or inserted or deleted by the most recently completed SQL statement
01500 ** on the [database connection] specified by the first parameter.
01501 ** ^(Only changes that are directly specified by the [INSERT], [UPDATE],
01502 ** or [DELETE] statement are counted.  Auxiliary changes caused by
01503 ** triggers or [foreign key actions] are not counted.)^ Use the
01504 ** [sqlite3_total_changes()] function to find the total number of changes
01505 ** including changes caused by triggers and foreign key actions.
01506 **
01507 ** ^Changes to a view that are simulated by an [INSTEAD OF trigger]
01508 ** are not counted.  Only real table changes are counted.
01509 **
01510 ** ^(A "row change" is a change to a single row of a single table
01511 ** caused by an INSERT, DELETE, or UPDATE statement.  Rows that
01512 ** are changed as side effects of [REPLACE] constraint resolution,
01513 ** rollback, ABORT processing, [DROP TABLE], or by any other
01514 ** mechanisms do not count as direct row changes.)^
01515 **
01516 ** A "trigger context" is a scope of execution that begins and
01517 ** ends with the script of a [CREATE TRIGGER | trigger]. 
01518 ** Most SQL statements are
01519 ** evaluated outside of any trigger.  This is the "top level"
01520 ** trigger context.  If a trigger fires from the top level, a
01521 ** new trigger context is entered for the duration of that one
01522 ** trigger.  Subtriggers create subcontexts for their duration.
01523 **
01524 ** ^Calling [sqlite3_exec()] or [sqlite3_step()] recursively does
01525 ** not create a new trigger context.
01526 **
01527 ** ^This function returns the number of direct row changes in the
01528 ** most recent INSERT, UPDATE, or DELETE statement within the same
01529 ** trigger context.
01530 **
01531 ** ^Thus, when called from the top level, this function returns the
01532 ** number of changes in the most recent INSERT, UPDATE, or DELETE
01533 ** that also occurred at the top level.  ^(Within the body of a trigger,
01534 ** the sqlite3_changes() interface can be called to find the number of
01535 ** changes in the most recently completed INSERT, UPDATE, or DELETE
01536 ** statement within the body of the same trigger.
01537 ** However, the number returned does not include changes
01538 ** caused by subtriggers since those have their own context.)^
01539 **
01540 ** See also the [sqlite3_total_changes()] interface, the
01541 ** [count_changes pragma], and the [changes() SQL function].
01542 **
01543 ** If a separate thread makes changes on the same database connection
01544 ** while [sqlite3_changes()] is running then the value returned
01545 ** is unpredictable and not meaningful.
01546 */
01547 SQLITE_API int sqlite3_changes(sqlite3*);
01548 
01549 /*
01550 ** CAPI3REF: Total Number Of Rows Modified
01551 **
01552 ** ^This function returns the number of row changes caused by [INSERT],
01553 ** [UPDATE] or [DELETE] statements since the [database connection] was opened.
01554 ** ^(The count returned by sqlite3_total_changes() includes all changes
01555 ** from all [CREATE TRIGGER | trigger] contexts and changes made by
01556 ** [foreign key actions]. However,
01557 ** the count does not include changes used to implement [REPLACE] constraints,
01558 ** do rollbacks or ABORT processing, or [DROP TABLE] processing.  The
01559 ** count does not include rows of views that fire an [INSTEAD OF trigger],
01560 ** though if the INSTEAD OF trigger makes changes of its own, those changes 
01561 ** are counted.)^
01562 ** ^The sqlite3_total_changes() function counts the changes as soon as
01563 ** the statement that makes them is completed (when the statement handle
01564 ** is passed to [sqlite3_reset()] or [sqlite3_finalize()]).
01565 **
01566 ** See also the [sqlite3_changes()] interface, the
01567 ** [count_changes pragma], and the [total_changes() SQL function].
01568 **
01569 ** If a separate thread makes changes on the same database connection
01570 ** while [sqlite3_total_changes()] is running then the value
01571 ** returned is unpredictable and not meaningful.
01572 */
01573 SQLITE_API int sqlite3_total_changes(sqlite3*);
01574 
01575 /*
01576 ** CAPI3REF: Interrupt A Long-Running Query
01577 **
01578 ** ^This function causes any pending database operation to abort and
01579 ** return at its earliest opportunity. This routine is typically
01580 ** called in response to a user action such as pressing "Cancel"
01581 ** or Ctrl-C where the user wants a long query operation to halt
01582 ** immediately.
01583 **
01584 ** ^It is safe to call this routine from a thread different from the
01585 ** thread that is currently running the database operation.  But it
01586 ** is not safe to call this routine with a [database connection] that
01587 ** is closed or might close before sqlite3_interrupt() returns.
01588 **
01589 ** ^If an SQL operation is very nearly finished at the time when
01590 ** sqlite3_interrupt() is called, then it might not have an opportunity
01591 ** to be interrupted and might continue to completion.
01592 **
01593 ** ^An SQL operation that is interrupted will return [SQLITE_INTERRUPT].
01594 ** ^If the interrupted SQL operation is an INSERT, UPDATE, or DELETE
01595 ** that is inside an explicit transaction, then the entire transaction
01596 ** will be rolled back automatically.
01597 **
01598 ** ^The sqlite3_interrupt(D) call is in effect until all currently running
01599 ** SQL statements on [database connection] D complete.  ^Any new SQL statements
01600 ** that are started after the sqlite3_interrupt() call and before the 
01601 ** running statements reaches zero are interrupted as if they had been
01602 ** running prior to the sqlite3_interrupt() call.  ^New SQL statements
01603 ** that are started after the running statement count reaches zero are
01604 ** not effected by the sqlite3_interrupt().
01605 ** ^A call to sqlite3_interrupt(D) that occurs when there are no running
01606 ** SQL statements is a no-op and has no effect on SQL statements
01607 ** that are started after the sqlite3_interrupt() call returns.
01608 **
01609 ** If the database connection closes while [sqlite3_interrupt()]
01610 ** is running then bad things will likely happen.
01611 */
01612 SQLITE_API void sqlite3_interrupt(sqlite3*);
01613 
01614 /*
01615 ** CAPI3REF: Determine If An SQL Statement Is Complete
01616 **
01617 ** These routines are useful during command-line input to determine if the
01618 ** currently entered text seems to form a complete SQL statement or
01619 ** if additional input is needed before sending the text into
01620 ** SQLite for parsing.  ^These routines return 1 if the input string
01621 ** appears to be a complete SQL statement.  ^A statement is judged to be
01622 ** complete if it ends with a semicolon token and is not a prefix of a
01623 ** well-formed CREATE TRIGGER statement.  ^Semicolons that are embedded within
01624 ** string literals or quoted identifier names or comments are not
01625 ** independent tokens (they are part of the token in which they are
01626 ** embedded) and thus do not count as a statement terminator.  ^Whitespace
01627 ** and comments that follow the final semicolon are ignored.
01628 **
01629 ** ^These routines return 0 if the statement is incomplete.  ^If a
01630 ** memory allocation fails, then SQLITE_NOMEM is returned.
01631 **
01632 ** ^These routines do not parse the SQL statements thus
01633 ** will not detect syntactically incorrect SQL.
01634 **
01635 ** ^(If SQLite has not been initialized using [sqlite3_initialize()] prior 
01636 ** to invoking sqlite3_complete16() then sqlite3_initialize() is invoked
01637 ** automatically by sqlite3_complete16().  If that initialization fails,
01638 ** then the return value from sqlite3_complete16() will be non-zero
01639 ** regardless of whether or not the input SQL is complete.)^
01640 **
01641 ** The input to [sqlite3_complete()] must be a zero-terminated
01642 ** UTF-8 string.
01643 **
01644 ** The input to [sqlite3_complete16()] must be a zero-terminated
01645 ** UTF-16 string in native byte order.
01646 */
01647 SQLITE_API int sqlite3_complete(const char *sql);
01648 SQLITE_API int sqlite3_complete16(const void *sql);
01649 
01650 /*
01651 ** CAPI3REF: Register A Callback To Handle SQLITE_BUSY Errors
01652 **
01653 ** ^This routine sets a callback function that might be invoked whenever
01654 ** an attempt is made to open a database table that another thread
01655 ** or process has locked.
01656 **
01657 ** ^If the busy callback is NULL, then [SQLITE_BUSY] or [SQLITE_IOERR_BLOCKED]
01658 ** is returned immediately upon encountering the lock.  ^If the busy callback
01659 ** is not NULL, then the callback might be invoked with two arguments.
01660 **
01661 ** ^The first argument to the busy handler is a copy of the void* pointer which
01662 ** is the third argument to sqlite3_busy_handler().  ^The second argument to
01663 ** the busy handler callback is the number of times that the busy handler has
01664 ** been invoked for this locking event.  ^If the
01665 ** busy callback returns 0, then no additional attempts are made to
01666 ** access the database and [SQLITE_BUSY] or [SQLITE_IOERR_BLOCKED] is returned.
01667 ** ^If the callback returns non-zero, then another attempt
01668 ** is made to open the database for reading and the cycle repeats.
01669 **
01670 ** The presence of a busy handler does not guarantee that it will be invoked
01671 ** when there is lock contention. ^If SQLite determines that invoking the busy
01672 ** handler could result in a deadlock, it will go ahead and return [SQLITE_BUSY]
01673 ** or [SQLITE_IOERR_BLOCKED] instead of invoking the busy handler.
01674 ** Consider a scenario where one process is holding a read lock that
01675 ** it is trying to promote to a reserved lock and
01676 ** a second process is holding a reserved lock that it is trying
01677 ** to promote to an exclusive lock.  The first process cannot proceed
01678 ** because it is blocked by the second and the second process cannot
01679 ** proceed because it is blocked by the first.  If both processes
01680 ** invoke the busy handlers, neither will make any progress.  Therefore,
01681 ** SQLite returns [SQLITE_BUSY] for the first process, hoping that this
01682 ** will induce the first process to release its read lock and allow
01683 ** the second process to proceed.
01684 **
01685 ** ^The default busy callback is NULL.
01686 **
01687 ** ^The [SQLITE_BUSY] error is converted to [SQLITE_IOERR_BLOCKED]
01688 ** when SQLite is in the middle of a large transaction where all the
01689 ** changes will not fit into the in-memory cache.  SQLite will
01690 ** already hold a RESERVED lock on the database file, but it needs
01691 ** to promote this lock to EXCLUSIVE so that it can spill cache
01692 ** pages into the database file without harm to concurrent
01693 ** readers.  ^If it is unable to promote the lock, then the in-memory
01694 ** cache will be left in an inconsistent state and so the error
01695 ** code is promoted from the relatively benign [SQLITE_BUSY] to
01696 ** the more severe [SQLITE_IOERR_BLOCKED].  ^This error code promotion
01697 ** forces an automatic rollback of the changes.  See the
01698 ** <a href="/cvstrac/wiki?p=CorruptionFollowingBusyError">
01699 ** CorruptionFollowingBusyError</a> wiki page for a discussion of why
01700 ** this is important.
01701 **
01702 ** ^(There can only be a single busy handler defined for each
01703 ** [database connection].  Setting a new busy handler clears any
01704 ** previously set handler.)^  ^Note that calling [sqlite3_busy_timeout()]
01705 ** will also set or clear the busy handler.
01706 **
01707 ** The busy callback should not take any actions which modify the
01708 ** database connection that invoked the busy handler.  Any such actions
01709 ** result in undefined behavior.
01710 ** 
01711 ** A busy handler must not close the database connection
01712 ** or [prepared statement] that invoked the busy handler.
01713 */
01714 SQLITE_API int sqlite3_busy_handler(sqlite3*, int(*)(void*,int), void*);
01715 
01716 /*
01717 ** CAPI3REF: Set A Busy Timeout
01718 **
01719 ** ^This routine sets a [sqlite3_busy_handler | busy handler] that sleeps
01720 ** for a specified amount of time when a table is locked.  ^The handler
01721 ** will sleep multiple times until at least "ms" milliseconds of sleeping
01722 ** have accumulated.  ^After at least "ms" milliseconds of sleeping,
01723 ** the handler returns 0 which causes [sqlite3_step()] to return
01724 ** [SQLITE_BUSY] or [SQLITE_IOERR_BLOCKED].
01725 **
01726 ** ^Calling this routine with an argument less than or equal to zero
01727 ** turns off all busy handlers.
01728 **
01729 ** ^(There can only be a single busy handler for a particular
01730 ** [database connection] any any given moment.  If another busy handler
01731 ** was defined  (using [sqlite3_busy_handler()]) prior to calling
01732 ** this routine, that other busy handler is cleared.)^
01733 */
01734 SQLITE_API int sqlite3_busy_timeout(sqlite3*, int ms);
01735 
01736 /*
01737 ** CAPI3REF: Convenience Routines For Running Queries
01738 **
01739 ** This is a legacy interface that is preserved for backwards compatibility.
01740 ** Use of this interface is not recommended.
01741 **
01742 ** Definition: A <b>result table</b> is memory data structure created by the
01743 ** [sqlite3_get_table()] interface.  A result table records the
01744 ** complete query results from one or more queries.
01745 **
01746 ** The table conceptually has a number of rows and columns.  But
01747 ** these numbers are not part of the result table itself.  These
01748 ** numbers are obtained separately.  Let N be the number of rows
01749 ** and M be the number of columns.
01750 **
01751 ** A result table is an array of pointers to zero-terminated UTF-8 strings.
01752 ** There are (N+1)*M elements in the array.  The first M pointers point
01753 ** to zero-terminated strings that  contain the names of the columns.
01754 ** The remaining entries all point to query results.  NULL values result
01755 ** in NULL pointers.  All other values are in their UTF-8 zero-terminated
01756 ** string representation as returned by [sqlite3_column_text()].
01757 **
01758 ** A result table might consist of one or more memory allocations.
01759 ** It is not safe to pass a result table directly to [sqlite3_free()].
01760 ** A result table should be deallocated using [sqlite3_free_table()].
01761 **
01762 ** ^(As an example of the result table format, suppose a query result
01763 ** is as follows:
01764 **
01765 ** <blockquote><pre>
01766 **        Name        | Age
01767 **        -----------------------
01768 **        Alice       | 43
01769 **        Bob         | 28
01770 **        Cindy       | 21
01771 ** </pre></blockquote>
01772 **
01773 ** There are two column (M==2) and three rows (N==3).  Thus the
01774 ** result table has 8 entries.  Suppose the result table is stored
01775 ** in an array names azResult.  Then azResult holds this content:
01776 **
01777 ** <blockquote><pre>
01778 **        azResult&#91;0] = "Name";
01779 **        azResult&#91;1] = "Age";
01780 **        azResult&#91;2] = "Alice";
01781 **        azResult&#91;3] = "43";
01782 **        azResult&#91;4] = "Bob";
01783 **        azResult&#91;5] = "28";
01784 **        azResult&#91;6] = "Cindy";
01785 **        azResult&#91;7] = "21";
01786 ** </pre></blockquote>)^
01787 **
01788 ** ^The sqlite3_get_table() function evaluates one or more
01789 ** semicolon-separated SQL statements in the zero-terminated UTF-8
01790 ** string of its 2nd parameter and returns a result table to the
01791 ** pointer given in its 3rd parameter.
01792 **
01793 ** After the application has finished with the result from sqlite3_get_table(),
01794 ** it must pass the result table pointer to sqlite3_free_table() in order to
01795 ** release the memory that was malloced.  Because of the way the
01796 ** [sqlite3_malloc()] happens within sqlite3_get_table(), the calling
01797 ** function must not try to call [sqlite3_free()] directly.  Only
01798 ** [sqlite3_free_table()] is able to release the memory properly and safely.
01799 **
01800 ** The sqlite3_get_table() interface is implemented as a wrapper around
01801 ** [sqlite3_exec()].  The sqlite3_get_table() routine does not have access
01802 ** to any internal data structures of SQLite.  It uses only the public
01803 ** interface defined here.  As a consequence, errors that occur in the
01804 ** wrapper layer outside of the internal [sqlite3_exec()] call are not
01805 ** reflected in subsequent calls to [sqlite3_errcode()] or
01806 ** [sqlite3_errmsg()].
01807 */
01808 SQLITE_API int sqlite3_get_table(
01809   sqlite3 *db,          /* An open database */
01810   const char *zSql,     /* SQL to be evaluated */
01811   char ***pazResult,    /* Results of the query */
01812   int *pnRow,           /* Number of result rows written here */
01813   int *pnColumn,        /* Number of result columns written here */
01814   char **pzErrmsg       /* Error msg written here */
01815 );
01816 SQLITE_API void sqlite3_free_table(char **result);
01817 
01818 /*
01819 ** CAPI3REF: Formatted String Printing Functions
01820 **
01821 ** These routines are work-alikes of the "printf()" family of functions
01822 ** from the standard C library.
01823 **
01824 ** ^The sqlite3_mprintf() and sqlite3_vmprintf() routines write their
01825 ** results into memory obtained from [sqlite3_malloc()].
01826 ** The strings returned by these two routines should be
01827 ** released by [sqlite3_free()].  ^Both routines return a
01828 ** NULL pointer if [sqlite3_malloc()] is unable to allocate enough
01829 ** memory to hold the resulting string.
01830 **
01831 ** ^(In sqlite3_snprintf() routine is similar to "snprintf()" from
01832 ** the standard C library.  The result is written into the
01833 ** buffer supplied as the second parameter whose size is given by
01834 ** the first parameter. Note that the order of the
01835 ** first two parameters is reversed from snprintf().)^  This is an
01836 ** historical accident that cannot be fixed without breaking
01837 ** backwards compatibility.  ^(Note also that sqlite3_snprintf()
01838 ** returns a pointer to its buffer instead of the number of
01839 ** characters actually written into the buffer.)^  We admit that
01840 ** the number of characters written would be a more useful return
01841 ** value but we cannot change the implementation of sqlite3_snprintf()
01842 ** now without breaking compatibility.
01843 **
01844 ** ^As long as the buffer size is greater than zero, sqlite3_snprintf()
01845 ** guarantees that the buffer is always zero-terminated.  ^The first
01846 ** parameter "n" is the total size of the buffer, including space for
01847 ** the zero terminator.  So the longest string that can be completely
01848 ** written will be n-1 characters.
01849 **
01850 ** These routines all implement some additional formatting
01851 ** options that are useful for constructing SQL statements.
01852 ** All of the usual printf() formatting options apply.  In addition, there
01853 ** is are "%q", "%Q", and "%z" options.
01854 **
01855 ** ^(The %q option works like %s in that it substitutes a null-terminated
01856 ** string from the argument list.  But %q also doubles every '\'' character.
01857 ** %q is designed for use inside a string literal.)^  By doubling each '\''
01858 ** character it escapes that character and allows it to be inserted into
01859 ** the string.
01860 **
01861 ** For example, assume the string variable zText contains text as follows:
01862 **
01863 ** <blockquote><pre>
01864 **  char *zText = "It's a happy day!";
01865 ** </pre></blockquote>
01866 **
01867 ** One can use this text in an SQL statement as follows:
01868 **
01869 ** <blockquote><pre>
01870 **  char *zSQL = sqlite3_mprintf("INSERT INTO table VALUES('%q')", zText);
01871 **  sqlite3_exec(db, zSQL, 0, 0, 0);
01872 **  sqlite3_free(zSQL);
01873 ** </pre></blockquote>
01874 **
01875 ** Because the %q format string is used, the '\'' character in zText
01876 ** is escaped and the SQL generated is as follows:
01877 **
01878 ** <blockquote><pre>
01879 **  INSERT INTO table1 VALUES('It''s a happy day!')
01880 ** </pre></blockquote>
01881 **
01882 ** This is correct.  Had we used %s instead of %q, the generated SQL
01883 ** would have looked like this:
01884 **
01885 ** <blockquote><pre>
01886 **  INSERT INTO table1 VALUES('It's a happy day!');
01887 ** </pre></blockquote>
01888 **
01889 ** This second example is an SQL syntax error.  As a general rule you should
01890 ** always use %q instead of %s when inserting text into a string literal.
01891 **
01892 ** ^(The %Q option works like %q except it also adds single quotes around
01893 ** the outside of the total string.  Additionally, if the parameter in the
01894 ** argument list is a NULL pointer, %Q substitutes the text "NULL" (without
01895 ** single quotes).)^  So, for example, one could say:
01896 **
01897 ** <blockquote><pre>
01898 **  char *zSQL = sqlite3_mprintf("INSERT INTO table VALUES(%Q)", zText);
01899 **  sqlite3_exec(db, zSQL, 0, 0, 0);
01900 **  sqlite3_free(zSQL);
01901 ** </pre></blockquote>
01902 **
01903 ** The code above will render a correct SQL statement in the zSQL
01904 ** variable even if the zText variable is a NULL pointer.
01905 **
01906 ** ^(The "%z" formatting option works like "%s" but with the
01907 ** addition that after the string has been read and copied into
01908 ** the result, [sqlite3_free()] is called on the input string.)^
01909 */
01910 SQLITE_API char *sqlite3_mprintf(const char*,...);
01911 SQLITE_API char *sqlite3_vmprintf(const char*, va_list);
01912 SQLITE_API char *sqlite3_snprintf(int,char*,const char*, ...);
01913 
01914 /*
01915 ** CAPI3REF: Memory Allocation Subsystem
01916 **
01917 ** The SQLite core uses these three routines for all of its own
01918 ** internal memory allocation needs. "Core" in the previous sentence
01919 ** does not include operating-system specific VFS implementation.  The
01920 ** Windows VFS uses native malloc() and free() for some operations.
01921 **
01922 ** ^The sqlite3_malloc() routine returns a pointer to a block
01923 ** of memory at least N bytes in length, where N is the parameter.
01924 ** ^If sqlite3_malloc() is unable to obtain sufficient free
01925 ** memory, it returns a NULL pointer.  ^If the parameter N to
01926 ** sqlite3_malloc() is zero or negative then sqlite3_malloc() returns
01927 ** a NULL pointer.
01928 **
01929 ** ^Calling sqlite3_free() with a pointer previously returned
01930 ** by sqlite3_malloc() or sqlite3_realloc() releases that memory so
01931 ** that it might be reused.  ^The sqlite3_free() routine is
01932 ** a no-op if is called with a NULL pointer.  Passing a NULL pointer
01933 ** to sqlite3_free() is harmless.  After being freed, memory
01934 ** should neither be read nor written.  Even reading previously freed
01935 ** memory might result in a segmentation fault or other severe error.
01936 ** Memory corruption, a segmentation fault, or other severe error
01937 ** might result if sqlite3_free() is called with a non-NULL pointer that
01938 ** was not obtained from sqlite3_malloc() or sqlite3_realloc().
01939 **
01940 ** ^(The sqlite3_realloc() interface attempts to resize a
01941 ** prior memory allocation to be at least N bytes, where N is the
01942 ** second parameter.  The memory allocation to be resized is the first
01943 ** parameter.)^ ^ If the first parameter to sqlite3_realloc()
01944 ** is a NULL pointer then its behavior is identical to calling
01945 ** sqlite3_malloc(N) where N is the second parameter to sqlite3_realloc().
01946 ** ^If the second parameter to sqlite3_realloc() is zero or
01947 ** negative then the behavior is exactly the same as calling
01948 ** sqlite3_free(P) where P is the first parameter to sqlite3_realloc().
01949 ** ^sqlite3_realloc() returns a pointer to a memory allocation
01950 ** of at least N bytes in size or NULL if sufficient memory is unavailable.
01951 ** ^If M is the size of the prior allocation, then min(N,M) bytes
01952 ** of the prior allocation are copied into the beginning of buffer returned
01953 ** by sqlite3_realloc() and the prior allocation is freed.
01954 ** ^If sqlite3_realloc() returns NULL, then the prior allocation
01955 ** is not freed.
01956 **
01957 ** ^The memory returned by sqlite3_malloc() and sqlite3_realloc()
01958 ** is always aligned to at least an 8 byte boundary, or to a
01959 ** 4 byte boundary if the [SQLITE_4_BYTE_ALIGNED_MALLOC] compile-time
01960 ** option is used.
01961 **
01962 ** In SQLite version 3.5.0 and 3.5.1, it was possible to define
01963 ** the SQLITE_OMIT_MEMORY_ALLOCATION which would cause the built-in
01964 ** implementation of these routines to be omitted.  That capability
01965 ** is no longer provided.  Only built-in memory allocators can be used.
01966 **
01967 ** The Windows OS interface layer calls
01968 ** the system malloc() and free() directly when converting
01969 ** filenames between the UTF-8 encoding used by SQLite
01970 ** and whatever filename encoding is used by the particular Windows
01971 ** installation.  Memory allocation errors are detected, but
01972 ** they are reported back as [SQLITE_CANTOPEN] or
01973 ** [SQLITE_IOERR] rather than [SQLITE_NOMEM].
01974 **
01975 ** The pointer arguments to [sqlite3_free()] and [sqlite3_realloc()]
01976 ** must be either NULL or else pointers obtained from a prior
01977 ** invocation of [sqlite3_malloc()] or [sqlite3_realloc()] that have
01978 ** not yet been released.
01979 **
01980 ** The application must not read or write any part of
01981 ** a block of memory after it has been released using
01982 ** [sqlite3_free()] or [sqlite3_realloc()].
01983 */
01984 SQLITE_API void *sqlite3_malloc(int);
01985 SQLITE_API void *sqlite3_realloc(void*, int);
01986 SQLITE_API void sqlite3_free(void*);
01987 
01988 /*
01989 ** CAPI3REF: Memory Allocator Statistics
01990 **
01991 ** SQLite provides these two interfaces for reporting on the status
01992 ** of the [sqlite3_malloc()], [sqlite3_free()], and [sqlite3_realloc()]
01993 ** routines, which form the built-in memory allocation subsystem.
01994 **
01995 ** ^The [sqlite3_memory_used()] routine returns the number of bytes
01996 ** of memory currently outstanding (malloced but not freed).
01997 ** ^The [sqlite3_memory_highwater()] routine returns the maximum
01998 ** value of [sqlite3_memory_used()] since the high-water mark
01999 ** was last reset.  ^The values returned by [sqlite3_memory_used()] and
02000 ** [sqlite3_memory_highwater()] include any overhead
02001 ** added by SQLite in its implementation of [sqlite3_malloc()],
02002 ** but not overhead added by the any underlying system library
02003 ** routines that [sqlite3_malloc()] may call.
02004 **
02005 ** ^The memory high-water mark is reset to the current value of
02006 ** [sqlite3_memory_used()] if and only if the parameter to
02007 ** [sqlite3_memory_highwater()] is true.  ^The value returned
02008 ** by [sqlite3_memory_highwater(1)] is the high-water mark
02009 ** prior to the reset.
02010 */
02011 SQLITE_API sqlite3_int64 sqlite3_memory_used(void);
02012 SQLITE_API sqlite3_int64 sqlite3_memory_highwater(int resetFlag);
02013 
02014 /*
02015 ** CAPI3REF: Pseudo-Random Number Generator
02016 **
02017 ** SQLite contains a high-quality pseudo-random number generator (PRNG) used to
02018 ** select random [ROWID | ROWIDs] when inserting new records into a table that
02019 ** already uses the largest possible [ROWID].  The PRNG is also used for
02020 ** the build-in random() and randomblob() SQL functions.  This interface allows
02021 ** applications to access the same PRNG for other purposes.
02022 **
02023 ** ^A call to this routine stores N bytes of randomness into buffer P.
02024 **
02025 ** ^The first time this routine is invoked (either internally or by
02026 ** the application) the PRNG is seeded using randomness obtained
02027 ** from the xRandomness method of the default [sqlite3_vfs] object.
02028 ** ^On all subsequent invocations, the pseudo-randomness is generated
02029 ** internally and without recourse to the [sqlite3_vfs] xRandomness
02030 ** method.
02031 */
02032 SQLITE_API void sqlite3_randomness(int N, void *P);
02033 
02034 /*
02035 ** CAPI3REF: Compile-Time Authorization Callbacks
02036 **
02037 ** ^This routine registers a authorizer callback with a particular
02038 ** [database connection], supplied in the first argument.
02039 ** ^The authorizer callback is invoked as SQL statements are being compiled
02040 ** by [sqlite3_prepare()] or its variants [sqlite3_prepare_v2()],
02041 ** [sqlite3_prepare16()] and [sqlite3_prepare16_v2()].  ^At various
02042 ** points during the compilation process, as logic is being created
02043 ** to perform various actions, the authorizer callback is invoked to
02044 ** see if those actions are allowed.  ^The authorizer callback should
02045 ** return [SQLITE_OK] to allow the action, [SQLITE_IGNORE] to disallow the
02046 ** specific action but allow the SQL statement to continue to be
02047 ** compiled, or [SQLITE_DENY] to cause the entire SQL statement to be
02048 ** rejected with an error.  ^If the authorizer callback returns
02049 ** any value other than [SQLITE_IGNORE], [SQLITE_OK], or [SQLITE_DENY]
02050 ** then the [sqlite3_prepare_v2()] or equivalent call that triggered
02051 ** the authorizer will fail with an error message.
02052 **
02053 ** When the callback returns [SQLITE_OK], that means the operation
02054 ** requested is ok.  ^When the callback returns [SQLITE_DENY], the
02055 ** [sqlite3_prepare_v2()] or equivalent call that triggered the
02056 ** authorizer will fail with an error message explaining that
02057 ** access is denied. 
02058 **
02059 ** ^The first parameter to the authorizer callback is a copy of the third
02060 ** parameter to the sqlite3_set_authorizer() interface. ^The second parameter
02061 ** to the callback is an integer [SQLITE_COPY | action code] that specifies
02062 ** the particular action to be authorized. ^The third through sixth parameters
02063 ** to the callback are zero-terminated strings that contain additional
02064 ** details about the action to be authorized.
02065 **
02066 ** ^If the action code is [SQLITE_READ]
02067 ** and the callback returns [SQLITE_IGNORE] then the
02068 ** [prepared statement] statement is constructed to substitute
02069 ** a NULL value in place of the table column that would have
02070 ** been read if [SQLITE_OK] had been returned.  The [SQLITE_IGNORE]
02071 ** return can be used to deny an untrusted user access to individual
02072 ** columns of a table.
02073 ** ^If the action code is [SQLITE_DELETE] and the callback returns
02074 ** [SQLITE_IGNORE] then the [DELETE] operation proceeds but the
02075 ** [truncate optimization] is disabled and all rows are deleted individually.
02076 **
02077 ** An authorizer is used when [sqlite3_prepare | preparing]
02078 ** SQL statements from an untrusted source, to ensure that the SQL statements
02079 ** do not try to access data they are not allowed to see, or that they do not
02080 ** try to execute malicious statements that damage the database.  For
02081 ** example, an application may allow a user to enter arbitrary
02082 ** SQL queries for evaluation by a database.  But the application does
02083 ** not want the user to be able to make arbitrary changes to the
02084 ** database.  An authorizer could then be put in place while the
02085 ** user-entered SQL is being [sqlite3_prepare | prepared] that
02086 ** disallows everything except [SELECT] statements.
02087 **
02088 ** Applications that need to process SQL from untrusted sources
02089 ** might also consider lowering resource limits using [sqlite3_limit()]
02090 ** and limiting database size using the [max_page_count] [PRAGMA]
02091 ** in addition to using an authorizer.
02092 **
02093 ** ^(Only a single authorizer can be in place on a database connection
02094 ** at a time.  Each call to sqlite3_set_authorizer overrides the
02095 ** previous call.)^  ^Disable the authorizer by installing a NULL callback.
02096 ** The authorizer is disabled by default.
02097 **
02098 ** The authorizer callback must not do anything that will modify
02099 ** the database connection that invoked the authorizer callback.
02100 ** Note that [sqlite3_prepare_v2()] and [sqlite3_step()] both modify their
02101 ** database connections for the meaning of "modify" in this paragraph.
02102 **
02103 ** ^When [sqlite3_prepare_v2()] is used to prepare a statement, the
02104 ** statement might be re-prepared during [sqlite3_step()] due to a 
02105 ** schema change.  Hence, the application should ensure that the
02106 ** correct authorizer callback remains in place during the [sqlite3_step()].
02107 **
02108 ** ^Note that the authorizer callback is invoked only during
02109 ** [sqlite3_prepare()] or its variants.  Authorization is not
02110 ** performed during statement evaluation in [sqlite3_step()], unless
02111 ** as stated in the previous paragraph, sqlite3_step() invokes
02112 ** sqlite3_prepare_v2() to reprepare a statement after a schema change.
02113 */
02114 SQLITE_API int sqlite3_set_authorizer(
02115   sqlite3*,
02116   int (*xAuth)(void*,int,const char*,const char*,const char*,const char*),
02117   void *pUserData
02118 );
02119 
02120 /*
02121 ** CAPI3REF: Authorizer Return Codes
02122 **
02123 ** The [sqlite3_set_authorizer | authorizer callback function] must
02124 ** return either [SQLITE_OK] or one of these two constants in order
02125 ** to signal SQLite whether or not the action is permitted.  See the
02126 ** [sqlite3_set_authorizer | authorizer documentation] for additional
02127 ** information.
02128 */
02129 #define SQLITE_DENY   1   /* Abort the SQL statement with an error */
02130 #define SQLITE_IGNORE 2   /* Don't allow access, but don't generate an error */
02131 
02132 /*
02133 ** CAPI3REF: Authorizer Action Codes
02134 **
02135 ** The [sqlite3_set_authorizer()] interface registers a callback function
02136 ** that is invoked to authorize certain SQL statement actions.  The
02137 ** second parameter to the callback is an integer code that specifies
02138 ** what action is being authorized.  These are the integer action codes that
02139 ** the authorizer callback may be passed.
02140 **
02141 ** These action code values signify what kind of operation is to be
02142 ** authorized.  The 3rd and 4th parameters to the authorization
02143 ** callback function will be parameters or NULL depending on which of these
02144 ** codes is used as the second parameter.  ^(The 5th parameter to the
02145 ** authorizer callback is the name of the database ("main", "temp",
02146 ** etc.) if applicable.)^  ^The 6th parameter to the authorizer callback
02147 ** is the name of the inner-most trigger or view that is responsible for
02148 ** the access attempt or NULL if this access attempt is directly from
02149 ** top-level SQL code.
02150 */
02151 /******************************************* 3rd ************ 4th ***********/
02152 #define SQLITE_CREATE_INDEX          1   /* Index Name      Table Name      */
02153 #define SQLITE_CREATE_TABLE          2   /* Table Name      NULL            */
02154 #define SQLITE_CREATE_TEMP_INDEX     3   /* Index Name      Table Name      */
02155 #define SQLITE_CREATE_TEMP_TABLE     4   /* Table Name      NULL            */
02156 #define SQLITE_CREATE_TEMP_TRIGGER   5   /* Trigger Name    Table Name      */
02157 #define SQLITE_CREATE_TEMP_VIEW      6   /* View Name       NULL            */
02158 #define SQLITE_CREATE_TRIGGER        7   /* Trigger Name    Table Name      */
02159 #define SQLITE_CREATE_VIEW           8   /* View Name       NULL            */
02160 #define SQLITE_DELETE                9   /* Table Name      NULL            */
02161 #define SQLITE_DROP_INDEX           10   /* Index Name      Table Name      */
02162 #define SQLITE_DROP_TABLE           11   /* Table Name      NULL            */
02163 #define SQLITE_DROP_TEMP_INDEX      12   /* Index Name      Table Name      */
02164 #define SQLITE_DROP_TEMP_TABLE      13   /* Table Name      NULL            */
02165 #define SQLITE_DROP_TEMP_TRIGGER    14   /* Trigger Name    Table Name      */
02166 #define SQLITE_DROP_TEMP_VIEW       15   /* View Name       NULL            */
02167 #define SQLITE_DROP_TRIGGER         16   /* Trigger Name    Table Name      */
02168 #define SQLITE_DROP_VIEW            17   /* View Name       NULL            */
02169 #define SQLITE_INSERT               18   /* Table Name      NULL            */
02170 #define SQLITE_PRAGMA               19   /* Pragma Name     1st arg or NULL */
02171 #define SQLITE_READ                 20   /* Table Name      Column Name     */
02172 #define SQLITE_SELECT               21   /* NULL            NULL            */
02173 #define SQLITE_TRANSACTION          22   /* Operation       NULL            */
02174 #define SQLITE_UPDATE               23   /* Table Name      Column Name     */
02175 #define SQLITE_ATTACH               24   /* Filename        NULL            */
02176 #define SQLITE_DETACH               25   /* Database Name   NULL            */
02177 #define SQLITE_ALTER_TABLE          26   /* Database Name   Table Name      */
02178 #define SQLITE_REINDEX              27   /* Index Name      NULL            */
02179 #define SQLITE_ANALYZE              28   /* Table Name      NULL            */
02180 #define SQLITE_CREATE_VTABLE        29   /* Table Name      Module Name     */
02181 #define SQLITE_DROP_VTABLE          30   /* Table Name      Module Name     */
02182 #define SQLITE_FUNCTION             31   /* NULL            Function Name   */
02183 #define SQLITE_SAVEPOINT            32   /* Operation       Savepoint Name  */
02184 #define SQLITE_COPY                  0   /* No longer used */
02185 
02186 /*
02187 ** CAPI3REF: Tracing And Profiling Functions
02188 **
02189 ** These routines register callback functions that can be used for
02190 ** tracing and profiling the execution of SQL statements.
02191 **
02192 ** ^The callback function registered by sqlite3_trace() is invoked at
02193 ** various times when an SQL statement is being run by [sqlite3_step()].
02194 ** ^The sqlite3_trace() callback is invoked with a UTF-8 rendering of the
02195 ** SQL statement text as the statement first begins executing.
02196 ** ^(Additional sqlite3_trace() callbacks might occur
02197 ** as each triggered subprogram is entered.  The callbacks for triggers
02198 ** contain a UTF-8 SQL comment that identifies the trigger.)^
02199 **
02200 ** ^The callback function registered by sqlite3_profile() is invoked
02201 ** as each SQL statement finishes.  ^The profile callback contains
02202 ** the original statement text and an estimate of wall-clock time
02203 ** of how long that statement took to run.  ^The profile callback
02204 ** time is in units of nanoseconds, however the current implementation
02205 ** is only capable of millisecond resolution so the six least significant
02206 ** digits in the time are meaningless.  Future versions of SQLite
02207 ** might provide greater resolution on the profiler callback.  The
02208 ** sqlite3_profile() function is considered experimental and is
02209 ** subject to change in future versions of SQLite.
02210 */
02211 SQLITE_API void *sqlite3_trace(sqlite3*, void(*xTrace)(void*,const char*), void*);
02212 SQLITE_API SQLITE_EXPERIMENTAL void *sqlite3_profile(sqlite3*,
02213    void(*xProfile)(void*,const char*,sqlite3_uint64), void*);
02214 
02215 /*
02216 ** CAPI3REF: Query Progress Callbacks
02217 **
02218 ** ^The sqlite3_progress_handler(D,N,X,P) interface causes the callback
02219 ** function X to be invoked periodically during long running calls to
02220 ** [sqlite3_exec()], [sqlite3_step()] and [sqlite3_get_table()] for
02221 ** database connection D.  An example use for this
02222 ** interface is to keep a GUI updated during a large query.
02223 **
02224 ** ^The parameter P is passed through as the only parameter to the 
02225 ** callback function X.  ^The parameter N is the number of 
02226 ** [virtual machine instructions] that are evaluated between successive
02227 ** invocations of the callback X.
02228 **
02229 ** ^Only a single progress handler may be defined at one time per
02230 ** [database connection]; setting a new progress handler cancels the
02231 ** old one.  ^Setting parameter X to NULL disables the progress handler.
02232 ** ^The progress handler is also disabled by setting N to a value less
02233 ** than 1.
02234 **
02235 ** ^If the progress callback returns non-zero, the operation is
02236 ** interrupted.  This feature can be used to implement a
02237 ** "Cancel" button on a GUI progress dialog box.
02238 **
02239 ** The progress handler callback must not do anything that will modify
02240 ** the database connection that invoked the progress handler.
02241 ** Note that [sqlite3_prepare_v2()] and [sqlite3_step()] both modify their
02242 ** database connections for the meaning of "modify" in this paragraph.
02243 **
02244 */
02245 SQLITE_API void sqlite3_progress_handler(sqlite3*, int, int(*)(void*), void*);
02246 
02247 /*
02248 ** CAPI3REF: Opening A New Database Connection
02249 **
02250 ** ^These routines open an SQLite database file whose name is given by the
02251 ** filename argument. ^The filename argument is interpreted as UTF-8 for
02252 ** sqlite3_open() and sqlite3_open_v2() and as UTF-16 in the native byte
02253 ** order for sqlite3_open16(). ^(A [database connection] handle is usually
02254 ** returned in *ppDb, even if an error occurs.  The only exception is that
02255 ** if SQLite is unable to allocate memory to hold the [sqlite3] object,
02256 ** a NULL will be written into *ppDb instead of a pointer to the [sqlite3]
02257 ** object.)^ ^(If the database is opened (and/or created) successfully, then
02258 ** [SQLITE_OK] is returned.  Otherwise an [error code] is returned.)^ ^The
02259 ** [sqlite3_errmsg()] or [sqlite3_errmsg16()] routines can be used to obtain
02260 ** an English language description of the error following a failure of any
02261 ** of the sqlite3_open() routines.
02262 **
02263 ** ^The default encoding for the database will be UTF-8 if
02264 ** sqlite3_open() or sqlite3_open_v2() is called and
02265 ** UTF-16 in the native byte order if sqlite3_open16() is used.
02266 **
02267 ** Whether or not an error occurs when it is opened, resources
02268 ** associated with the [database connection] handle should be released by
02269 ** passing it to [sqlite3_close()] when it is no longer required.
02270 **
02271 ** The sqlite3_open_v2() interface works like sqlite3_open()
02272 ** except that it accepts two additional parameters for additional control
02273 ** over the new database connection.  ^(The flags parameter to
02274 ** sqlite3_open_v2() can take one of
02275 ** the following three values, optionally combined with the 
02276 ** [SQLITE_OPEN_NOMUTEX], [SQLITE_OPEN_FULLMUTEX], [SQLITE_OPEN_SHAREDCACHE],
02277 ** and/or [SQLITE_OPEN_PRIVATECACHE] flags:)^
02278 **
02279 ** <dl>
02280 ** ^(<dt>[SQLITE_OPEN_READONLY]</dt>
02281 ** <dd>The database is opened in read-only mode.  If the database does not
02282 ** already exist, an error is returned.</dd>)^
02283 **
02284 ** ^(<dt>[SQLITE_OPEN_READWRITE]</dt>
02285 ** <dd>The database is opened for reading and writing if possible, or reading
02286 ** only if the file is write protected by the operating system.  In either
02287 ** case the database must already exist, otherwise an error is returned.</dd>)^
02288 **
02289 ** ^(<dt>[SQLITE_OPEN_READWRITE] | [SQLITE_OPEN_CREATE]</dt>
02290 ** <dd>The database is opened for reading and writing, and is creates it if
02291 ** it does not already exist. This is the behavior that is always used for
02292 ** sqlite3_open() and sqlite3_open16().</dd>)^
02293 ** </dl>
02294 **
02295 ** If the 3rd parameter to sqlite3_open_v2() is not one of the
02296 ** combinations shown above or one of the combinations shown above combined
02297 ** with the [SQLITE_OPEN_NOMUTEX], [SQLITE_OPEN_FULLMUTEX],
02298 ** [SQLITE_OPEN_SHAREDCACHE] and/or [SQLITE_OPEN_PRIVATECACHE] flags,
02299 ** then the behavior is undefined.
02300 **
02301 ** ^If the [SQLITE_OPEN_NOMUTEX] flag is set, then the database connection
02302 ** opens in the multi-thread [threading mode] as long as the single-thread
02303 ** mode has not been set at compile-time or start-time.  ^If the
02304 ** [SQLITE_OPEN_FULLMUTEX] flag is set then the database connection opens
02305 ** in the serialized [threading mode] unless single-thread was
02306 ** previously selected at compile-time or start-time.
02307 ** ^The [SQLITE_OPEN_SHAREDCACHE] flag causes the database connection to be
02308 ** eligible to use [shared cache mode], regardless of whether or not shared
02309 ** cache is enabled using [sqlite3_enable_shared_cache()].  ^The
02310 ** [SQLITE_OPEN_PRIVATECACHE] flag causes the database connection to not
02311 ** participate in [shared cache mode] even if it is enabled.
02312 **
02313 ** ^If the filename is ":memory:", then a private, temporary in-memory database
02314 ** is created for the connection.  ^This in-memory database will vanish when
02315 ** the database connection is closed.  Future versions of SQLite might
02316 ** make use of additional special filenames that begin with the ":" character.
02317 ** It is recommended that when a database filename actually does begin with
02318 ** a ":" character you should prefix the filename with a pathname such as
02319 ** "./" to avoid ambiguity.
02320 **
02321 ** ^If the filename is an empty string, then a private, temporary
02322 ** on-disk database will be created.  ^This private database will be
02323 ** automatically deleted as soon as the database connection is closed.
02324 **
02325 ** ^The fourth parameter to sqlite3_open_v2() is the name of the
02326 ** [sqlite3_vfs] object that defines the operating system interface that
02327 ** the new database connection should use.  ^If the fourth parameter is
02328 ** a NULL pointer then the default [sqlite3_vfs] object is used.
02329 **
02330 ** <b>Note to Windows users:</b>  The encoding used for the filename argument
02331 ** of sqlite3_open() and sqlite3_open_v2() must be UTF-8, not whatever
02332 ** codepage is currently defined.  Filenames containing international
02333 ** characters must be converted to UTF-8 prior to passing them into
02334 ** sqlite3_open() or sqlite3_open_v2().
02335 */
02336 SQLITE_API int sqlite3_open(
02337   const char *filename,   /* Database filename (UTF-8) */
02338   sqlite3 **ppDb          /* OUT: SQLite db handle */
02339 );
02340 SQLITE_API int sqlite3_open16(
02341   const void *filename,   /* Database filename (UTF-16) */
02342   sqlite3 **ppDb          /* OUT: SQLite db handle */
02343 );
02344 SQLITE_API int sqlite3_open_v2(
02345   const char *filename,   /* Database filename (UTF-8) */
02346   sqlite3 **ppDb,         /* OUT: SQLite db handle */
02347   int flags,              /* Flags */
02348   const char *zVfs        /* Name of VFS module to use */
02349 );
02350 
02351 /*
02352 ** CAPI3REF: Error Codes And Messages
02353 **
02354 ** ^The sqlite3_errcode() interface returns the numeric [result code] or
02355 ** [extended result code] for the most recent failed sqlite3_* API call
02356 ** associated with a [database connection]. If a prior API call failed
02357 ** but the most recent API call succeeded, the return value from
02358 ** sqlite3_errcode() is undefined.  ^The sqlite3_extended_errcode()
02359 ** interface is the same except that it always returns the 
02360 ** [extended result code] even when extended result codes are
02361 ** disabled.
02362 **
02363 ** ^The sqlite3_errmsg() and sqlite3_errmsg16() return English-language
02364 ** text that describes the error, as either UTF-8 or UTF-16 respectively.
02365 ** ^(Memory to hold the error message string is managed internally.
02366 ** The application does not need to worry about freeing the result.
02367 ** However, the error string might be overwritten or deallocated by
02368 ** subsequent calls to other SQLite interface functions.)^
02369 **
02370 ** When the serialized [threading mode] is in use, it might be the
02371 ** case that a second error occurs on a separate thread in between
02372 ** the time of the first error and the call to these interfaces.
02373 ** When that happens, the second error will be reported since these
02374 ** interfaces always report the most recent result.  To avoid
02375 ** this, each thread can obtain exclusive use of the [database connection] D
02376 ** by invoking [sqlite3_mutex_enter]([sqlite3_db_mutex](D)) before beginning
02377 ** to use D and invoking [sqlite3_mutex_leave]([sqlite3_db_mutex](D)) after
02378 ** all calls to the interfaces listed here are completed.
02379 **
02380 ** If an interface fails with SQLITE_MISUSE, that means the interface
02381 ** was invoked incorrectly by the application.  In that case, the
02382 ** error code and message may or may not be set.
02383 */
02384 SQLITE_API int sqlite3_errcode(sqlite3 *db);
02385 SQLITE_API int sqlite3_extended_errcode(sqlite3 *db);
02386 SQLITE_API const char *sqlite3_errmsg(sqlite3*);
02387 SQLITE_API const void *sqlite3_errmsg16(sqlite3*);
02388 
02389 /*
02390 ** CAPI3REF: SQL Statement Object
02391 ** KEYWORDS: {prepared statement} {prepared statements}
02392 **
02393 ** An instance of this object represents a single SQL statement.
02394 ** This object is variously known as a "prepared statement" or a
02395 ** "compiled SQL statement" or simply as a "statement".
02396 **
02397 ** The life of a statement object goes something like this:
02398 **
02399 ** <ol>
02400 ** <li> Create the object using [sqlite3_prepare_v2()] or a related
02401 **      function.
02402 ** <li> Bind values to [host parameters] using the sqlite3_bind_*()
02403 **      interfaces.
02404 ** <li> Run the SQL by calling [sqlite3_step()] one or more times.
02405 ** <li> Reset the statement using [sqlite3_reset()] then go back
02406 **      to step 2.  Do this zero or more times.
02407 ** <li> Destroy the object using [sqlite3_finalize()].
02408 ** </ol>
02409 **
02410 ** Refer to documentation on individual methods above for additional
02411 ** information.
02412 */
02413 typedef struct sqlite3_stmt sqlite3_stmt;
02414 
02415 /*
02416 ** CAPI3REF: Run-time Limits
02417 **
02418 ** ^(This interface allows the size of various constructs to be limited
02419 ** on a connection by connection basis.  The first parameter is the
02420 ** [database connection] whose limit is to be set or queried.  The
02421 ** second parameter is one of the [limit categories] that define a
02422 ** class of constructs to be size limited.  The third parameter is the
02423 ** new limit for that construct.)^
02424 **
02425 ** ^If the new limit is a negative number, the limit is unchanged.
02426 ** ^(For each limit category SQLITE_LIMIT_<i>NAME</i> there is a 
02427 ** [limits | hard upper bound]
02428 ** set at compile-time by a C preprocessor macro called
02429 ** [limits | SQLITE_MAX_<i>NAME</i>].
02430 ** (The "_LIMIT_" in the name is changed to "_MAX_".))^
02431 ** ^Attempts to increase a limit above its hard upper bound are
02432 ** silently truncated to the hard upper bound.
02433 **
02434 ** ^Regardless of whether or not the limit was changed, the 
02435 ** [sqlite3_limit()] interface returns the prior value of the limit.
02436 ** ^Hence, to find the current value of a limit without changing it,
02437 ** simply invoke this interface with the third parameter set to -1.
02438 **
02439 ** Run-time limits are intended for use in applications that manage
02440 ** both their own internal database and also databases that are controlled
02441 ** by untrusted external sources.  An example application might be a
02442 ** web browser that has its own databases for storing history and
02443 ** separate databases controlled by JavaScript applications downloaded
02444 ** off the Internet.  The internal databases can be given the
02445 ** large, default limits.  Databases managed by external sources can
02446 ** be given much smaller limits designed to prevent a denial of service
02447 ** attack.  Developers might also want to use the [sqlite3_set_authorizer()]
02448 ** interface to further control untrusted SQL.  The size of the database
02449 ** created by an untrusted script can be contained using the
02450 ** [max_page_count] [PRAGMA].
02451 **
02452 ** New run-time limit categories may be added in future releases.
02453 */
02454 SQLITE_API int sqlite3_limit(sqlite3*, int id, int newVal);
02455 
02456 /*
02457 ** CAPI3REF: Run-Time Limit Categories
02458 ** KEYWORDS: {limit category} {*limit categories}
02459 **
02460 ** These constants define various performance limits
02461 ** that can be lowered at run-time using [sqlite3_limit()].
02462 ** The synopsis of the meanings of the various limits is shown below.
02463 ** Additional information is available at [limits | Limits in SQLite].
02464 **
02465 ** <dl>
02466 ** ^(<dt>SQLITE_LIMIT_LENGTH</dt>
02467 ** <dd>The maximum size of any string or BLOB or table row, in bytes.<dd>)^
02468 **
02469 ** ^(<dt>SQLITE_LIMIT_SQL_LENGTH</dt>
02470 ** <dd>The maximum length of an SQL statement, in bytes.</dd>)^
02471 **
02472 ** ^(<dt>SQLITE_LIMIT_COLUMN</dt>
02473 ** <dd>The maximum number of columns in a table definition or in the
02474 ** result set of a [SELECT] or the maximum number of columns in an index
02475 ** or in an ORDER BY or GROUP BY clause.</dd>)^
02476 **
02477 ** ^(<dt>SQLITE_LIMIT_EXPR_DEPTH</dt>
02478 ** <dd>The maximum depth of the parse tree on any expression.</dd>)^
02479 **
02480 ** ^(<dt>SQLITE_LIMIT_COMPOUND_SELECT</dt>
02481 ** <dd>The maximum number of terms in a compound SELECT statement.</dd>)^
02482 **
02483 ** ^(<dt>SQLITE_LIMIT_VDBE_OP</dt>
02484 ** <dd>The maximum number of instructions in a virtual machine program
02485 ** used to implement an SQL statement.  This limit is not currently
02486 ** enforced, though that might be added in some future release of
02487 ** SQLite.</dd>)^
02488 **
02489 ** ^(<dt>SQLITE_LIMIT_FUNCTION_ARG</dt>
02490 ** <dd>The maximum number of arguments on a function.</dd>)^
02491 **
02492 ** ^(<dt>SQLITE_LIMIT_ATTACHED</dt>
02493 ** <dd>The maximum number of [ATTACH | attached databases].)^</dd>
02494 **
02495 ** ^(<dt>SQLITE_LIMIT_LIKE_PATTERN_LENGTH</dt>
02496 ** <dd>The maximum length of the pattern argument to the [LIKE] or
02497 ** [GLOB] operators.</dd>)^
02498 **
02499 ** ^(<dt>SQLITE_LIMIT_VARIABLE_NUMBER</dt>
02500 ** <dd>The maximum index number of any [parameter] in an SQL statement.)^
02501 **
02502 ** ^(<dt>SQLITE_LIMIT_TRIGGER_DEPTH</dt>
02503 ** <dd>The maximum depth of recursion for triggers.</dd>)^
02504 ** </dl>
02505 */
02506 #define SQLITE_LIMIT_LENGTH                    0
02507 #define SQLITE_LIMIT_SQL_LENGTH                1
02508 #define SQLITE_LIMIT_COLUMN                    2
02509 #define SQLITE_LIMIT_EXPR_DEPTH                3
02510 #define SQLITE_LIMIT_COMPOUND_SELECT           4
02511 #define SQLITE_LIMIT_VDBE_OP                   5
02512 #define SQLITE_LIMIT_FUNCTION_ARG              6
02513 #define SQLITE_LIMIT_ATTACHED                  7
02514 #define SQLITE_LIMIT_LIKE_PATTERN_LENGTH       8
02515 #define SQLITE_LIMIT_VARIABLE_NUMBER           9
02516 #define SQLITE_LIMIT_TRIGGER_DEPTH            10
02517 
02518 /*
02519 ** CAPI3REF: Compiling An SQL Statement
02520 ** KEYWORDS: {SQL statement compiler}
02521 **
02522 ** To execute an SQL query, it must first be compiled into a byte-code
02523 ** program using one of these routines.
02524 **
02525 ** The first argument, "db", is a [database connection] obtained from a
02526 ** prior successful call to [sqlite3_open()], [sqlite3_open_v2()] or
02527 ** [sqlite3_open16()].  The database connection must not have been closed.
02528 **
02529 ** The second argument, "zSql", is the statement to be compiled, encoded
02530 ** as either UTF-8 or UTF-16.  The sqlite3_prepare() and sqlite3_prepare_v2()
02531 ** interfaces use UTF-8, and sqlite3_prepare16() and sqlite3_prepare16_v2()
02532 ** use UTF-16.
02533 **
02534 ** ^If the nByte argument is less than zero, then zSql is read up to the
02535 ** first zero terminator. ^If nByte is non-negative, then it is the maximum
02536 ** number of  bytes read from zSql.  ^When nByte is non-negative, the
02537 ** zSql string ends at either the first '\000' or '\u0000' character or
02538 ** the nByte-th byte, whichever comes first. If the caller knows
02539 ** that the supplied string is nul-terminated, then there is a small
02540 ** performance advantage to be gained by passing an nByte parameter that
02541 ** is equal to the number of bytes in the input string <i>including</i>
02542 ** the nul-terminator bytes.
02543 **
02544 ** ^If pzTail is not NULL then *pzTail is made to point to the first byte
02545 ** past the end of the first SQL statement in zSql.  These routines only
02546 ** compile the first statement in zSql, so *pzTail is left pointing to
02547 ** what remains uncompiled.
02548 **
02549 ** ^*ppStmt is left pointing to a compiled [prepared statement] that can be
02550 ** executed using [sqlite3_step()].  ^If there is an error, *ppStmt is set
02551 ** to NULL.  ^If the input text contains no SQL (if the input is an empty
02552 ** string or a comment) then *ppStmt is set to NULL.
02553 ** The calling procedure is responsible for deleting the compiled
02554 ** SQL statement using [sqlite3_finalize()] after it has finished with it.
02555 ** ppStmt may not be NULL.
02556 **
02557 ** ^On success, the sqlite3_prepare() family of routines return [SQLITE_OK];
02558 ** otherwise an [error code] is returned.
02559 **
02560 ** The sqlite3_prepare_v2() and sqlite3_prepare16_v2() interfaces are
02561 ** recommended for all new programs. The two older interfaces are retained
02562 ** for backwards compatibility, but their use is discouraged.
02563 ** ^In the "v2" interfaces, the prepared statement
02564 ** that is returned (the [sqlite3_stmt] object) contains a copy of the
02565 ** original SQL text. This causes the [sqlite3_step()] interface to
02566 ** behave differently in three ways:
02567 **
02568 ** <ol>
02569 ** <li>
02570 ** ^If the database schema changes, instead of returning [SQLITE_SCHEMA] as it
02571 ** always used to do, [sqlite3_step()] will automatically recompile the SQL
02572 ** statement and try to run it again.
02573 ** </li>
02574 **
02575 ** <li>
02576 ** ^When an error occurs, [sqlite3_step()] will return one of the detailed
02577 ** [error codes] or [extended error codes].  ^The legacy behavior was that
02578 ** [sqlite3_step()] would only return a generic [SQLITE_ERROR] result code
02579 ** and the application would have to make a second call to [sqlite3_reset()]
02580 ** in order to find the underlying cause of the problem. With the "v2" prepare
02581 ** interfaces, the underlying reason for the error is returned immediately.
02582 ** </li>
02583 **
02584 ** <li>
02585 ** ^If the specific value bound to [parameter | host parameter] in the 
02586 ** WHERE clause might influence the choice of query plan for a statement,
02587 ** then the statement will be automatically recompiled, as if there had been 
02588 ** a schema change, on the first  [sqlite3_step()] call following any change
02589 ** to the [sqlite3_bind_text | bindings] of that [parameter]. 
02590 ** ^The specific value of WHERE-clause [parameter] might influence the 
02591 ** choice of query plan if the parameter is the left-hand side of a [LIKE]
02592 ** or [GLOB] operator or if the parameter is compared to an indexed column
02593 ** and the [SQLITE_ENABLE_STAT2] compile-time option is enabled.
02594 ** the 
02595 ** </li>
02596 ** </ol>
02597 */
02598 SQLITE_API int sqlite3_prepare(
02599   sqlite3 *db,            /* Database handle */
02600   const char *zSql,       /* SQL statement, UTF-8 encoded */
02601   int nByte,              /* Maximum length of zSql in bytes. */
02602   sqlite3_stmt **ppStmt,  /* OUT: Statement handle */
02603   const char **pzTail     /* OUT: Pointer to unused portion of zSql */
02604 );
02605 SQLITE_API int sqlite3_prepare_v2(
02606   sqlite3 *db,            /* Database handle */
02607   const char *zSql,       /* SQL statement, UTF-8 encoded */
02608   int nByte,              /* Maximum length of zSql in bytes. */
02609   sqlite3_stmt **ppStmt,  /* OUT: Statement handle */
02610   const char **pzTail     /* OUT: Pointer to unused portion of zSql */
02611 );
02612 SQLITE_API int sqlite3_prepare16(
02613   sqlite3 *db,            /* Database handle */
02614   const void *zSql,       /* SQL statement, UTF-16 encoded */
02615   int nByte,              /* Maximum length of zSql in bytes. */
02616   sqlite3_stmt **ppStmt,  /* OUT: Statement handle */
02617   const void **pzTail     /* OUT: Pointer to unused portion of zSql */
02618 );
02619 SQLITE_API int sqlite3_prepare16_v2(
02620   sqlite3 *db,            /* Database handle */
02621   const void *zSql,       /* SQL statement, UTF-16 encoded */
02622   int nByte,              /* Maximum length of zSql in bytes. */
02623   sqlite3_stmt **ppStmt,  /* OUT: Statement handle */
02624   const void **pzTail     /* OUT: Pointer to unused portion of zSql */
02625 );
02626 
02627 /*
02628 ** CAPI3REF: Retrieving Statement SQL
02629 **
02630 ** ^This interface can be used to retrieve a saved copy of the original
02631 ** SQL text used to create a [prepared statement] if that statement was
02632 ** compiled using either [sqlite3_prepare_v2()] or [sqlite3_prepare16_v2()].
02633 */
02634 SQLITE_API const char *sqlite3_sql(sqlite3_stmt *pStmt);
02635 
02636 /*
02637 ** CAPI3REF: Dynamically Typed Value Object
02638 ** KEYWORDS: {protected sqlite3_value} {unprotected sqlite3_value}
02639 **
02640 ** SQLite uses the sqlite3_value object to represent all values
02641 ** that can be stored in a database table. SQLite uses dynamic typing
02642 ** for the values it stores.  ^Values stored in sqlite3_value objects
02643 ** can be integers, floating point values, strings, BLOBs, or NULL.
02644 **
02645 ** An sqlite3_value object may be either "protected" or "unprotected".
02646 ** Some interfaces require a protected sqlite3_value.  Other interfaces
02647 ** will accept either a protected or an unprotected sqlite3_value.
02648 ** Every interface that accepts sqlite3_value arguments specifies
02649 ** whether or not it requires a protected sqlite3_value.
02650 **
02651 ** The terms "protected" and "unprotected" refer to whether or not
02652 ** a mutex is held.  A internal mutex is held for a protected
02653 ** sqlite3_value object but no mutex is held for an unprotected
02654 ** sqlite3_value object.  If SQLite is compiled to be single-threaded
02655 ** (with [SQLITE_THREADSAFE=0] and with [sqlite3_threadsafe()] returning 0)
02656 ** or if SQLite is run in one of reduced mutex modes 
02657 ** [SQLITE_CONFIG_SINGLETHREAD] or [SQLITE_CONFIG_MULTITHREAD]
02658 ** then there is no distinction between protected and unprotected
02659 ** sqlite3_value objects and they can be used interchangeably.  However,
02660 ** for maximum code portability it is recommended that applications
02661 ** still make the distinction between protected and unprotected
02662 ** sqlite3_value objects even when not strictly required.
02663 **
02664 ** ^The sqlite3_value objects that are passed as parameters into the
02665 ** implementation of [application-defined SQL functions] are protected.
02666 ** ^The sqlite3_value object returned by
02667 ** [sqlite3_column_value()] is unprotected.
02668 ** Unprotected sqlite3_value objects may only be used with
02669 ** [sqlite3_result_value()] and [sqlite3_bind_value()].
02670 ** The [sqlite3_value_blob | sqlite3_value_type()] family of
02671 ** interfaces require protected sqlite3_value objects.
02672 */
02673 typedef struct Mem sqlite3_value;
02674 
02675 /*
02676 ** CAPI3REF: SQL Function Context Object
02677 **
02678 ** The context in which an SQL function executes is stored in an
02679 ** sqlite3_context object.  ^A pointer to an sqlite3_context object
02680 ** is always first parameter to [application-defined SQL functions].
02681 ** The application-defined SQL function implementation will pass this
02682 ** pointer through into calls to [sqlite3_result_int | sqlite3_result()],
02683 ** [sqlite3_aggregate_context()], [sqlite3_user_data()],
02684 ** [sqlite3_context_db_handle()], [sqlite3_get_auxdata()],
02685 ** and/or [sqlite3_set_auxdata()].
02686 */
02687 typedef struct sqlite3_context sqlite3_context;
02688 
02689 /*
02690 ** CAPI3REF: Binding Values To Prepared Statements
02691 ** KEYWORDS: {host parameter} {host parameters} {host parameter name}
02692 ** KEYWORDS: {SQL parameter} {SQL parameters} {parameter binding}
02693 **
02694 ** ^(In the SQL statement text input to [sqlite3_prepare_v2()] and its variants,
02695 ** literals may be replaced by a [parameter] that matches one of following
02696 ** templates:
02697 **
02698 ** <ul>
02699 ** <li>  ?
02700 ** <li>  ?NNN
02701 ** <li>  :VVV
02702 ** <li>  @VVV
02703 ** <li>  $VVV
02704 ** </ul>
02705 **
02706 ** In the templates above, NNN represents an integer literal,
02707 ** and VVV represents an alphanumeric identifier.)^  ^The values of these
02708 ** parameters (also called "host parameter names" or "SQL parameters")
02709 ** can be set using the sqlite3_bind_*() routines defined here.
02710 **
02711 ** ^The first argument to the sqlite3_bind_*() routines is always
02712 ** a pointer to the [sqlite3_stmt] object returned from
02713 ** [sqlite3_prepare_v2()] or its variants.
02714 **
02715 ** ^The second argument is the index of the SQL parameter to be set.
02716 ** ^The leftmost SQL parameter has an index of 1.  ^When the same named
02717 ** SQL parameter is used more than once, second and subsequent
02718 ** occurrences have the same index as the first occurrence.
02719 ** ^The index for named parameters can be looked up using the
02720 ** [sqlite3_bind_parameter_index()] API if desired.  ^The index
02721 ** for "?NNN" parameters is the value of NNN.
02722 ** ^The NNN value must be between 1 and the [sqlite3_limit()]
02723 ** parameter [SQLITE_LIMIT_VARIABLE_NUMBER] (default value: 999).
02724 **
02725 ** ^The third argument is the value to bind to the parameter.
02726 **
02727 ** ^(In those routines that have a fourth argument, its value is the
02728 ** number of bytes in the parameter.  To be clear: the value is the
02729 ** number of <u>bytes</u> in the value, not the number of characters.)^
02730 ** ^If the fourth parameter is negative, the length of the string is
02731 ** the number of bytes up to the first zero terminator.
02732 **
02733 ** ^The fifth argument to sqlite3_bind_blob(), sqlite3_bind_text(), and
02734 ** sqlite3_bind_text16() is a destructor used to dispose of the BLOB or
02735 ** string after SQLite has finished with it. ^If the fifth argument is
02736 ** the special value [SQLITE_STATIC], then SQLite assumes that the
02737 ** information is in static, unmanaged space and does not need to be freed.
02738 ** ^If the fifth argument has the value [SQLITE_TRANSIENT], then
02739 ** SQLite makes its own private copy of the data immediately, before
02740 ** the sqlite3_bind_*() routine returns.
02741 **
02742 ** ^The sqlite3_bind_zeroblob() routine binds a BLOB of length N that
02743 ** is filled with zeroes.  ^A zeroblob uses a fixed amount of memory
02744 ** (just an integer to hold its size) while it is being processed.
02745 ** Zeroblobs are intended to serve as placeholders for BLOBs whose
02746 ** content is later written using
02747 ** [sqlite3_blob_open | incremental BLOB I/O] routines.
02748 ** ^A negative value for the zeroblob results in a zero-length BLOB.
02749 **
02750 ** ^If any of the sqlite3_bind_*() routines are called with a NULL pointer
02751 ** for the [prepared statement] or with a prepared statement for which
02752 ** [sqlite3_step()] has been called more recently than [sqlite3_reset()],
02753 ** then the call will return [SQLITE_MISUSE].  If any sqlite3_bind_()
02754 ** routine is passed a [prepared statement] that has been finalized, the
02755 ** result is undefined and probably harmful.
02756 **
02757 ** ^Bindings are not cleared by the [sqlite3_reset()] routine.
02758 ** ^Unbound parameters are interpreted as NULL.
02759 **
02760 ** ^The sqlite3_bind_* routines return [SQLITE_OK] on success or an
02761 ** [error code] if anything goes wrong.
02762 ** ^[SQLITE_RANGE] is returned if the parameter
02763 ** index is out of range.  ^[SQLITE_NOMEM] is returned if malloc() fails.
02764 **
02765 ** See also: [sqlite3_bind_parameter_count()],
02766 ** [sqlite3_bind_parameter_name()], and [sqlite3_bind_parameter_index()].
02767 */
02768 SQLITE_API int sqlite3_bind_blob(sqlite3_stmt*, int, const void*, int n, void(*)(void*));
02769 SQLITE_API int sqlite3_bind_double(sqlite3_stmt*, int, double);
02770 SQLITE_API int sqlite3_bind_int(sqlite3_stmt*, int, int);
02771 SQLITE_API int sqlite3_bind_int64(sqlite3_stmt*, int, sqlite3_int64);
02772 SQLITE_API int sqlite3_bind_null(sqlite3_stmt*, int);
02773 SQLITE_API int sqlite3_bind_text(sqlite3_stmt*, int, const char*, int n, void(*)(void*));
02774 SQLITE_API int sqlite3_bind_text16(sqlite3_stmt*, int, const void*, int, void(*)(void*));
02775 SQLITE_API int sqlite3_bind_value(sqlite3_stmt*, int, const sqlite3_value*);
02776 SQLITE_API int sqlite3_bind_zeroblob(sqlite3_stmt*, int, int n);
02777 
02778 /*
02779 ** CAPI3REF: Number Of SQL Parameters
02780 **
02781 ** ^This routine can be used to find the number of [SQL parameters]
02782 ** in a [prepared statement].  SQL parameters are tokens of the
02783 ** form "?", "?NNN", ":AAA", "$AAA", or "@AAA" that serve as
02784 ** placeholders for values that are [sqlite3_bind_blob | bound]
02785 ** to the parameters at a later time.
02786 **
02787 ** ^(This routine actually returns the index of the largest (rightmost)
02788 ** parameter. For all forms except ?NNN, this will correspond to the
02789 ** number of unique parameters.  If parameters of the ?NNN form are used,
02790 ** there may be gaps in the list.)^
02791 **
02792 ** See also: [sqlite3_bind_blob|sqlite3_bind()],
02793 ** [sqlite3_bind_parameter_name()], and
02794 ** [sqlite3_bind_parameter_index()].
02795 */
02796 SQLITE_API int sqlite3_bind_parameter_count(sqlite3_stmt*);
02797 
02798 /*
02799 ** CAPI3REF: Name Of A Host Parameter
02800 **
02801 ** ^The sqlite3_bind_parameter_name(P,N) interface returns
02802 ** the name of the N-th [SQL parameter] in the [prepared statement] P.
02803 ** ^(SQL parameters of the form "?NNN" or ":AAA" or "@AAA" or "$AAA"
02804 ** have a name which is the string "?NNN" or ":AAA" or "@AAA" or "$AAA"
02805 ** respectively.
02806 ** In other words, the initial ":" or "$" or "@" or "?"
02807 ** is included as part of the name.)^
02808 ** ^Parameters of the form "?" without a following integer have no name
02809 ** and are referred to as "nameless" or "anonymous parameters".
02810 **
02811 ** ^The first host parameter has an index of 1, not 0.
02812 **
02813 ** ^If the value N is out of range or if the N-th parameter is
02814 ** nameless, then NULL is returned.  ^The returned string is
02815 ** always in UTF-8 encoding even if the named parameter was
02816 ** originally specified as UTF-16 in [sqlite3_prepare16()] or
02817 ** [sqlite3_prepare16_v2()].
02818 **
02819 ** See also: [sqlite3_bind_blob|sqlite3_bind()],
02820 ** [sqlite3_bind_parameter_count()], and
02821 ** [sqlite3_bind_parameter_index()].
02822 */
02823 SQLITE_API const char *sqlite3_bind_parameter_name(sqlite3_stmt*, int);
02824 
02825 /*
02826 ** CAPI3REF: Index Of A Parameter With A Given Name
02827 **
02828 ** ^Return the index of an SQL parameter given its name.  ^The
02829 ** index value returned is suitable for use as the second
02830 ** parameter to [sqlite3_bind_blob|sqlite3_bind()].  ^A zero
02831 ** is returned if no matching parameter is found.  ^The parameter
02832 ** name must be given in UTF-8 even if the original statement
02833 ** was prepared from UTF-16 text using [sqlite3_prepare16_v2()].
02834 **
02835 ** See also: [sqlite3_bind_blob|sqlite3_bind()],
02836 ** [sqlite3_bind_parameter_count()], and
02837 ** [sqlite3_bind_parameter_index()].
02838 */
02839 SQLITE_API int sqlite3_bind_parameter_index(sqlite3_stmt*, const char *zName);
02840 
02841 /*
02842 ** CAPI3REF: Reset All Bindings On A Prepared Statement
02843 **
02844 ** ^Contrary to the intuition of many, [sqlite3_reset()] does not reset
02845 ** the [sqlite3_bind_blob | bindings] on a [prepared statement].
02846 ** ^Use this routine to reset all host parameters to NULL.
02847 */
02848 SQLITE_API int sqlite3_clear_bindings(sqlite3_stmt*);
02849 
02850 /*
02851 ** CAPI3REF: Number Of Columns In A Result Set
02852 **
02853 ** ^Return the number of columns in the result set returned by the
02854 ** [prepared statement]. ^This routine returns 0 if pStmt is an SQL
02855 ** statement that does not return data (for example an [UPDATE]).
02856 **
02857 ** See also: [sqlite3_data_count()]
02858 */
02859 SQLITE_API int sqlite3_column_count(sqlite3_stmt *pStmt);
02860 
02861 /*
02862 ** CAPI3REF: Column Names In A Result Set
02863 **
02864 ** ^These routines return the name assigned to a particular column
02865 ** in the result set of a [SELECT] statement.  ^The sqlite3_column_name()
02866 ** interface returns a pointer to a zero-terminated UTF-8 string
02867 ** and sqlite3_column_name16() returns a pointer to a zero-terminated
02868 ** UTF-16 string.  ^The first parameter is the [prepared statement]
02869 ** that implements the [SELECT] statement. ^The second parameter is the
02870 ** column number.  ^The leftmost column is number 0.
02871 **
02872 ** ^The returned string pointer is valid until either the [prepared statement]
02873 ** is destroyed by [sqlite3_finalize()] or until the next call to
02874 ** sqlite3_column_name() or sqlite3_column_name16() on the same column.
02875 **
02876 ** ^If sqlite3_malloc() fails during the processing of either routine
02877 ** (for example during a conversion from UTF-8 to UTF-16) then a
02878 ** NULL pointer is returned.
02879 **
02880 ** ^The name of a result column is the value of the "AS" clause for
02881 ** that column, if there is an AS clause.  If there is no AS clause
02882 ** then the name of the column is unspecified and may change from
02883 ** one release of SQLite to the next.
02884 */
02885 SQLITE_API const char *sqlite3_column_name(sqlite3_stmt*, int N);
02886 SQLITE_API const void *sqlite3_column_name16(sqlite3_stmt*, int N);
02887 
02888 /*
02889 ** CAPI3REF: Source Of Data In A Query Result
02890 **
02891 ** ^These routines provide a means to determine the database, table, and
02892 ** table column that is the origin of a particular result column in
02893 ** [SELECT] statement.
02894 ** ^The name of the database or table or column can be returned as
02895 ** either a UTF-8 or UTF-16 string.  ^The _database_ routines return
02896 ** the database name, the _table_ routines return the table name, and
02897 ** the origin_ routines return the column name.
02898 ** ^The returned string is valid until the [prepared statement] is destroyed
02899 ** using [sqlite3_finalize()] or until the same information is requested
02900 ** again in a different encoding.
02901 **
02902 ** ^The names returned are the original un-aliased names of the
02903 ** database, table, and column.
02904 **
02905 ** ^The first argument to these interfaces is a [prepared statement].
02906 ** ^These functions return information about the Nth result column returned by
02907 ** the statement, where N is the second function argument.
02908 ** ^The left-most column is column 0 for these routines.
02909 **
02910 ** ^If the Nth column returned by the statement is an expression or
02911 ** subquery and is not a column value, then all of these functions return
02912 ** NULL.  ^These routine might also return NULL if a memory allocation error
02913 ** occurs.  ^Otherwise, they return the name of the attached database, table,
02914 ** or column that query result column was extracted from.
02915 **
02916 ** ^As with all other SQLite APIs, those whose names end with "16" return
02917 ** UTF-16 encoded strings and the other functions return UTF-8.
02918 **
02919 ** ^These APIs are only available if the library was compiled with the
02920 ** [SQLITE_ENABLE_COLUMN_METADATA] C-preprocessor symbol.
02921 **
02922 ** If two or more threads call one or more of these routines against the same
02923 ** prepared statement and column at the same time then the results are
02924 ** undefined.
02925 **
02926 ** If two or more threads call one or more
02927 ** [sqlite3_column_database_name | column metadata interfaces]
02928 ** for the same [prepared statement] and result column
02929 ** at the same time then the results are undefined.
02930 */
02931 SQLITE_API const char *sqlite3_column_database_name(sqlite3_stmt*,int);
02932 SQLITE_API const void *sqlite3_column_database_name16(sqlite3_stmt*,int);
02933 SQLITE_API const char *sqlite3_column_table_name(sqlite3_stmt*,int);
02934 SQLITE_API const void *sqlite3_column_table_name16(sqlite3_stmt*,int);
02935 SQLITE_API const char *sqlite3_column_origin_name(sqlite3_stmt*,int);
02936 SQLITE_API const void *sqlite3_column_origin_name16(sqlite3_stmt*,int);
02937 
02938 /*
02939 ** CAPI3REF: Declared Datatype Of A Query Result
02940 **
02941 ** ^(The first parameter is a [prepared statement].
02942 ** If this statement is a [SELECT] statement and the Nth column of the
02943 ** returned result set of that [SELECT] is a table column (not an
02944 ** expression or subquery) then the declared type of the table
02945 ** column is returned.)^  ^If the Nth column of the result set is an
02946 ** expression or subquery, then a NULL pointer is returned.
02947 ** ^The returned string is always UTF-8 encoded.
02948 **
02949 ** ^(For example, given the database schema:
02950 **
02951 ** CREATE TABLE t1(c1 VARIANT);
02952 **
02953 ** and the following statement to be compiled:
02954 **
02955 ** SELECT c1 + 1, c1 FROM t1;
02956 **
02957 ** this routine would return the string "VARIANT" for the second result
02958 ** column (i==1), and a NULL pointer for the first result column (i==0).)^
02959 **
02960 ** ^SQLite uses dynamic run-time typing.  ^So just because a column
02961 ** is declared to contain a particular type does not mean that the
02962 ** data stored in that column is of the declared type.  SQLite is
02963 ** strongly typed, but the typing is dynamic not static.  ^Type
02964 ** is associated with individual values, not with the containers
02965 ** used to hold those values.
02966 */
02967 SQLITE_API const char *sqlite3_column_decltype(sqlite3_stmt*,int);
02968 SQLITE_API const void *sqlite3_column_decltype16(sqlite3_stmt*,int);
02969 
02970 /*
02971 ** CAPI3REF: Evaluate An SQL Statement
02972 **
02973 ** After a [prepared statement] has been prepared using either
02974 ** [sqlite3_prepare_v2()] or [sqlite3_prepare16_v2()] or one of the legacy
