02975 ** interfaces [sqlite3_prepare()] or [sqlite3_prepare16()], this function
02976 ** must be called one or more times to evaluate the statement.
02977 **
02978 ** The details of the behavior of the sqlite3_step() interface depend
02979 ** on whether the statement was prepared using the newer "v2" interface
02980 ** [sqlite3_prepare_v2()] and [sqlite3_prepare16_v2()] or the older legacy
02981 ** interface [sqlite3_prepare()] and [sqlite3_prepare16()].  The use of the
02982 ** new "v2" interface is recommended for new applications but the legacy
02983 ** interface will continue to be supported.
02984 **
02985 ** ^In the legacy interface, the return value will be either [SQLITE_BUSY],
02986 ** [SQLITE_DONE], [SQLITE_ROW], [SQLITE_ERROR], or [SQLITE_MISUSE].
02987 ** ^With the "v2" interface, any of the other [result codes] or
02988 ** [extended result codes] might be returned as well.
02989 **
02990 ** ^[SQLITE_BUSY] means that the database engine was unable to acquire the
02991 ** database locks it needs to do its job.  ^If the statement is a [COMMIT]
02992 ** or occurs outside of an explicit transaction, then you can retry the
02993 ** statement.  If the statement is not a [COMMIT] and occurs within a
02994 ** explicit transaction then you should rollback the transaction before
02995 ** continuing.
02996 **
02997 ** ^[SQLITE_DONE] means that the statement has finished executing
02998 ** successfully.  sqlite3_step() should not be called again on this virtual
02999 ** machine without first calling [sqlite3_reset()] to reset the virtual
03000 ** machine back to its initial state.
03001 **
03002 ** ^If the SQL statement being executed returns any data, then [SQLITE_ROW]
03003 ** is returned each time a new row of data is ready for processing by the
03004 ** caller. The values may be accessed using the [column access functions].
03005 ** sqlite3_step() is called again to retrieve the next row of data.
03006 **
03007 ** ^[SQLITE_ERROR] means that a run-time error (such as a constraint
03008 ** violation) has occurred.  sqlite3_step() should not be called again on
03009 ** the VM. More information may be found by calling [sqlite3_errmsg()].
03010 ** ^With the legacy interface, a more specific error code (for example,
03011 ** [SQLITE_INTERRUPT], [SQLITE_SCHEMA], [SQLITE_CORRUPT], and so forth)
03012 ** can be obtained by calling [sqlite3_reset()] on the
03013 ** [prepared statement].  ^In the "v2" interface,
03014 ** the more specific error code is returned directly by sqlite3_step().
03015 **
03016 ** [SQLITE_MISUSE] means that the this routine was called inappropriately.
03017 ** Perhaps it was called on a [prepared statement] that has
03018 ** already been [sqlite3_finalize | finalized] or on one that had
03019 ** previously returned [SQLITE_ERROR] or [SQLITE_DONE].  Or it could
03020 ** be the case that the same database connection is being used by two or
03021 ** more threads at the same moment in time.
03022 **
03023 ** For all versions of SQLite up to and including 3.6.23.1, it was required
03024 ** after sqlite3_step() returned anything other than [SQLITE_ROW] that
03025 ** [sqlite3_reset()] be called before any subsequent invocation of
03026 ** sqlite3_step().  Failure to invoke [sqlite3_reset()] in this way would
03027 ** result in an [SQLITE_MISUSE] return from sqlite3_step().  But after
03028 ** version 3.6.23.1, sqlite3_step() began calling [sqlite3_reset()] 
03029 ** automatically in this circumstance rather than returning [SQLITE_MISUSE].  
03030 **
03031 ** <b>Goofy Interface Alert:</b> In the legacy interface, the sqlite3_step()
03032 ** API always returns a generic error code, [SQLITE_ERROR], following any
03033 ** error other than [SQLITE_BUSY] and [SQLITE_MISUSE].  You must call
03034 ** [sqlite3_reset()] or [sqlite3_finalize()] in order to find one of the
03035 ** specific [error codes] that better describes the error.
03036 ** We admit that this is a goofy design.  The problem has been fixed
03037 ** with the "v2" interface.  If you prepare all of your SQL statements
03038 ** using either [sqlite3_prepare_v2()] or [sqlite3_prepare16_v2()] instead
03039 ** of the legacy [sqlite3_prepare()] and [sqlite3_prepare16()] interfaces,
03040 ** then the more specific [error codes] are returned directly
03041 ** by sqlite3_step().  The use of the "v2" interface is recommended.
03042 */
03043 SQLITE_API int sqlite3_step(sqlite3_stmt*);
03044 
03045 /*
03046 ** CAPI3REF: Number of columns in a result set
03047 **
03048 ** ^The sqlite3_data_count(P) interface returns the number of columns in the
03049 ** current row of the result set of [prepared statement] P.
03050 ** ^If prepared statement P does not have results ready to return
03051 ** (via calls to the [sqlite3_column_int | sqlite3_column_*()] of
03052 ** interfaces) then sqlite3_data_count(P) returns 0.
03053 ** ^The sqlite3_data_count(P) routine also returns 0 if P is a NULL pointer.
03054 **
03055 ** See also: [sqlite3_column_count()]
03056 */
03057 SQLITE_API int sqlite3_data_count(sqlite3_stmt *pStmt);
03058 
03059 /*
03060 ** CAPI3REF: Fundamental Datatypes
03061 ** KEYWORDS: SQLITE_TEXT
03062 **
03063 ** ^(Every value in SQLite has one of five fundamental datatypes:
03064 **
03065 ** <ul>
03066 ** <li> 64-bit signed integer
03067 ** <li> 64-bit IEEE floating point number
03068 ** <li> string
03069 ** <li> BLOB
03070 ** <li> NULL
03071 ** </ul>)^
03072 **
03073 ** These constants are codes for each of those types.
03074 **
03075 ** Note that the SQLITE_TEXT constant was also used in SQLite version 2
03076 ** for a completely different meaning.  Software that links against both
03077 ** SQLite version 2 and SQLite version 3 should use SQLITE3_TEXT, not
03078 ** SQLITE_TEXT.
03079 */
03080 #define SQLITE_INTEGER  1
03081 #define SQLITE_FLOAT    2
03082 #define SQLITE_BLOB     4
03083 #define SQLITE_NULL     5
03084 #ifdef SQLITE_TEXT
03085 # undef SQLITE_TEXT
03086 #else
03087 # define SQLITE_TEXT     3
03088 #endif
03089 #define SQLITE3_TEXT     3
03090 
03091 /*
03092 ** CAPI3REF: Result Values From A Query
03093 ** KEYWORDS: {column access functions}
03094 **
03095 ** These routines form the "result set" interface.
03096 **
03097 ** ^These routines return information about a single column of the current
03098 ** result row of a query.  ^In every case the first argument is a pointer
03099 ** to the [prepared statement] that is being evaluated (the [sqlite3_stmt*]
03100 ** that was returned from [sqlite3_prepare_v2()] or one of its variants)
03101 ** and the second argument is the index of the column for which information
03102 ** should be returned. ^The leftmost column of the result set has the index 0.
03103 ** ^The number of columns in the result can be determined using
03104 ** [sqlite3_column_count()].
03105 **
03106 ** If the SQL statement does not currently point to a valid row, or if the
03107 ** column index is out of range, the result is undefined.
03108 ** These routines may only be called when the most recent call to
03109 ** [sqlite3_step()] has returned [SQLITE_ROW] and neither
03110 ** [sqlite3_reset()] nor [sqlite3_finalize()] have been called subsequently.
03111 ** If any of these routines are called after [sqlite3_reset()] or
03112 ** [sqlite3_finalize()] or after [sqlite3_step()] has returned
03113 ** something other than [SQLITE_ROW], the results are undefined.
03114 ** If [sqlite3_step()] or [sqlite3_reset()] or [sqlite3_finalize()]
03115 ** are called from a different thread while any of these routines
03116 ** are pending, then the results are undefined.
03117 **
03118 ** ^The sqlite3_column_type() routine returns the
03119 ** [SQLITE_INTEGER | datatype code] for the initial data type
03120 ** of the result column.  ^The returned value is one of [SQLITE_INTEGER],
03121 ** [SQLITE_FLOAT], [SQLITE_TEXT], [SQLITE_BLOB], or [SQLITE_NULL].  The value
03122 ** returned by sqlite3_column_type() is only meaningful if no type
03123 ** conversions have occurred as described below.  After a type conversion,
03124 ** the value returned by sqlite3_column_type() is undefined.  Future
03125 ** versions of SQLite may change the behavior of sqlite3_column_type()
03126 ** following a type conversion.
03127 **
03128 ** ^If the result is a BLOB or UTF-8 string then the sqlite3_column_bytes()
03129 ** routine returns the number of bytes in that BLOB or string.
03130 ** ^If the result is a UTF-16 string, then sqlite3_column_bytes() converts
03131 ** the string to UTF-8 and then returns the number of bytes.
03132 ** ^If the result is a numeric value then sqlite3_column_bytes() uses
03133 ** [sqlite3_snprintf()] to convert that value to a UTF-8 string and returns
03134 ** the number of bytes in that string.
03135 ** ^If the result is NULL, then sqlite3_column_bytes() returns zero.
03136 **
03137 ** ^If the result is a BLOB or UTF-16 string then the sqlite3_column_bytes16()
03138 ** routine returns the number of bytes in that BLOB or string.
03139 ** ^If the result is a UTF-8 string, then sqlite3_column_bytes16() converts
03140 ** the string to UTF-16 and then returns the number of bytes.
03141 ** ^If the result is a numeric value then sqlite3_column_bytes16() uses
03142 ** [sqlite3_snprintf()] to convert that value to a UTF-16 string and returns
03143 ** the number of bytes in that string.
03144 ** ^If the result is NULL, then sqlite3_column_bytes16() returns zero.
03145 **
03146 ** ^The values returned by [sqlite3_column_bytes()] and 
03147 ** [sqlite3_column_bytes16()] do not include the zero terminators at the end
03148 ** of the string.  ^For clarity: the values returned by
03149 ** [sqlite3_column_bytes()] and [sqlite3_column_bytes16()] are the number of
03150 ** bytes in the string, not the number of characters.
03151 **
03152 ** ^Strings returned by sqlite3_column_text() and sqlite3_column_text16(),
03153 ** even empty strings, are always zero terminated.  ^The return
03154 ** value from sqlite3_column_blob() for a zero-length BLOB is a NULL pointer.
03155 **
03156 ** ^The object returned by [sqlite3_column_value()] is an
03157 ** [unprotected sqlite3_value] object.  An unprotected sqlite3_value object
03158 ** may only be used with [sqlite3_bind_value()] and [sqlite3_result_value()].
03159 ** If the [unprotected sqlite3_value] object returned by
03160 ** [sqlite3_column_value()] is used in any other way, including calls
03161 ** to routines like [sqlite3_value_int()], [sqlite3_value_text()],
03162 ** or [sqlite3_value_bytes()], then the behavior is undefined.
03163 **
03164 ** These routines attempt to convert the value where appropriate.  ^For
03165 ** example, if the internal representation is FLOAT and a text result
03166 ** is requested, [sqlite3_snprintf()] is used internally to perform the
03167 ** conversion automatically.  ^(The following table details the conversions
03168 ** that are applied:
03169 **
03170 ** <blockquote>
03171 ** <table border="1">
03172 ** <tr><th> Internal<br>Type <th> Requested<br>Type <th>  Conversion
03173 **
03174 ** <tr><td>  NULL    <td> INTEGER   <td> Result is 0
03175 ** <tr><td>  NULL    <td>  FLOAT    <td> Result is 0.0
03176 ** <tr><td>  NULL    <td>   TEXT    <td> Result is NULL pointer
03177 ** <tr><td>  NULL    <td>   BLOB    <td> Result is NULL pointer
03178 ** <tr><td> INTEGER  <td>  FLOAT    <td> Convert from integer to float
03179 ** <tr><td> INTEGER  <td>   TEXT    <td> ASCII rendering of the integer
03180 ** <tr><td> INTEGER  <td>   BLOB    <td> Same as INTEGER->TEXT
03181 ** <tr><td>  FLOAT   <td> INTEGER   <td> Convert from float to integer
03182 ** <tr><td>  FLOAT   <td>   TEXT    <td> ASCII rendering of the float
03183 ** <tr><td>  FLOAT   <td>   BLOB    <td> Same as FLOAT->TEXT
03184 ** <tr><td>  TEXT    <td> INTEGER   <td> Use atoi()
03185 ** <tr><td>  TEXT    <td>  FLOAT    <td> Use atof()
03186 ** <tr><td>  TEXT    <td>   BLOB    <td> No change
03187 ** <tr><td>  BLOB    <td> INTEGER   <td> Convert to TEXT then use atoi()
03188 ** <tr><td>  BLOB    <td>  FLOAT    <td> Convert to TEXT then use atof()
03189 ** <tr><td>  BLOB    <td>   TEXT    <td> Add a zero terminator if needed
03190 ** </table>
03191 ** </blockquote>)^
03192 **
03193 ** The table above makes reference to standard C library functions atoi()
03194 ** and atof().  SQLite does not really use these functions.  It has its
03195 ** own equivalent internal routines.  The atoi() and atof() names are
03196 ** used in the table for brevity and because they are familiar to most
03197 ** C programmers.
03198 **
03199 ** Note that when type conversions occur, pointers returned by prior
03200 ** calls to sqlite3_column_blob(), sqlite3_column_text(), and/or
03201 ** sqlite3_column_text16() may be invalidated.
03202 ** Type conversions and pointer invalidations might occur
03203 ** in the following cases:
03204 **
03205 ** <ul>
03206 ** <li> The initial content is a BLOB and sqlite3_column_text() or
03207 **      sqlite3_column_text16() is called.  A zero-terminator might
03208 **      need to be added to the string.</li>
03209 ** <li> The initial content is UTF-8 text and sqlite3_column_bytes16() or
03210 **      sqlite3_column_text16() is called.  The content must be converted
03211 **      to UTF-16.</li>
03212 ** <li> The initial content is UTF-16 text and sqlite3_column_bytes() or
03213 **      sqlite3_column_text() is called.  The content must be converted
03214 **      to UTF-8.</li>
03215 ** </ul>
03216 **
03217 ** ^Conversions between UTF-16be and UTF-16le are always done in place and do
03218 ** not invalidate a prior pointer, though of course the content of the buffer
03219 ** that the prior pointer references will have been modified.  Other kinds
03220 ** of conversion are done in place when it is possible, but sometimes they
03221 ** are not possible and in those cases prior pointers are invalidated.
03222 **
03223 ** The safest and easiest to remember policy is to invoke these routines
03224 ** in one of the following ways:
03225 **
03226 ** <ul>
03227 **  <li>sqlite3_column_text() followed by sqlite3_column_bytes()</li>
03228 **  <li>sqlite3_column_blob() followed by sqlite3_column_bytes()</li>
03229 **  <li>sqlite3_column_text16() followed by sqlite3_column_bytes16()</li>
03230 ** </ul>
03231 **
03232 ** In other words, you should call sqlite3_column_text(),
03233 ** sqlite3_column_blob(), or sqlite3_column_text16() first to force the result
03234 ** into the desired format, then invoke sqlite3_column_bytes() or
03235 ** sqlite3_column_bytes16() to find the size of the result.  Do not mix calls
03236 ** to sqlite3_column_text() or sqlite3_column_blob() with calls to
03237 ** sqlite3_column_bytes16(), and do not mix calls to sqlite3_column_text16()
03238 ** with calls to sqlite3_column_bytes().
03239 **
03240 ** ^The pointers returned are valid until a type conversion occurs as
03241 ** described above, or until [sqlite3_step()] or [sqlite3_reset()] or
03242 ** [sqlite3_finalize()] is called.  ^The memory space used to hold strings
03243 ** and BLOBs is freed automatically.  Do <b>not</b> pass the pointers returned
03244 ** [sqlite3_column_blob()], [sqlite3_column_text()], etc. into
03245 ** [sqlite3_free()].
03246 **
03247 ** ^(If a memory allocation error occurs during the evaluation of any
03248 ** of these routines, a default value is returned.  The default value
03249 ** is either the integer 0, the floating point number 0.0, or a NULL
03250 ** pointer.  Subsequent calls to [sqlite3_errcode()] will return
03251 ** [SQLITE_NOMEM].)^
03252 */
03253 SQLITE_API const void *sqlite3_column_blob(sqlite3_stmt*, int iCol);
03254 SQLITE_API int sqlite3_column_bytes(sqlite3_stmt*, int iCol);
03255 SQLITE_API int sqlite3_column_bytes16(sqlite3_stmt*, int iCol);
03256 SQLITE_API double sqlite3_column_double(sqlite3_stmt*, int iCol);
03257 SQLITE_API int sqlite3_column_int(sqlite3_stmt*, int iCol);
03258 SQLITE_API sqlite3_int64 sqlite3_column_int64(sqlite3_stmt*, int iCol);
03259 SQLITE_API const unsigned char *sqlite3_column_text(sqlite3_stmt*, int iCol);
03260 SQLITE_API const void *sqlite3_column_text16(sqlite3_stmt*, int iCol);
03261 SQLITE_API int sqlite3_column_type(sqlite3_stmt*, int iCol);
03262 SQLITE_API sqlite3_value *sqlite3_column_value(sqlite3_stmt*, int iCol);
03263 
03264 /*
03265 ** CAPI3REF: Destroy A Prepared Statement Object
03266 **
03267 ** ^The sqlite3_finalize() function is called to delete a [prepared statement].
03268 ** ^If the most recent evaluation of the statement encountered no errors or
03269 ** or if the statement is never been evaluated, then sqlite3_finalize() returns
03270 ** SQLITE_OK.  ^If the most recent evaluation of statement S failed, then
03271 ** sqlite3_finalize(S) returns the appropriate [error code] or
03272 ** [extended error code].
03273 **
03274 ** ^The sqlite3_finalize(S) routine can be called at any point during
03275 ** the life cycle of [prepared statement] S:
03276 ** before statement S is ever evaluated, after
03277 ** one or more calls to [sqlite3_reset()], or after any call
03278 ** to [sqlite3_step()] regardless of whether or not the statement has
03279 ** completed execution.
03280 **
03281 ** ^Invoking sqlite3_finalize() on a NULL pointer is a harmless no-op.
03282 **
03283 ** The application must finalize every [prepared statement] in order to avoid
03284 ** resource leaks.  It is a grievous error for the application to try to use
03285 ** a prepared statement after it has been finalized.  Any use of a prepared
03286 ** statement after it has been finalized can result in undefined and
03287 ** undesirable behavior such as segfaults and heap corruption.
03288 */
03289 SQLITE_API int sqlite3_finalize(sqlite3_stmt *pStmt);
03290 
03291 /*
03292 ** CAPI3REF: Reset A Prepared Statement Object
03293 **
03294 ** The sqlite3_reset() function is called to reset a [prepared statement]
03295 ** object back to its initial state, ready to be re-executed.
03296 ** ^Any SQL statement variables that had values bound to them using
03297 ** the [sqlite3_bind_blob | sqlite3_bind_*() API] retain their values.
03298 ** Use [sqlite3_clear_bindings()] to reset the bindings.
03299 **
03300 ** ^The [sqlite3_reset(S)] interface resets the [prepared statement] S
03301 ** back to the beginning of its program.
03302 **
03303 ** ^If the most recent call to [sqlite3_step(S)] for the
03304 ** [prepared statement] S returned [SQLITE_ROW] or [SQLITE_DONE],
03305 ** or if [sqlite3_step(S)] has never before been called on S,
03306 ** then [sqlite3_reset(S)] returns [SQLITE_OK].
03307 **
03308 ** ^If the most recent call to [sqlite3_step(S)] for the
03309 ** [prepared statement] S indicated an error, then
03310 ** [sqlite3_reset(S)] returns an appropriate [error code].
03311 **
03312 ** ^The [sqlite3_reset(S)] interface does not change the values
03313 ** of any [sqlite3_bind_blob|bindings] on the [prepared statement] S.
03314 */
03315 SQLITE_API int sqlite3_reset(sqlite3_stmt *pStmt);
03316 
03317 /*
03318 ** CAPI3REF: Create Or Redefine SQL Functions
03319 ** KEYWORDS: {function creation routines}
03320 ** KEYWORDS: {application-defined SQL function}
03321 ** KEYWORDS: {application-defined SQL functions}
03322 **
03323 ** ^These functions (collectively known as "function creation routines")
03324 ** are used to add SQL functions or aggregates or to redefine the behavior
03325 ** of existing SQL functions or aggregates.  The only differences between
03326 ** these routines are the text encoding expected for
03327 ** the the second parameter (the name of the function being created)
03328 ** and the presence or absence of a destructor callback for
03329 ** the application data pointer.
03330 **
03331 ** ^The first parameter is the [database connection] to which the SQL
03332 ** function is to be added.  ^If an application uses more than one database
03333 ** connection then application-defined SQL functions must be added
03334 ** to each database connection separately.
03335 **
03336 ** ^The second parameter is the name of the SQL function to be created or
03337 ** redefined.  ^The length of the name is limited to 255 bytes in a UTF-8
03338 ** representation, exclusive of the zero-terminator.  ^Note that the name
03339 ** length limit is in UTF-8 bytes, not characters nor UTF-16 bytes.  
03340 ** ^Any attempt to create a function with a longer name
03341 ** will result in [SQLITE_MISUSE] being returned.
03342 **
03343 ** ^The third parameter (nArg)
03344 ** is the number of arguments that the SQL function or
03345 ** aggregate takes. ^If this parameter is -1, then the SQL function or
03346 ** aggregate may take any number of arguments between 0 and the limit
03347 ** set by [sqlite3_limit]([SQLITE_LIMIT_FUNCTION_ARG]).  If the third
03348 ** parameter is less than -1 or greater than 127 then the behavior is
03349 ** undefined.
03350 **
03351 ** ^The fourth parameter, eTextRep, specifies what
03352 ** [SQLITE_UTF8 | text encoding] this SQL function prefers for
03353 ** its parameters.  Every SQL function implementation must be able to work
03354 ** with UTF-8, UTF-16le, or UTF-16be.  But some implementations may be
03355 ** more efficient with one encoding than another.  ^An application may
03356 ** invoke sqlite3_create_function() or sqlite3_create_function16() multiple
03357 ** times with the same function but with different values of eTextRep.
03358 ** ^When multiple implementations of the same function are available, SQLite
03359 ** will pick the one that involves the least amount of data conversion.
03360 ** If there is only a single implementation which does not care what text
03361 ** encoding is used, then the fourth argument should be [SQLITE_ANY].
03362 **
03363 ** ^(The fifth parameter is an arbitrary pointer.  The implementation of the
03364 ** function can gain access to this pointer using [sqlite3_user_data()].)^
03365 **
03366 ** ^The seventh, eighth and ninth parameters, xFunc, xStep and xFinal, are
03367 ** pointers to C-language functions that implement the SQL function or
03368 ** aggregate. ^A scalar SQL function requires an implementation of the xFunc
03369 ** callback only; NULL pointers must be passed as the xStep and xFinal
03370 ** parameters. ^An aggregate SQL function requires an implementation of xStep
03371 ** and xFinal and NULL pointer must be passed for xFunc. ^To delete an existing
03372 ** SQL function or aggregate, pass NULL poiners for all three function
03373 ** callbacks.
03374 **
03375 ** ^If the tenth parameter to sqlite3_create_function_v2() is not NULL,
03376 ** then it is invoked when the function is deleted, either by being
03377 ** overloaded or when the database connection closes.
03378 ** ^When the destructure callback of the tenth parameter is invoked, it
03379 ** is passed a single argument which is a copy of the pointer which was
03380 ** the fifth parameter to sqlite3_create_function_v2().
03381 **
03382 ** ^It is permitted to register multiple implementations of the same
03383 ** functions with the same name but with either differing numbers of
03384 ** arguments or differing preferred text encodings.  ^SQLite will use
03385 ** the implementation that most closely matches the way in which the
03386 ** SQL function is used.  ^A function implementation with a non-negative
03387 ** nArg parameter is a better match than a function implementation with
03388 ** a negative nArg.  ^A function where the preferred text encoding
03389 ** matches the database encoding is a better
03390 ** match than a function where the encoding is different.  
03391 ** ^A function where the encoding difference is between UTF16le and UTF16be
03392 ** is a closer match than a function where the encoding difference is
03393 ** between UTF8 and UTF16.
03394 **
03395 ** ^Built-in functions may be overloaded by new application-defined functions.
03396 **
03397 ** ^An application-defined function is permitted to call other
03398 ** SQLite interfaces.  However, such calls must not
03399 ** close the database connection nor finalize or reset the prepared
03400 ** statement in which the function is running.
03401 */
03402 SQLITE_API int sqlite3_create_function(
03403   sqlite3 *db,
03404   const char *zFunctionName,
03405   int nArg,
03406   int eTextRep,
03407   void *pApp,
03408   void (*xFunc)(sqlite3_context*,int,sqlite3_value**),
03409   void (*xStep)(sqlite3_context*,int,sqlite3_value**),
03410   void (*xFinal)(sqlite3_context*)
03411 );
03412 SQLITE_API int sqlite3_create_function16(
03413   sqlite3 *db,
03414   const void *zFunctionName,
03415   int nArg,
03416   int eTextRep,
03417   void *pApp,
03418   void (*xFunc)(sqlite3_context*,int,sqlite3_value**),
03419   void (*xStep)(sqlite3_context*,int,sqlite3_value**),
03420   void (*xFinal)(sqlite3_context*)
03421 );
03422 SQLITE_API int sqlite3_create_function_v2(
03423   sqlite3 *db,
03424   const char *zFunctionName,
03425   int nArg,
03426   int eTextRep,
03427   void *pApp,
03428   void (*xFunc)(sqlite3_context*,int,sqlite3_value**),
03429   void (*xStep)(sqlite3_context*,int,sqlite3_value**),
03430   void (*xFinal)(sqlite3_context*),
03431   void(*xDestroy)(void*)
03432 );
03433 
03434 /*
03435 ** CAPI3REF: Text Encodings
03436 **
03437 ** These constant define integer codes that represent the various
03438 ** text encodings supported by SQLite.
03439 */
03440 #define SQLITE_UTF8           1
03441 #define SQLITE_UTF16LE        2
03442 #define SQLITE_UTF16BE        3
03443 #define SQLITE_UTF16          4    /* Use native byte order */
03444 #define SQLITE_ANY            5    /* sqlite3_create_function only */
03445 #define SQLITE_UTF16_ALIGNED  8    /* sqlite3_create_collation only */
03446 
03447 /*
03448 ** CAPI3REF: Deprecated Functions
03449 ** DEPRECATED
03450 **
03451 ** These functions are [deprecated].  In order to maintain
03452 ** backwards compatibility with older code, these functions continue 
03453 ** to be supported.  However, new applications should avoid
03454 ** the use of these functions.  To help encourage people to avoid
03455 ** using these functions, we are not going to tell you what they do.
03456 */
03457 #ifndef SQLITE_OMIT_DEPRECATED
03458 SQLITE_API SQLITE_DEPRECATED int sqlite3_aggregate_count(sqlite3_context*);
03459 SQLITE_API SQLITE_DEPRECATED int sqlite3_expired(sqlite3_stmt*);
03460 SQLITE_API SQLITE_DEPRECATED int sqlite3_transfer_bindings(sqlite3_stmt*, sqlite3_stmt*);
03461 SQLITE_API SQLITE_DEPRECATED int sqlite3_global_recover(void);
03462 SQLITE_API SQLITE_DEPRECATED void sqlite3_thread_cleanup(void);
03463 SQLITE_API SQLITE_DEPRECATED int sqlite3_memory_alarm(void(*)(void*,sqlite3_int64,int),void*,sqlite3_int64);
03464 #endif
03465 
03466 /*
03467 ** CAPI3REF: Obtaining SQL Function Parameter Values
03468 **
03469 ** The C-language implementation of SQL functions and aggregates uses
03470 ** this set of interface routines to access the parameter values on
03471 ** the function or aggregate.
03472 **
03473 ** The xFunc (for scalar functions) or xStep (for aggregates) parameters
03474 ** to [sqlite3_create_function()] and [sqlite3_create_function16()]
03475 ** define callbacks that implement the SQL functions and aggregates.
03476 ** The 4th parameter to these callbacks is an array of pointers to
03477 ** [protected sqlite3_value] objects.  There is one [sqlite3_value] object for
03478 ** each parameter to the SQL function.  These routines are used to
03479 ** extract values from the [sqlite3_value] objects.
03480 **
03481 ** These routines work only with [protected sqlite3_value] objects.
03482 ** Any attempt to use these routines on an [unprotected sqlite3_value]
03483 ** object results in undefined behavior.
03484 **
03485 ** ^These routines work just like the corresponding [column access functions]
03486 ** except that  these routines take a single [protected sqlite3_value] object
03487 ** pointer instead of a [sqlite3_stmt*] pointer and an integer column number.
03488 **
03489 ** ^The sqlite3_value_text16() interface extracts a UTF-16 string
03490 ** in the native byte-order of the host machine.  ^The
03491 ** sqlite3_value_text16be() and sqlite3_value_text16le() interfaces
03492 ** extract UTF-16 strings as big-endian and little-endian respectively.
03493 **
03494 ** ^(The sqlite3_value_numeric_type() interface attempts to apply
03495 ** numeric affinity to the value.  This means that an attempt is
03496 ** made to convert the value to an integer or floating point.  If
03497 ** such a conversion is possible without loss of information (in other
03498 ** words, if the value is a string that looks like a number)
03499 ** then the conversion is performed.  Otherwise no conversion occurs.
03500 ** The [SQLITE_INTEGER | datatype] after conversion is returned.)^
03501 **
03502 ** Please pay particular attention to the fact that the pointer returned
03503 ** from [sqlite3_value_blob()], [sqlite3_value_text()], or
03504 ** [sqlite3_value_text16()] can be invalidated by a subsequent call to
03505 ** [sqlite3_value_bytes()], [sqlite3_value_bytes16()], [sqlite3_value_text()],
03506 ** or [sqlite3_value_text16()].
03507 **
03508 ** These routines must be called from the same thread as
03509 ** the SQL function that supplied the [sqlite3_value*] parameters.
03510 */
03511 SQLITE_API const void *sqlite3_value_blob(sqlite3_value*);
03512 SQLITE_API int sqlite3_value_bytes(sqlite3_value*);
03513 SQLITE_API int sqlite3_value_bytes16(sqlite3_value*);
03514 SQLITE_API double sqlite3_value_double(sqlite3_value*);
03515 SQLITE_API int sqlite3_value_int(sqlite3_value*);
03516 SQLITE_API sqlite3_int64 sqlite3_value_int64(sqlite3_value*);
03517 SQLITE_API const unsigned char *sqlite3_value_text(sqlite3_value*);
03518 SQLITE_API const void *sqlite3_value_text16(sqlite3_value*);
03519 SQLITE_API const void *sqlite3_value_text16le(sqlite3_value*);
03520 SQLITE_API const void *sqlite3_value_text16be(sqlite3_value*);
03521 SQLITE_API int sqlite3_value_type(sqlite3_value*);
03522 SQLITE_API int sqlite3_value_numeric_type(sqlite3_value*);
03523 
03524 /*
03525 ** CAPI3REF: Obtain Aggregate Function Context
03526 **
03527 ** Implementations of aggregate SQL functions use this
03528 ** routine to allocate memory for storing their state.
03529 **
03530 ** ^The first time the sqlite3_aggregate_context(C,N) routine is called 
03531 ** for a particular aggregate function, SQLite
03532 ** allocates N of memory, zeroes out that memory, and returns a pointer
03533 ** to the new memory. ^On second and subsequent calls to
03534 ** sqlite3_aggregate_context() for the same aggregate function instance,
03535 ** the same buffer is returned.  Sqlite3_aggregate_context() is normally
03536 ** called once for each invocation of the xStep callback and then one
03537 ** last time when the xFinal callback is invoked.  ^(When no rows match
03538 ** an aggregate query, the xStep() callback of the aggregate function
03539 ** implementation is never called and xFinal() is called exactly once.
03540 ** In those cases, sqlite3_aggregate_context() might be called for the
03541 ** first time from within xFinal().)^
03542 **
03543 ** ^The sqlite3_aggregate_context(C,N) routine returns a NULL pointer if N is
03544 ** less than or equal to zero or if a memory allocate error occurs.
03545 **
03546 ** ^(The amount of space allocated by sqlite3_aggregate_context(C,N) is
03547 ** determined by the N parameter on first successful call.  Changing the
03548 ** value of N in subsequent call to sqlite3_aggregate_context() within
03549 ** the same aggregate function instance will not resize the memory
03550 ** allocation.)^
03551 **
03552 ** ^SQLite automatically frees the memory allocated by 
03553 ** sqlite3_aggregate_context() when the aggregate query concludes.
03554 **
03555 ** The first parameter must be a copy of the
03556 ** [sqlite3_context | SQL function context] that is the first parameter
03557 ** to the xStep or xFinal callback routine that implements the aggregate
03558 ** function.
03559 **
03560 ** This routine must be called from the same thread in which
03561 ** the aggregate SQL function is running.
03562 */
03563 SQLITE_API void *sqlite3_aggregate_context(sqlite3_context*, int nBytes);
03564 
03565 /*
03566 ** CAPI3REF: User Data For Functions
03567 **
03568 ** ^The sqlite3_user_data() interface returns a copy of
03569 ** the pointer that was the pUserData parameter (the 5th parameter)
03570 ** of the [sqlite3_create_function()]
03571 ** and [sqlite3_create_function16()] routines that originally
03572 ** registered the application defined function.
03573 **
03574 ** This routine must be called from the same thread in which
03575 ** the application-defined function is running.
03576 */
03577 SQLITE_API void *sqlite3_user_data(sqlite3_context*);
03578 
03579 /*
03580 ** CAPI3REF: Database Connection For Functions
03581 **
03582 ** ^The sqlite3_context_db_handle() interface returns a copy of
03583 ** the pointer to the [database connection] (the 1st parameter)
03584 ** of the [sqlite3_create_function()]
03585 ** and [sqlite3_create_function16()] routines that originally
03586 ** registered the application defined function.
03587 */
03588 SQLITE_API sqlite3 *sqlite3_context_db_handle(sqlite3_context*);
03589 
03590 /*
03591 ** CAPI3REF: Function Auxiliary Data
03592 **
03593 ** The following two functions may be used by scalar SQL functions to
03594 ** associate metadata with argument values. If the same value is passed to
03595 ** multiple invocations of the same SQL function during query execution, under
03596 ** some circumstances the associated metadata may be preserved. This may
03597 ** be used, for example, to add a regular-expression matching scalar
03598 ** function. The compiled version of the regular expression is stored as
03599 ** metadata associated with the SQL value passed as the regular expression
03600 ** pattern.  The compiled regular expression can be reused on multiple
03601 ** invocations of the same function so that the original pattern string
03602 ** does not need to be recompiled on each invocation.
03603 **
03604 ** ^The sqlite3_get_auxdata() interface returns a pointer to the metadata
03605 ** associated by the sqlite3_set_auxdata() function with the Nth argument
03606 ** value to the application-defined function. ^If no metadata has been ever
03607 ** been set for the Nth argument of the function, or if the corresponding
03608 ** function parameter has changed since the meta-data was set,
03609 ** then sqlite3_get_auxdata() returns a NULL pointer.
03610 **
03611 ** ^The sqlite3_set_auxdata() interface saves the metadata
03612 ** pointed to by its 3rd parameter as the metadata for the N-th
03613 ** argument of the application-defined function.  Subsequent
03614 ** calls to sqlite3_get_auxdata() might return this data, if it has
03615 ** not been destroyed.
03616 ** ^If it is not NULL, SQLite will invoke the destructor
03617 ** function given by the 4th parameter to sqlite3_set_auxdata() on
03618 ** the metadata when the corresponding function parameter changes
03619 ** or when the SQL statement completes, whichever comes first.
03620 **
03621 ** SQLite is free to call the destructor and drop metadata on any
03622 ** parameter of any function at any time.  ^The only guarantee is that
03623 ** the destructor will be called before the metadata is dropped.
03624 **
03625 ** ^(In practice, metadata is preserved between function calls for
03626 ** expressions that are constant at compile time. This includes literal
03627 ** values and [parameters].)^
03628 **
03629 ** These routines must be called from the same thread in which
03630 ** the SQL function is running.
03631 */
03632 SQLITE_API void *sqlite3_get_auxdata(sqlite3_context*, int N);
03633 SQLITE_API void sqlite3_set_auxdata(sqlite3_context*, int N, void*, void (*)(void*));
03634 
03635 
03636 /*
03637 ** CAPI3REF: Constants Defining Special Destructor Behavior
03638 **
03639 ** These are special values for the destructor that is passed in as the
03640 ** final argument to routines like [sqlite3_result_blob()].  ^If the destructor
03641 ** argument is SQLITE_STATIC, it means that the content pointer is constant
03642 ** and will never change.  It does not need to be destroyed.  ^The
03643 ** SQLITE_TRANSIENT value means that the content will likely change in
03644 ** the near future and that SQLite should make its own private copy of
03645 ** the content before returning.
03646 **
03647 ** The typedef is necessary to work around problems in certain
03648 ** C++ compilers.  See ticket #2191.
03649 */
03650 typedef void (*sqlite3_destructor_type)(void*);
03651 #define SQLITE_STATIC      ((sqlite3_destructor_type)0)
03652 #define SQLITE_TRANSIENT   ((sqlite3_destructor_type)-1)
03653 
03654 /*
03655 ** CAPI3REF: Setting The Result Of An SQL Function
03656 **
03657 ** These routines are used by the xFunc or xFinal callbacks that
03658 ** implement SQL functions and aggregates.  See
03659 ** [sqlite3_create_function()] and [sqlite3_create_function16()]
03660 ** for additional information.
03661 **
03662 ** These functions work very much like the [parameter binding] family of
03663 ** functions used to bind values to host parameters in prepared statements.
03664 ** Refer to the [SQL parameter] documentation for additional information.
03665 **
03666 ** ^The sqlite3_result_blob() interface sets the result from
03667 ** an application-defined function to be the BLOB whose content is pointed
03668 ** to by the second parameter and which is N bytes long where N is the
03669 ** third parameter.
03670 **
03671 ** ^The sqlite3_result_zeroblob() interfaces set the result of
03672 ** the application-defined function to be a BLOB containing all zero
03673 ** bytes and N bytes in size, where N is the value of the 2nd parameter.
03674 **
03675 ** ^The sqlite3_result_double() interface sets the result from
03676 ** an application-defined function to be a floating point value specified
03677 ** by its 2nd argument.
03678 **
03679 ** ^The sqlite3_result_error() and sqlite3_result_error16() functions
03680 ** cause the implemented SQL function to throw an exception.
03681 ** ^SQLite uses the string pointed to by the
03682 ** 2nd parameter of sqlite3_result_error() or sqlite3_result_error16()
03683 ** as the text of an error message.  ^SQLite interprets the error
03684 ** message string from sqlite3_result_error() as UTF-8. ^SQLite
03685 ** interprets the string from sqlite3_result_error16() as UTF-16 in native
03686 ** byte order.  ^If the third parameter to sqlite3_result_error()
03687 ** or sqlite3_result_error16() is negative then SQLite takes as the error
03688 ** message all text up through the first zero character.
03689 ** ^If the third parameter to sqlite3_result_error() or
03690 ** sqlite3_result_error16() is non-negative then SQLite takes that many
03691 ** bytes (not characters) from the 2nd parameter as the error message.
03692 ** ^The sqlite3_result_error() and sqlite3_result_error16()
03693 ** routines make a private copy of the error message text before
03694 ** they return.  Hence, the calling function can deallocate or
03695 ** modify the text after they return without harm.
03696 ** ^The sqlite3_result_error_code() function changes the error code
03697 ** returned by SQLite as a result of an error in a function.  ^By default,
03698 ** the error code is SQLITE_ERROR.  ^A subsequent call to sqlite3_result_error()
03699 ** or sqlite3_result_error16() resets the error code to SQLITE_ERROR.
03700 **
03701 ** ^The sqlite3_result_toobig() interface causes SQLite to throw an error
03702 ** indicating that a string or BLOB is too long to represent.
03703 **
03704 ** ^The sqlite3_result_nomem() interface causes SQLite to throw an error
03705 ** indicating that a memory allocation failed.
03706 **
03707 ** ^The sqlite3_result_int() interface sets the return value
03708 ** of the application-defined function to be the 32-bit signed integer
03709 ** value given in the 2nd argument.
03710 ** ^The sqlite3_result_int64() interface sets the return value
03711 ** of the application-defined function to be the 64-bit signed integer
03712 ** value given in the 2nd argument.
03713 **
03714 ** ^The sqlite3_result_null() interface sets the return value
03715 ** of the application-defined function to be NULL.
03716 **
03717 ** ^The sqlite3_result_text(), sqlite3_result_text16(),
03718 ** sqlite3_result_text16le(), and sqlite3_result_text16be() interfaces
03719 ** set the return value of the application-defined function to be
03720 ** a text string which is represented as UTF-8, UTF-16 native byte order,
03721 ** UTF-16 little endian, or UTF-16 big endian, respectively.
03722 ** ^SQLite takes the text result from the application from
03723 ** the 2nd parameter of the sqlite3_result_text* interfaces.
03724 ** ^If the 3rd parameter to the sqlite3_result_text* interfaces
03725 ** is negative, then SQLite takes result text from the 2nd parameter
03726 ** through the first zero character.
03727 ** ^If the 3rd parameter to the sqlite3_result_text* interfaces
03728 ** is non-negative, then as many bytes (not characters) of the text
03729 ** pointed to by the 2nd parameter are taken as the application-defined
03730 ** function result.
03731 ** ^If the 4th parameter to the sqlite3_result_text* interfaces
03732 ** or sqlite3_result_blob is a non-NULL pointer, then SQLite calls that
03733 ** function as the destructor on the text or BLOB result when it has
03734 ** finished using that result.
03735 ** ^If the 4th parameter to the sqlite3_result_text* interfaces or to
03736 ** sqlite3_result_blob is the special constant SQLITE_STATIC, then SQLite
03737 ** assumes that the text or BLOB result is in constant space and does not
03738 ** copy the content of the parameter nor call a destructor on the content
03739 ** when it has finished using that result.
03740 ** ^If the 4th parameter to the sqlite3_result_text* interfaces
03741 ** or sqlite3_result_blob is the special constant SQLITE_TRANSIENT
03742 ** then SQLite makes a copy of the result into space obtained from
03743 ** from [sqlite3_malloc()] before it returns.
03744 **
03745 ** ^The sqlite3_result_value() interface sets the result of
03746 ** the application-defined function to be a copy the
03747 ** [unprotected sqlite3_value] object specified by the 2nd parameter.  ^The
03748 ** sqlite3_result_value() interface makes a copy of the [sqlite3_value]
03749 ** so that the [sqlite3_value] specified in the parameter may change or
03750 ** be deallocated after sqlite3_result_value() returns without harm.
03751 ** ^A [protected sqlite3_value] object may always be used where an
03752 ** [unprotected sqlite3_value] object is required, so either
03753 ** kind of [sqlite3_value] object can be used with this interface.
03754 **
03755 ** If these routines are called from within the different thread
03756 ** than the one containing the application-defined function that received
03757 ** the [sqlite3_context] pointer, the results are undefined.
03758 */
03759 SQLITE_API void sqlite3_result_blob(sqlite3_context*, const void*, int, void(*)(void*));
03760 SQLITE_API void sqlite3_result_double(sqlite3_context*, double);
03761 SQLITE_API void sqlite3_result_error(sqlite3_context*, const char*, int);
03762 SQLITE_API void sqlite3_result_error16(sqlite3_context*, const void*, int);
03763 SQLITE_API void sqlite3_result_error_toobig(sqlite3_context*);
03764 SQLITE_API void sqlite3_result_error_nomem(sqlite3_context*);
03765 SQLITE_API void sqlite3_result_error_code(sqlite3_context*, int);
03766 SQLITE_API void sqlite3_result_int(sqlite3_context*, int);
03767 SQLITE_API void sqlite3_result_int64(sqlite3_context*, sqlite3_int64);
03768 SQLITE_API void sqlite3_result_null(sqlite3_context*);
03769 SQLITE_API void sqlite3_result_text(sqlite3_context*, const char*, int, void(*)(void*));
03770 SQLITE_API void sqlite3_result_text16(sqlite3_context*, const void*, int, void(*)(void*));
03771 SQLITE_API void sqlite3_result_text16le(sqlite3_context*, const void*, int,void(*)(void*));
03772 SQLITE_API void sqlite3_result_text16be(sqlite3_context*, const void*, int,void(*)(void*));
03773 SQLITE_API void sqlite3_result_value(sqlite3_context*, sqlite3_value*);
03774 SQLITE_API void sqlite3_result_zeroblob(sqlite3_context*, int n);
03775 
03776 /*
03777 ** CAPI3REF: Define New Collating Sequences
03778 **
03779 ** ^These functions add, remove, or modify a [collation] associated
03780 ** with the [database connection] specified as the first argument.
03781 **
03782 ** ^The name of the collation is a UTF-8 string
03783 ** for sqlite3_create_collation() and sqlite3_create_collation_v2()
03784 ** and a UTF-16 string in native byte order for sqlite3_create_collation16().
03785 ** ^Collation names that compare equal according to [sqlite3_strnicmp()] are
03786 ** considered to be the same name.
03787 **
03788 ** ^(The third argument (eTextRep) must be one of the constants:
03789 ** <ul>
03790 ** <li> [SQLITE_UTF8],
03791 ** <li> [SQLITE_UTF16LE],
03792 ** <li> [SQLITE_UTF16BE],
03793 ** <li> [SQLITE_UTF16], or
03794 ** <li> [SQLITE_UTF16_ALIGNED].
03795 ** </ul>)^
03796 ** ^The eTextRep argument determines the encoding of strings passed
03797 ** to the collating function callback, xCallback.
03798 ** ^The [SQLITE_UTF16] and [SQLITE_UTF16_ALIGNED] values for eTextRep
03799 ** force strings to be UTF16 with native byte order.
03800 ** ^The [SQLITE_UTF16_ALIGNED] value for eTextRep forces strings to begin
03801 ** on an even byte address.
03802 **
03803 ** ^The fourth argument, pArg, is a application data pointer that is passed
03804 ** through as the first argument to the collating function callback.
03805 **
03806 ** ^The fifth argument, xCallback, is a pointer to the collating function.
03807 ** ^Multiple collating functions can be registered using the same name but
03808 ** with different eTextRep parameters and SQLite will use whichever
03809 ** function requires the least amount of data transformation.
03810 ** ^If the xCallback argument is NULL then the collating function is
03811 ** deleted.  ^When all collating functions having the same name are deleted,
03812 ** that collation is no longer usable.
03813 **
03814 ** ^The collating function callback is invoked with a copy of the pArg 
03815 ** application data pointer and with two strings in the encoding specified
03816 ** by the eTextRep argument.  The collating function must return an
03817 ** integer that is negative, zero, or positive
03818 ** if the first string is less than, equal to, or greater than the second,
03819 ** respectively.  A collating function must alway return the same answer
03820 ** given the same inputs.  If two or more collating functions are registered
03821 ** to the same collation name (using different eTextRep values) then all
03822 ** must give an equivalent answer when invoked with equivalent strings.
03823 ** The collating function must obey the following properties for all
03824 ** strings A, B, and C:
03825 **
03826 ** <ol>
03827 ** <li> If A==B then B==A.
03828 ** <li> If A==B and B==C then A==C.
03829 ** <li> If A&lt;B THEN B&gt;A.
03830 ** <li> If A&lt;B and B&lt;C then A&lt;C.
03831 ** </ol>
03832 **
03833 ** If a collating function fails any of the above constraints and that
03834 ** collating function is  registered and used, then the behavior of SQLite
03835 ** is undefined.
03836 **
03837 ** ^The sqlite3_create_collation_v2() works like sqlite3_create_collation()
03838 ** with the addition that the xDestroy callback is invoked on pArg when
03839 ** the collating function is deleted.
03840 ** ^Collating functions are deleted when they are overridden by later
03841 ** calls to the collation creation functions or when the
03842 ** [database connection] is closed using [sqlite3_close()].
03843 **
03844 ** See also:  [sqlite3_collation_needed()] and [sqlite3_collation_needed16()].
03845 */
03846 SQLITE_API int sqlite3_create_collation(
03847   sqlite3*, 
03848   const char *zName, 
03849   int eTextRep, 
03850   void *pArg,
03851   int(*xCompare)(void*,int,const void*,int,const void*)
03852 );
03853 SQLITE_API int sqlite3_create_collation_v2(
03854   sqlite3*, 
03855   const char *zName, 
03856   int eTextRep, 
03857   void *pArg,
03858   int(*xCompare)(void*,int,const void*,int,const void*),
03859   void(*xDestroy)(void*)
03860 );
03861 SQLITE_API int sqlite3_create_collation16(
03862   sqlite3*, 
03863   const void *zName,
03864   int eTextRep, 
03865   void *pArg,
03866   int(*xCompare)(void*,int,const void*,int,const void*)
03867 );
03868 
03869 /*
03870 ** CAPI3REF: Collation Needed Callbacks
03871 **
03872 ** ^To avoid having to register all collation sequences before a database
03873 ** can be used, a single callback function may be registered with the
03874 ** [database connection] to be invoked whenever an undefined collation
03875 ** sequence is required.
03876 **
03877 ** ^If the function is registered using the sqlite3_collation_needed() API,
03878 ** then it is passed the names of undefined collation sequences as strings
03879 ** encoded in UTF-8. ^If sqlite3_collation_needed16() is used,
03880 ** the names are passed as UTF-16 in machine native byte order.
03881 ** ^A call to either function replaces the existing collation-needed callback.
03882 **
03883 ** ^(When the callback is invoked, the first argument passed is a copy
03884 ** of the second argument to sqlite3_collation_needed() or
03885 ** sqlite3_collation_needed16().  The second argument is the database
03886 ** connection.  The third argument is one of [SQLITE_UTF8], [SQLITE_UTF16BE],
03887 ** or [SQLITE_UTF16LE], indicating the most desirable form of the collation
03888 ** sequence function required.  The fourth parameter is the name of the
03889 ** required collation sequence.)^
03890 **
03891 ** The callback function should register the desired collation using
03892 ** [sqlite3_create_collation()], [sqlite3_create_collation16()], or
03893 ** [sqlite3_create_collation_v2()].
03894 */
03895 SQLITE_API int sqlite3_collation_needed(
03896   sqlite3*, 
03897   void*, 
03898   void(*)(void*,sqlite3*,int eTextRep,const char*)
03899 );
03900 SQLITE_API int sqlite3_collation_needed16(
03901   sqlite3*, 
03902   void*,
03903   void(*)(void*,sqlite3*,int eTextRep,const void*)
03904 );
03905 
03906 #ifdef SQLITE_HAS_CODEC
03907 /*
03908 ** Specify the key for an encrypted database.  This routine should be
03909 ** called right after sqlite3_open().
03910 **
03911 ** The code to implement this API is not available in the public release
03912 ** of SQLite.
03913 */
03914 SQLITE_API int sqlite3_key(
03915   sqlite3 *db,                   /* Database to be rekeyed */
03916   const void *pKey, int nKey     /* The key */
03917 );
03918 
03919 /*
03920 ** Change the key on an open database.  If the current database is not
03921 ** encrypted, this routine will encrypt it.  If pNew==0 or nNew==0, the
03922 ** database is decrypted.
03923 **
03924 ** The code to implement this API is not available in the public release
03925 ** of SQLite.
03926 */
03927 SQLITE_API int sqlite3_rekey(
03928   sqlite3 *db,                   /* Database to be rekeyed */
03929   const void *pKey, int nKey     /* The new key */
03930 );
03931 
03932 /*
03933 ** Specify the activation key for a SEE database.  Unless 
03934 ** activated, none of the SEE routines will work.
03935 */
03936 SQLITE_API void sqlite3_activate_see(
03937   const char *zPassPhrase        /* Activation phrase */
03938 );
03939 #endif
03940 
03941 #ifdef SQLITE_ENABLE_CEROD
03942 /*
03943 ** Specify the activation key for a CEROD database.  Unless 
03944 ** activated, none of the CEROD routines will work.
03945 */
03946 SQLITE_API void sqlite3_activate_cerod(
03947   const char *zPassPhrase        /* Activation phrase */
03948 );
03949 #endif
03950 
03951 /*
03952 ** CAPI3REF: Suspend Execution For A Short Time
03953 **
03954 ** The sqlite3_sleep() function causes the current thread to suspend execution
03955 ** for at least a number of milliseconds specified in its parameter.
03956 **
03957 ** If the operating system does not support sleep requests with
03958 ** millisecond time resolution, then the time will be rounded up to
03959 ** the nearest second. The number of milliseconds of sleep actually
03960 ** requested from the operating system is returned.
03961 **
03962 ** ^SQLite implements this interface by calling the xSleep()
03963 ** method of the default [sqlite3_vfs] object.  If the xSleep() method
03964 ** of the default VFS is not implemented correctly, or not implemented at
03965 ** all, then the behavior of sqlite3_sleep() may deviate from the description
03966 ** in the previous paragraphs.
03967 */
03968 SQLITE_API int sqlite3_sleep(int);
03969 
03970 /*
03971 ** CAPI3REF: Name Of The Folder Holding Temporary Files
03972 **
03973 ** ^(If this global variable is made to point to a string which is
03974 ** the name of a folder (a.k.a. directory), then all temporary files
03975 ** created by SQLite when using a built-in [sqlite3_vfs | VFS]
03976 ** will be placed in that directory.)^  ^If this variable
03977 ** is a NULL pointer, then SQLite performs a search for an appropriate
03978 ** temporary file directory.
03979 **
03980 ** It is not safe to read or modify this variable in more than one
03981 ** thread at a time.  It is not safe to read or modify this variable
03982 ** if a [database connection] is being used at the same time in a separate
03983 ** thread.
03984 ** It is intended that this variable be set once
03985 ** as part of process initialization and before any SQLite interface
03986 ** routines have been called and that this variable remain unchanged
03987 ** thereafter.
03988 **
03989 ** ^The [temp_store_directory pragma] may modify this variable and cause
03990 ** it to point to memory obtained from [sqlite3_malloc].  ^Furthermore,
03991 ** the [temp_store_directory pragma] always assumes that any string
03992 ** that this variable points to is held in memory obtained from 
03993 ** [sqlite3_malloc] and the pragma may attempt to free that memory
03994 ** using [sqlite3_free].
03995 ** Hence, if this variable is modified directly, either it should be
03996 ** made NULL or made to point to memory obtained from [sqlite3_malloc]
03997 ** or else the use of the [temp_store_directory pragma] should be avoided.
03998 */
03999 SQLITE_API SQLITE_EXTERN char *sqlite3_temp_directory;
04000 
04001 /*
04002 ** CAPI3REF: Test For Auto-Commit Mode
04003 ** KEYWORDS: {autocommit mode}
04004 **
04005 ** ^The sqlite3_get_autocommit() interface returns non-zero or
04006 ** zero if the given database connection is or is not in autocommit mode,
04007 ** respectively.  ^Autocommit mode is on by default.
04008 ** ^Autocommit mode is disabled by a [BEGIN] statement.
04009 ** ^Autocommit mode is re-enabled by a [COMMIT] or [ROLLBACK].
04010 **
04011 ** If certain kinds of errors occur on a statement within a multi-statement
04012 ** transaction (errors including [SQLITE_FULL], [SQLITE_IOERR],
04013 ** [SQLITE_NOMEM], [SQLITE_BUSY], and [SQLITE_INTERRUPT]) then the
04014 ** transaction might be rolled back automatically.  The only way to
04015 ** find out whether SQLite automatically rolled back the transaction after
04016 ** an error is to use this function.
04017 **
04018 ** If another thread changes the autocommit status of the database
04019 ** connection while this routine is running, then the return value
04020 ** is undefined.
04021 */
04022 SQLITE_API int sqlite3_get_autocommit(sqlite3*);
04023 
04024 /*
04025 ** CAPI3REF: Find The Database Handle Of A Prepared Statement
04026 **
04027 ** ^The sqlite3_db_handle interface returns the [database connection] handle
04028 ** to which a [prepared statement] belongs.  ^The [database connection]
04029 ** returned by sqlite3_db_handle is the same [database connection]
04030 ** that was the first argument
04031 ** to the [sqlite3_prepare_v2()] call (or its variants) that was used to
04032 ** create the statement in the first place.
04033 */
04034 SQLITE_API sqlite3 *sqlite3_db_handle(sqlite3_stmt*);
04035 
04036 /*
04037 ** CAPI3REF: Find the next prepared statement
04038 **
04039 ** ^This interface returns a pointer to the next [prepared statement] after
04040 ** pStmt associated with the [database connection] pDb.  ^If pStmt is NULL
04041 ** then this interface returns a pointer to the first prepared statement
04042 ** associated with the database connection pDb.  ^If no prepared statement
04043 ** satisfies the conditions of this routine, it returns NULL.
04044 **
04045 ** The [database connection] pointer D in a call to
04046 ** [sqlite3_next_stmt(D,S)] must refer to an open database
04047 ** connection and in particular must not be a NULL pointer.
04048 */
04049 SQLITE_API sqlite3_stmt *sqlite3_next_stmt(sqlite3 *pDb, sqlite3_stmt *pStmt);
04050 
04051 /*
04052 ** CAPI3REF: Commit And Rollback Notification Callbacks
04053 **
04054 ** ^The sqlite3_commit_hook() interface registers a callback
04055 ** function to be invoked whenever a transaction is [COMMIT | committed].
04056 ** ^Any callback set by a previous call to sqlite3_commit_hook()
04057 ** for the same database connection is overridden.
04058 ** ^The sqlite3_rollback_hook() interface registers a callback
04059 ** function to be invoked whenever a transaction is [ROLLBACK | rolled back].
04060 ** ^Any callback set by a previous call to sqlite3_rollback_hook()
04061 ** for the same database connection is overridden.
04062 ** ^The pArg argument is passed through to the callback.
04063 ** ^If the callback on a commit hook function returns non-zero,
04064 ** then the commit is converted into a rollback.
04065 **
04066 ** ^The sqlite3_commit_hook(D,C,P) and sqlite3_rollback_hook(D,C,P) functions
04067 ** return the P argument from the previous call of the same function
04068 ** on the same [database connection] D, or NULL for
04069 ** the first call for each function on D.
04070 **
04071 ** The callback implementation must not do anything that will modify
04072 ** the database connection that invoked the callback.  Any actions
04073 ** to modify the database connection must be deferred until after the
04074 ** completion of the [sqlite3_step()] call that triggered the commit
04075 ** or rollback hook in the first place.
04076 ** Note that [sqlite3_prepare_v2()] and [sqlite3_step()] both modify their
04077 ** database connections for the meaning of "modify" in this paragraph.
04078 **
04079 ** ^Registering a NULL function disables the callback.
04080 **
04081 ** ^When the commit hook callback routine returns zero, the [COMMIT]
04082 ** operation is allowed to continue normally.  ^If the commit hook
04083 ** returns non-zero, then the [COMMIT] is converted into a [ROLLBACK].
04084 ** ^The rollback hook is invoked on a rollback that results from a commit
04085 ** hook returning non-zero, just as it would be with any other rollback.
04086 **
04087 ** ^For the purposes of this API, a transaction is said to have been
04088 ** rolled back if an explicit "ROLLBACK" statement is executed, or
04089 ** an error or constraint causes an implicit rollback to occur.
04090 ** ^The rollback callback is not invoked if a transaction is
04091 ** automatically rolled back because the database connection is closed.
04092 **
04093 ** See also the [sqlite3_update_hook()] interface.
04094 */
04095 SQLITE_API void *sqlite3_commit_hook(sqlite3*, int(*)(void*), void*);
04096 SQLITE_API void *sqlite3_rollback_hook(sqlite3*, void(*)(void *), void*);
04097 
04098 /*
04099 ** CAPI3REF: Data Change Notification Callbacks
04100 **
04101 ** ^The sqlite3_update_hook() interface registers a callback function
04102 ** with the [database connection] identified by the first argument
04103 ** to be invoked whenever a row is updated, inserted or deleted.
04104 ** ^Any callback set by a previous call to this function
04105 ** for the same database connection is overridden.
04106 **
04107 ** ^The second argument is a pointer to the function to invoke when a
04108 ** row is updated, inserted or deleted.
04109 ** ^The first argument to the callback is a copy of the third argument
04110 ** to sqlite3_update_hook().
04111 ** ^The second callback argument is one of [SQLITE_INSERT], [SQLITE_DELETE],
04112 ** or [SQLITE_UPDATE], depending on the operation that caused the callback
04113 ** to be invoked.
04114 ** ^The third and fourth arguments to the callback contain pointers to the
04115 ** database and table name containing the affected row.
04116 ** ^The final callback parameter is the [rowid] of the row.
04117 ** ^In the case of an update, this is the [rowid] after the update takes place.
04118 **
04119 ** ^(The update hook is not invoked when internal system tables are
04120 ** modified (i.e. sqlite_master and sqlite_sequence).)^
04121 **
04122 ** ^In the current implementation, the update hook
04123 ** is not invoked when duplication rows are deleted because of an
04124 ** [ON CONFLICT | ON CONFLICT REPLACE] clause.  ^Nor is the update hook
04125 ** invoked when rows are deleted using the [truncate optimization].
04126 ** The exceptions defined in this paragraph might change in a future
04127 ** release of SQLite.
04128 **
04129 ** The update hook implementation must not do anything that will modify
04130 ** the database connection that invoked the update hook.  Any actions
04131 ** to modify the database connection must be deferred until after the
04132 ** completion of the [sqlite3_step()] call that triggered the update hook.
04133 ** Note that [sqlite3_prepare_v2()] and [sqlite3_step()] both modify their
04134 ** database connections for the meaning of "modify" in this paragraph.
04135 **
04136 ** ^The sqlite3_update_hook(D,C,P) function
04137 ** returns the P argument from the previous call
04138 ** on the same [database connection] D, or NULL for
04139 ** the first call on D.
04140 **
04141 ** See also the [sqlite3_commit_hook()] and [sqlite3_rollback_hook()]
04142 ** interfaces.
04143 */
04144 SQLITE_API void *sqlite3_update_hook(
04145   sqlite3*, 
04146   void(*)(void *,int ,char const *,char const *,sqlite3_int64),
04147   void*
04148 );
04149 
04150 /*
04151 ** CAPI3REF: Enable Or Disable Shared Pager Cache
04152 ** KEYWORDS: {shared cache}
04153 **
04154 ** ^(This routine enables or disables the sharing of the database cache
04155 ** and schema data structures between [database connection | connections]
04156 ** to the same database. Sharing is enabled if the argument is true
04157 ** and disabled if the argument is false.)^
04158 **
04159 ** ^Cache sharing is enabled and disabled for an entire process.
04160 ** This is a change as of SQLite version 3.5.0. In prior versions of SQLite,
04161 ** sharing was enabled or disabled for each thread separately.
04162 **
04163 ** ^(The cache sharing mode set by this interface effects all subsequent
04164 ** calls to [sqlite3_open()], [sqlite3_open_v2()], and [sqlite3_open16()].
04165 ** Existing database connections continue use the sharing mode
04166 ** that was in effect at the time they were opened.)^
04167 **
04168 ** ^(This routine returns [SQLITE_OK] if shared cache was enabled or disabled
04169 ** successfully.  An [error code] is returned otherwise.)^
04170 **
04171 ** ^Shared cache is disabled by default. But this might change in
04172 ** future releases of SQLite.  Applications that care about shared
04173 ** cache setting should set it explicitly.
04174 **
04175 ** See Also:  [SQLite Shared-Cache Mode]
04176 */
04177 SQLITE_API int sqlite3_enable_shared_cache(int);
04178 
04179 /*
04180 ** CAPI3REF: Attempt To Free Heap Memory
04181 **
04182 ** ^The sqlite3_release_memory() interface attempts to free N bytes
04183 ** of heap memory by deallocating non-essential memory allocations
04184 ** held by the database library.   Memory used to cache database
04185 ** pages to improve performance is an example of non-essential memory.
04186 ** ^sqlite3_release_memory() returns the number of bytes actually freed,
04187 ** which might be more or less than the amount requested.
04188 ** ^The sqlite3_release_memory() routine is a no-op returning zero
04189 ** if SQLite is not compiled with [SQLITE_ENABLE_MEMORY_MANAGEMENT].
04190 */
04191 SQLITE_API int sqlite3_release_memory(int);
04192 
04193 /*
04194 ** CAPI3REF: Impose A Limit On Heap Size
04195 **
04196 ** ^The sqlite3_soft_heap_limit64() interface sets and/or queries the
04197 ** soft limit on the amount of heap memory that may be allocated by SQLite.
04198 ** ^SQLite strives to keep heap memory utilization below the soft heap
04199 ** limit by reducing the number of pages held in the page cache
04200 ** as heap memory usages approaches the limit.
04201 ** ^The soft heap limit is "soft" because even though SQLite strives to stay
04202 ** below the limit, it will exceed the limit rather than generate
04203 ** an [SQLITE_NOMEM] error.  In other words, the soft heap limit 
04204 ** is advisory only.
04205 **
04206 ** ^The return value from sqlite3_soft_heap_limit64() is the size of
04207 ** the soft heap limit prior to the call.  ^If the argument N is negative
04208 ** then no change is made to the soft heap limit.  Hence, the current
04209 ** size of the soft heap limit can be determined by invoking
04210 ** sqlite3_soft_heap_limit64() with a negative argument.
04211 **
04212 ** ^If the argument N is zero then the soft heap limit is disabled.
04213 **
04214 ** ^(The soft heap limit is not enforced in the current implementation
04215 ** if one or more of following conditions are true:
04216 **
04217 ** <ul>
04218 ** <li> The soft heap limit is set to zero.
04219 ** <li> Memory accounting is disabled using a combination of the
04220 **      [sqlite3_config]([SQLITE_CONFIG_MEMSTATUS],...) start-time option and
04221 **      the [SQLITE_DEFAULT_MEMSTATUS] compile-time option.
04222 ** <li> An alternative page cache implementation is specifed using
04223 **      [sqlite3_config]([SQLITE_CONFIG_PCACHE],...).
04224 ** <li> The page cache allocates from its own memory pool supplied
04225 **      by [sqlite3_config]([SQLITE_CONFIG_PAGECACHE],...) rather than
04226 **      from the heap.
04227 ** </ul>)^
04228 **
04229 ** Beginning with SQLite version 3.7.3, the soft heap limit is enforced
04230 ** regardless of whether or not the [SQLITE_ENABLE_MEMORY_MANAGEMENT]
04231 ** compile-time option is invoked.  With [SQLITE_ENABLE_MEMORY_MANAGEMENT],
04232 ** the soft heap limit is enforced on every memory allocation.  Without
04233 ** [SQLITE_ENABLE_MEMORY_MANAGEMENT], the soft heap limit is only enforced
04234 ** when memory is allocated by the page cache.  Testing suggests that because
04235 ** the page cache is the predominate memory user in SQLite, most
04236 ** applications will achieve adequate soft heap limit enforcement without
04237 ** the use of [SQLITE_ENABLE_MEMORY_MANAGEMENT].
04238 **
04239 ** The circumstances under which SQLite will enforce the soft heap limit may
04240 ** changes in future releases of SQLite.
04241 */
04242 SQLITE_API sqlite3_int64 sqlite3_soft_heap_limit64(sqlite3_int64 N);
04243 
04244 /*
04245 ** CAPI3REF: Deprecated Soft Heap Limit Interface
04246 ** DEPRECATED
04247 **
04248 ** This is a deprecated version of the [sqlite3_soft_heap_limit64()]
04249 ** interface.  This routine is provided for historical compatibility
04250 ** only.  All new applications should use the
04251 ** [sqlite3_soft_heap_limit64()] interface rather than this one.
04252 */
04253 SQLITE_API SQLITE_DEPRECATED void sqlite3_soft_heap_limit(int N);
04254 
04255 
04256 /*
04257 ** CAPI3REF: Extract Metadata About A Column Of A Table
04258 **
04259 ** ^This routine returns metadata about a specific column of a specific
04260 ** database table accessible using the [database connection] handle
04261 ** passed as the first function argument.
04262 **
04263 ** ^The column is identified by the second, third and fourth parameters to
04264 ** this function. ^The second parameter is either the name of the database
04265 ** (i.e. "main", "temp", or an attached database) containing the specified
04266 ** table or NULL. ^If it is NULL, then all attached databases are searched
04267 ** for the table using the same algorithm used by the database engine to
04268 ** resolve unqualified table references.
04269 **
04270 ** ^The third and fourth parameters to this function are the table and column
04271 ** name of the desired column, respectively. Neither of these parameters
04272 ** may be NULL.
04273 **
04274 ** ^Metadata is returned by writing to the memory locations passed as the 5th
04275 ** and subsequent parameters to this function. ^Any of these arguments may be
04276 ** NULL, in which case the corresponding element of metadata is omitted.
04277 **
04278 ** ^(<blockquote>
04279 ** <table border="1">
04280 ** <tr><th> Parameter <th> Output<br>Type <th>  Description
04281 **
04282 ** <tr><td> 5th <td> const char* <td> Data type
04283 ** <tr><td> 6th <td> const char* <td> Name of default collation sequence
04284 ** <tr><td> 7th <td> int         <td> True if column has a NOT NULL constraint
04285 ** <tr><td> 8th <td> int         <td> True if column is part of the PRIMARY KEY
04286 ** <tr><td> 9th <td> int         <td> True if column is [AUTOINCREMENT]
04287 ** </table>
04288 ** </blockquote>)^
04289 **
04290 ** ^The memory pointed to by the character pointers returned for the
04291 ** declaration type and collation sequence is valid only until the next
04292 ** call to any SQLite API function.
04293 **
04294 ** ^If the specified table is actually a view, an [error code] is returned.
04295 **
04296 ** ^If the specified column is "rowid", "oid" or "_rowid_" and an
04297 ** [INTEGER PRIMARY KEY] column has been explicitly declared, then the output
04298 ** parameters are set for the explicitly declared column. ^(If there is no
04299 ** explicitly declared [INTEGER PRIMARY KEY] column, then the output
04300 ** parameters are set as follows:
04301 **
04302 ** <pre>
04303 **     data type: "INTEGER"
04304 **     collation sequence: "BINARY"
04305 **     not null: 0
04306 **     primary key: 1
04307 **     auto increment: 0
04308 ** </pre>)^
04309 **
04310 ** ^(This function may load one or more schemas from database files. If an
04311 ** error occurs during this process, or if the requested table or column
04312 ** cannot be found, an [error code] is returned and an error message left
04313 ** in the [database connection] (to be retrieved using sqlite3_errmsg()).)^
04314 **
04315 ** ^This API is only available if the library was compiled with the
04316 ** [SQLITE_ENABLE_COLUMN_METADATA] C-preprocessor symbol defined.
04317 */
04318 SQLITE_API int sqlite3_table_column_metadata(
04319   sqlite3 *db,                /* Connection handle */
04320   const char *zDbName,        /* Database name or NULL */
04321   const char *zTableName,     /* Table name */
04322   const char *zColumnName,    /* Column name */
04323   char const **pzDataType,    /* OUTPUT: Declared data type */
04324   char const **pzCollSeq,     /* OUTPUT: Collation sequence name */
04325   int *pNotNull,              /* OUTPUT: True if NOT NULL constraint exists */
04326   int *pPrimaryKey,           /* OUTPUT: True if column part of PK */
04327   int *pAutoinc               /* OUTPUT: True if column is auto-increment */
04328 );
04329 
04330 /*
04331 ** CAPI3REF: Load An Extension
04332 **
04333 ** ^This interface loads an SQLite extension library from the named file.
04334 **
04335 ** ^The sqlite3_load_extension() interface attempts to load an
04336 ** SQLite extension library contained in the file zFile.
04337 **
04338 ** ^The entry point is zProc.
04339 ** ^zProc may be 0, in which case the name of the entry point
04340 ** defaults to "sqlite3_extension_init".
04341 ** ^The sqlite3_load_extension() interface returns
04342 ** [SQLITE_OK] on success and [SQLITE_ERROR] if something goes wrong.
04343 ** ^If an error occurs and pzErrMsg is not 0, then the
04344 ** [sqlite3_load_extension()] interface shall attempt to
04345 ** fill *pzErrMsg with error message text stored in memory
04346 ** obtained from [sqlite3_malloc()]. The calling function
04347 ** should free this memory by calling [sqlite3_free()].
04348 **
04349 ** ^Extension loading must be enabled using
04350 ** [sqlite3_enable_load_extension()] prior to calling this API,
04351 ** otherwise an error will be returned.
04352 **
04353 ** See also the [load_extension() SQL function].
04354 */
04355 SQLITE_API int sqlite3_load_extension(
04356   sqlite3 *db,          /* Load the extension into this database connection */
04357   const char *zFile,    /* Name of the shared library containing extension */
04358   const char *zProc,    /* Entry point.  Derived from zFile if 0 */
04359   char **pzErrMsg       /* Put error message here if not 0 */
04360 );
04361 
04362 /*
04363 ** CAPI3REF: Enable Or Disable Extension Loading
04364 **
04365 ** ^So as not to open security holes in older applications that are
04366 ** unprepared to deal with extension loading, and as a means of disabling
04367 ** extension loading while evaluating user-entered SQL, the following API
04368 ** is provided to turn the [sqlite3_load_extension()] mechanism on and off.
04369 **
04370 ** ^Extension loading is off by default. See ticket #1863.
04371 ** ^Call the sqlite3_enable_load_extension() routine with onoff==1
04372 ** to turn extension loading on and call it with onoff==0 to turn
04373 ** it back off again.
04374 */
04375 SQLITE_API int sqlite3_enable_load_extension(sqlite3 *db, int onoff);
04376 
04377 /*
04378 ** CAPI3REF: Automatically Load Statically Linked Extensions
04379 **
04380 ** ^This interface causes the xEntryPoint() function to be invoked for
04381 ** each new [database connection] that is created.  The idea here is that
04382 ** xEntryPoint() is the entry point for a statically linked SQLite extension
04383 ** that is to be automatically loaded into all new database connections.
04384 **
04385 ** ^(Even though the function prototype shows that xEntryPoint() takes
04386 ** no arguments and returns void, SQLite invokes xEntryPoint() with three
04387 ** arguments and expects and integer result as if the signature of the
04388 ** entry point where as follows:
04389 **
04390 ** <blockquote><pre>
04391 ** &nbsp;  int xEntryPoint(
04392 ** &nbsp;    sqlite3 *db,
04393 ** &nbsp;    const char **pzErrMsg,
04394 ** &nbsp;    const struct sqlite3_api_routines *pThunk
04395 ** &nbsp;  );
04396 ** </pre></blockquote>)^
04397 **
04398 ** If the xEntryPoint routine encounters an error, it should make *pzErrMsg
04399 ** point to an appropriate error message (obtained from [sqlite3_mprintf()])
04400 ** and return an appropriate [error code].  ^SQLite ensures that *pzErrMsg
04401 ** is NULL before calling the xEntryPoint().  ^SQLite will invoke
04402 ** [sqlite3_free()] on *pzErrMsg after xEntryPoint() returns.  ^If any
04403 ** xEntryPoint() returns an error, the [sqlite3_open()], [sqlite3_open16()],
04404 ** or [sqlite3_open_v2()] call that provoked the xEntryPoint() will fail.
04405 **
04406 ** ^Calling sqlite3_auto_extension(X) with an entry point X that is already
04407 ** on the list of automatic extensions is a harmless no-op. ^No entry point
04408 ** will be called more than once for each database connection that is opened.
04409 **
04410 ** See also: [sqlite3_reset_auto_extension()].
04411 */
04412 SQLITE_API int sqlite3_auto_extension(void (*xEntryPoint)(void));
04413 
04414 /*
04415 ** CAPI3REF: Reset Automatic Extension Loading
04416 **
04417 ** ^This interface disables all automatic extensions previously
04418 ** registered using [sqlite3_auto_extension()].
04419 */
04420 SQLITE_API void sqlite3_reset_auto_extension(void);
04421 
04422 /*
04423 ** The interface to the virtual-table mechanism is currently considered
04424 ** to be experimental.  The interface might change in incompatible ways.
04425 ** If this is a problem for you, do not use the interface at this time.
04426 **
04427 ** When the virtual-table mechanism stabilizes, we will declare the
04428 ** interface fixed, support it indefinitely, and remove this comment.
04429 */
04430 
04431 /*
04432 ** Structures used by the virtual table interface
04433 */
04434 typedef struct sqlite3_vtab sqlite3_vtab;
04435 typedef struct sqlite3_index_info sqlite3_index_info;
04436 typedef struct sqlite3_vtab_cursor sqlite3_vtab_cursor;
04437 typedef struct sqlite3_module sqlite3_module;
04438 
04439 /*
04440 ** CAPI3REF: Virtual Table Object
04441 ** KEYWORDS: sqlite3_module {virtual table module}
04442 **
04443 ** This structure, sometimes called a a "virtual table module", 
04444 ** defines the implementation of a [virtual tables].  
04445 ** This structure consists mostly of methods for the module.
04446 **
04447 ** ^A virtual table module is created by filling in a persistent
04448 ** instance of this structure and passing a pointer to that instance
04449 ** to [sqlite3_create_module()] or [sqlite3_create_module_v2()].
04450 ** ^The registration remains valid until it is replaced by a different
04451 ** module or until the [database connection] closes.  The content
04452 ** of this structure must not change while it is registered with
04453 ** any database connection.
04454 */
04455 struct sqlite3_module {
04456   int iVersion;
04457   int (*xCreate)(sqlite3*, void *pAux,
04458                int argc, const char *const*argv,
04459                sqlite3_vtab **ppVTab, char**);
04460   int (*xConnect)(sqlite3*, void *pAux,
04461                int argc, const char *const*argv,
04462                sqlite3_vtab **ppVTab, char**);
04463   int (*xBestIndex)(sqlite3_vtab *pVTab, sqlite3_index_info*);
04464   int (*xDisconnect)(sqlite3_vtab *pVTab);
04465   int (*xDestroy)(sqlite3_vtab *pVTab);
04466   int (*xOpen)(sqlite3_vtab *pVTab, sqlite3_vtab_cursor **ppCursor);
04467   int (*xClose)(sqlite3_vtab_cursor*);
04468   int (*xFilter)(sqlite3_vtab_cursor*, int idxNum, const char *idxStr,
04469                 int argc, sqlite3_value **argv);
04470   int (*xNext)(sqlite3_vtab_cursor*);
04471   int (*xEof)(sqlite3_vtab_cursor*);
04472   int (*xColumn)(sqlite3_vtab_cursor*, sqlite3_context*, int);
04473   int (*xRowid)(sqlite3_vtab_cursor*, sqlite3_int64 *pRowid);
04474   int (*xUpdate)(sqlite3_vtab *, int, sqlite3_value **, sqlite3_int64 *);
04475   int (*xBegin)(sqlite3_vtab *pVTab);
04476   int (*xSync)(sqlite3_vtab *pVTab);
04477   int (*xCommit)(sqlite3_vtab *pVTab);
04478   int (*xRollback)(sqlite3_vtab *pVTab);
04479   int (*xFindFunction)(sqlite3_vtab *pVtab, int nArg, const char *zName,
04480                        void (**pxFunc)(sqlite3_context*,int,sqlite3_value**),
04481                        void **ppArg);
04482   int (*xRename)(sqlite3_vtab *pVtab, const char *zNew);
04483 };
04484 
04485 /*
04486 ** CAPI3REF: Virtual Table Indexing Information
04487 ** KEYWORDS: sqlite3_index_info
04488 **
04489 ** The sqlite3_index_info structure and its substructures is used as part
04490 ** of the [virtual table] interface to
04491 ** pass information into and receive the reply from the [xBestIndex]
04492 ** method of a [virtual table module].  The fields under **Inputs** are the
04493 ** inputs to xBestIndex and are read-only.  xBestIndex inserts its
04494 ** results into the **Outputs** fields.
04495 **
04496 ** ^(The aConstraint[] array records WHERE clause constraints of the form:
04497 **
04498 ** <blockquote>column OP expr</blockquote>
04499 **
04500 ** where OP is =, &lt;, &lt;=, &gt;, or &gt;=.)^  ^(The particular operator is
04501 ** stored in aConstraint[].op using one of the
04502 ** [SQLITE_INDEX_CONSTRAINT_EQ | SQLITE_INDEX_CONSTRAINT_ values].)^
04503 ** ^(The index of the column is stored in
04504 ** aConstraint[].iColumn.)^  ^(aConstraint[].usable is TRUE if the
