04505 ** expr on the right-hand side can be evaluated (and thus the constraint
04506 ** is usable) and false if it cannot.)^
04507 **
04508 ** ^The optimizer automatically inverts terms of the form "expr OP column"
04509 ** and makes other simplifications to the WHERE clause in an attempt to
04510 ** get as many WHERE clause terms into the form shown above as possible.
04511 ** ^The aConstraint[] array only reports WHERE clause terms that are
04512 ** relevant to the particular virtual table being queried.
04513 **
04514 ** ^Information about the ORDER BY clause is stored in aOrderBy[].
04515 ** ^Each term of aOrderBy records a column of the ORDER BY clause.
04516 **
04517 ** The [xBestIndex] method must fill aConstraintUsage[] with information
04518 ** about what parameters to pass to xFilter.  ^If argvIndex>0 then
04519 ** the right-hand side of the corresponding aConstraint[] is evaluated
04520 ** and becomes the argvIndex-th entry in argv.  ^(If aConstraintUsage[].omit
04521 ** is true, then the constraint is assumed to be fully handled by the
04522 ** virtual table and is not checked again by SQLite.)^
04523 **
04524 ** ^The idxNum and idxPtr values are recorded and passed into the
04525 ** [xFilter] method.
04526 ** ^[sqlite3_free()] is used to free idxPtr if and only if
04527 ** needToFreeIdxPtr is true.
04528 **
04529 ** ^The orderByConsumed means that output from [xFilter]/[xNext] will occur in
04530 ** the correct order to satisfy the ORDER BY clause so that no separate
04531 ** sorting step is required.
04532 **
04533 ** ^The estimatedCost value is an estimate of the cost of doing the
04534 ** particular lookup.  A full scan of a table with N entries should have
04535 ** a cost of N.  A binary search of a table of N entries should have a
04536 ** cost of approximately log(N).
04537 */
04538 struct sqlite3_index_info {
04539   /* Inputs */
04540   int nConstraint;           /* Number of entries in aConstraint */
04541   struct sqlite3_index_constraint {
04542      int iColumn;              /* Column on left-hand side of constraint */
04543      unsigned char op;         /* Constraint operator */
04544      unsigned char usable;     /* True if this constraint is usable */
04545      int iTermOffset;          /* Used internally - xBestIndex should ignore */
04546   } *aConstraint;            /* Table of WHERE clause constraints */
04547   int nOrderBy;              /* Number of terms in the ORDER BY clause */
04548   struct sqlite3_index_orderby {
04549      int iColumn;              /* Column number */
04550      unsigned char desc;       /* True for DESC.  False for ASC. */
04551   } *aOrderBy;               /* The ORDER BY clause */
04552   /* Outputs */
04553   struct sqlite3_index_constraint_usage {
04554     int argvIndex;           /* if >0, constraint is part of argv to xFilter */
04555     unsigned char omit;      /* Do not code a test for this constraint */
04556   } *aConstraintUsage;
04557   int idxNum;                /* Number used to identify the index */
04558   char *idxStr;              /* String, possibly obtained from sqlite3_malloc */
04559   int needToFreeIdxStr;      /* Free idxStr using sqlite3_free() if true */
04560   int orderByConsumed;       /* True if output is already ordered */
04561   double estimatedCost;      /* Estimated cost of using this index */
04562 };
04563 
04564 /*
04565 ** CAPI3REF: Virtual Table Constraint Operator Codes
04566 **
04567 ** These macros defined the allowed values for the
04568 ** [sqlite3_index_info].aConstraint[].op field.  Each value represents
04569 ** an operator that is part of a constraint term in the wHERE clause of
04570 ** a query that uses a [virtual table].
04571 */
04572 #define SQLITE_INDEX_CONSTRAINT_EQ    2
04573 #define SQLITE_INDEX_CONSTRAINT_GT    4
04574 #define SQLITE_INDEX_CONSTRAINT_LE    8
04575 #define SQLITE_INDEX_CONSTRAINT_LT    16
04576 #define SQLITE_INDEX_CONSTRAINT_GE    32
04577 #define SQLITE_INDEX_CONSTRAINT_MATCH 64
04578 
04579 /*
04580 ** CAPI3REF: Register A Virtual Table Implementation
04581 **
04582 ** ^These routines are used to register a new [virtual table module] name.
04583 ** ^Module names must be registered before
04584 ** creating a new [virtual table] using the module and before using a
04585 ** preexisting [virtual table] for the module.
04586 **
04587 ** ^The module name is registered on the [database connection] specified
04588 ** by the first parameter.  ^The name of the module is given by the 
04589 ** second parameter.  ^The third parameter is a pointer to
04590 ** the implementation of the [virtual table module].   ^The fourth
04591 ** parameter is an arbitrary client data pointer that is passed through
04592 ** into the [xCreate] and [xConnect] methods of the virtual table module
04593 ** when a new virtual table is be being created or reinitialized.
04594 **
04595 ** ^The sqlite3_create_module_v2() interface has a fifth parameter which
04596 ** is a pointer to a destructor for the pClientData.  ^SQLite will
04597 ** invoke the destructor function (if it is not NULL) when SQLite
04598 ** no longer needs the pClientData pointer.  ^The sqlite3_create_module()
04599 ** interface is equivalent to sqlite3_create_module_v2() with a NULL
04600 ** destructor.
04601 */
04602 SQLITE_API int sqlite3_create_module(
04603   sqlite3 *db,               /* SQLite connection to register module with */
04604   const char *zName,         /* Name of the module */
04605   const sqlite3_module *p,   /* Methods for the module */
04606   void *pClientData          /* Client data for xCreate/xConnect */
04607 );
04608 SQLITE_API int sqlite3_create_module_v2(
04609   sqlite3 *db,               /* SQLite connection to register module with */
04610   const char *zName,         /* Name of the module */
04611   const sqlite3_module *p,   /* Methods for the module */
04612   void *pClientData,         /* Client data for xCreate/xConnect */
04613   void(*xDestroy)(void*)     /* Module destructor function */
04614 );
04615 
04616 /*
04617 ** CAPI3REF: Virtual Table Instance Object
04618 ** KEYWORDS: sqlite3_vtab
04619 **
04620 ** Every [virtual table module] implementation uses a subclass
04621 ** of this object to describe a particular instance
04622 ** of the [virtual table].  Each subclass will
04623 ** be tailored to the specific needs of the module implementation.
04624 ** The purpose of this superclass is to define certain fields that are
04625 ** common to all module implementations.
04626 **
04627 ** ^Virtual tables methods can set an error message by assigning a
04628 ** string obtained from [sqlite3_mprintf()] to zErrMsg.  The method should
04629 ** take care that any prior string is freed by a call to [sqlite3_free()]
04630 ** prior to assigning a new string to zErrMsg.  ^After the error message
04631 ** is delivered up to the client application, the string will be automatically
04632 ** freed by sqlite3_free() and the zErrMsg field will be zeroed.
04633 */
04634 struct sqlite3_vtab {
04635   const sqlite3_module *pModule;  /* The module for this virtual table */
04636   int nRef;                       /* NO LONGER USED */
04637   char *zErrMsg;                  /* Error message from sqlite3_mprintf() */
04638   /* Virtual table implementations will typically add additional fields */
04639 };
04640 
04641 /*
04642 ** CAPI3REF: Virtual Table Cursor Object
04643 ** KEYWORDS: sqlite3_vtab_cursor {virtual table cursor}
04644 **
04645 ** Every [virtual table module] implementation uses a subclass of the
04646 ** following structure to describe cursors that point into the
04647 ** [virtual table] and are used
04648 ** to loop through the virtual table.  Cursors are created using the
04649 ** [sqlite3_module.xOpen | xOpen] method of the module and are destroyed
04650 ** by the [sqlite3_module.xClose | xClose] method.  Cursors are used
04651 ** by the [xFilter], [xNext], [xEof], [xColumn], and [xRowid] methods
04652 ** of the module.  Each module implementation will define
04653 ** the content of a cursor structure to suit its own needs.
04654 **
04655 ** This superclass exists in order to define fields of the cursor that
04656 ** are common to all implementations.
04657 */
04658 struct sqlite3_vtab_cursor {
04659   sqlite3_vtab *pVtab;      /* Virtual table of this cursor */
04660   /* Virtual table implementations will typically add additional fields */
04661 };
04662 
04663 /*
04664 ** CAPI3REF: Declare The Schema Of A Virtual Table
04665 **
04666 ** ^The [xCreate] and [xConnect] methods of a
04667 ** [virtual table module] call this interface
04668 ** to declare the format (the names and datatypes of the columns) of
04669 ** the virtual tables they implement.
04670 */
04671 SQLITE_API int sqlite3_declare_vtab(sqlite3*, const char *zSQL);
04672 
04673 /*
04674 ** CAPI3REF: Overload A Function For A Virtual Table
04675 **
04676 ** ^(Virtual tables can provide alternative implementations of functions
04677 ** using the [xFindFunction] method of the [virtual table module].  
04678 ** But global versions of those functions
04679 ** must exist in order to be overloaded.)^
04680 **
04681 ** ^(This API makes sure a global version of a function with a particular
04682 ** name and number of parameters exists.  If no such function exists
04683 ** before this API is called, a new function is created.)^  ^The implementation
04684 ** of the new function always causes an exception to be thrown.  So
04685 ** the new function is not good for anything by itself.  Its only
04686 ** purpose is to be a placeholder function that can be overloaded
04687 ** by a [virtual table].
04688 */
04689 SQLITE_API int sqlite3_overload_function(sqlite3*, const char *zFuncName, int nArg);
04690 
04691 /*
04692 ** The interface to the virtual-table mechanism defined above (back up
04693 ** to a comment remarkably similar to this one) is currently considered
04694 ** to be experimental.  The interface might change in incompatible ways.
04695 ** If this is a problem for you, do not use the interface at this time.
04696 **
04697 ** When the virtual-table mechanism stabilizes, we will declare the
04698 ** interface fixed, support it indefinitely, and remove this comment.
04699 */
04700 
04701 /*
04702 ** CAPI3REF: A Handle To An Open BLOB
04703 ** KEYWORDS: {BLOB handle} {BLOB handles}
04704 **
04705 ** An instance of this object represents an open BLOB on which
04706 ** [sqlite3_blob_open | incremental BLOB I/O] can be performed.
04707 ** ^Objects of this type are created by [sqlite3_blob_open()]
04708 ** and destroyed by [sqlite3_blob_close()].
04709 ** ^The [sqlite3_blob_read()] and [sqlite3_blob_write()] interfaces
04710 ** can be used to read or write small subsections of the BLOB.
04711 ** ^The [sqlite3_blob_bytes()] interface returns the size of the BLOB in bytes.
04712 */
04713 typedef struct sqlite3_blob sqlite3_blob;
04714 
04715 /*
04716 ** CAPI3REF: Open A BLOB For Incremental I/O
04717 **
04718 ** ^(This interfaces opens a [BLOB handle | handle] to the BLOB located
04719 ** in row iRow, column zColumn, table zTable in database zDb;
04720 ** in other words, the same BLOB that would be selected by:
04721 **
04722 ** <pre>
04723 **     SELECT zColumn FROM zDb.zTable WHERE [rowid] = iRow;
04724 ** </pre>)^
04725 **
04726 ** ^If the flags parameter is non-zero, then the BLOB is opened for read
04727 ** and write access. ^If it is zero, the BLOB is opened for read access.
04728 ** ^It is not possible to open a column that is part of an index or primary 
04729 ** key for writing. ^If [foreign key constraints] are enabled, it is 
04730 ** not possible to open a column that is part of a [child key] for writing.
04731 **
04732 ** ^Note that the database name is not the filename that contains
04733 ** the database but rather the symbolic name of the database that
04734 ** appears after the AS keyword when the database is connected using [ATTACH].
04735 ** ^For the main database file, the database name is "main".
04736 ** ^For TEMP tables, the database name is "temp".
04737 **
04738 ** ^(On success, [SQLITE_OK] is returned and the new [BLOB handle] is written
04739 ** to *ppBlob. Otherwise an [error code] is returned and *ppBlob is set
04740 ** to be a null pointer.)^
04741 ** ^This function sets the [database connection] error code and message
04742 ** accessible via [sqlite3_errcode()] and [sqlite3_errmsg()] and related
04743 ** functions. ^Note that the *ppBlob variable is always initialized in a
04744 ** way that makes it safe to invoke [sqlite3_blob_close()] on *ppBlob
04745 ** regardless of the success or failure of this routine.
04746 **
04747 ** ^(If the row that a BLOB handle points to is modified by an
04748 ** [UPDATE], [DELETE], or by [ON CONFLICT] side-effects
04749 ** then the BLOB handle is marked as "expired".
04750 ** This is true if any column of the row is changed, even a column
04751 ** other than the one the BLOB handle is open on.)^
04752 ** ^Calls to [sqlite3_blob_read()] and [sqlite3_blob_write()] for
04753 ** a expired BLOB handle fail with an return code of [SQLITE_ABORT].
04754 ** ^(Changes written into a BLOB prior to the BLOB expiring are not
04755 ** rolled back by the expiration of the BLOB.  Such changes will eventually
04756 ** commit if the transaction continues to completion.)^
04757 **
04758 ** ^Use the [sqlite3_blob_bytes()] interface to determine the size of
04759 ** the opened blob.  ^The size of a blob may not be changed by this
04760 ** interface.  Use the [UPDATE] SQL command to change the size of a
04761 ** blob.
04762 **
04763 ** ^The [sqlite3_bind_zeroblob()] and [sqlite3_result_zeroblob()] interfaces
04764 ** and the built-in [zeroblob] SQL function can be used, if desired,
04765 ** to create an empty, zero-filled blob in which to read or write using
04766 ** this interface.
04767 **
04768 ** To avoid a resource leak, every open [BLOB handle] should eventually
04769 ** be released by a call to [sqlite3_blob_close()].
04770 */
04771 SQLITE_API int sqlite3_blob_open(
04772   sqlite3*,
04773   const char *zDb,
04774   const char *zTable,
04775   const char *zColumn,
04776   sqlite3_int64 iRow,
04777   int flags,
04778   sqlite3_blob **ppBlob
04779 );
04780 
04781 /*
04782 ** CAPI3REF: Close A BLOB Handle
04783 **
04784 ** ^Closes an open [BLOB handle].
04785 **
04786 ** ^Closing a BLOB shall cause the current transaction to commit
04787 ** if there are no other BLOBs, no pending prepared statements, and the
04788 ** database connection is in [autocommit mode].
04789 ** ^If any writes were made to the BLOB, they might be held in cache
04790 ** until the close operation if they will fit.
04791 **
04792 ** ^(Closing the BLOB often forces the changes
04793 ** out to disk and so if any I/O errors occur, they will likely occur
04794 ** at the time when the BLOB is closed.  Any errors that occur during
04795 ** closing are reported as a non-zero return value.)^
04796 **
04797 ** ^(The BLOB is closed unconditionally.  Even if this routine returns
04798 ** an error code, the BLOB is still closed.)^
04799 **
04800 ** ^Calling this routine with a null pointer (such as would be returned
04801 ** by a failed call to [sqlite3_blob_open()]) is a harmless no-op.
04802 */
04803 SQLITE_API int sqlite3_blob_close(sqlite3_blob *);
04804 
04805 /*
04806 ** CAPI3REF: Return The Size Of An Open BLOB
04807 **
04808 ** ^Returns the size in bytes of the BLOB accessible via the 
04809 ** successfully opened [BLOB handle] in its only argument.  ^The
04810 ** incremental blob I/O routines can only read or overwriting existing
04811 ** blob content; they cannot change the size of a blob.
04812 **
04813 ** This routine only works on a [BLOB handle] which has been created
04814 ** by a prior successful call to [sqlite3_blob_open()] and which has not
04815 ** been closed by [sqlite3_blob_close()].  Passing any other pointer in
04816 ** to this routine results in undefined and probably undesirable behavior.
04817 */
04818 SQLITE_API int sqlite3_blob_bytes(sqlite3_blob *);
04819 
04820 /*
04821 ** CAPI3REF: Read Data From A BLOB Incrementally
04822 **
04823 ** ^(This function is used to read data from an open [BLOB handle] into a
04824 ** caller-supplied buffer. N bytes of data are copied into buffer Z
04825 ** from the open BLOB, starting at offset iOffset.)^
04826 **
04827 ** ^If offset iOffset is less than N bytes from the end of the BLOB,
04828 ** [SQLITE_ERROR] is returned and no data is read.  ^If N or iOffset is
04829 ** less than zero, [SQLITE_ERROR] is returned and no data is read.
04830 ** ^The size of the blob (and hence the maximum value of N+iOffset)
04831 ** can be determined using the [sqlite3_blob_bytes()] interface.
04832 **
04833 ** ^An attempt to read from an expired [BLOB handle] fails with an
04834 ** error code of [SQLITE_ABORT].
04835 **
04836 ** ^(On success, sqlite3_blob_read() returns SQLITE_OK.
04837 ** Otherwise, an [error code] or an [extended error code] is returned.)^
04838 **
04839 ** This routine only works on a [BLOB handle] which has been created
04840 ** by a prior successful call to [sqlite3_blob_open()] and which has not
04841 ** been closed by [sqlite3_blob_close()].  Passing any other pointer in
04842 ** to this routine results in undefined and probably undesirable behavior.
04843 **
04844 ** See also: [sqlite3_blob_write()].
04845 */
04846 SQLITE_API int sqlite3_blob_read(sqlite3_blob *, void *Z, int N, int iOffset);
04847 
04848 /*
04849 ** CAPI3REF: Write Data Into A BLOB Incrementally
04850 **
04851 ** ^This function is used to write data into an open [BLOB handle] from a
04852 ** caller-supplied buffer. ^N bytes of data are copied from the buffer Z
04853 ** into the open BLOB, starting at offset iOffset.
04854 **
04855 ** ^If the [BLOB handle] passed as the first argument was not opened for
04856 ** writing (the flags parameter to [sqlite3_blob_open()] was zero),
04857 ** this function returns [SQLITE_READONLY].
04858 **
04859 ** ^This function may only modify the contents of the BLOB; it is
04860 ** not possible to increase the size of a BLOB using this API.
04861 ** ^If offset iOffset is less than N bytes from the end of the BLOB,
04862 ** [SQLITE_ERROR] is returned and no data is written.  ^If N is
04863 ** less than zero [SQLITE_ERROR] is returned and no data is written.
04864 ** The size of the BLOB (and hence the maximum value of N+iOffset)
04865 ** can be determined using the [sqlite3_blob_bytes()] interface.
04866 **
04867 ** ^An attempt to write to an expired [BLOB handle] fails with an
04868 ** error code of [SQLITE_ABORT].  ^Writes to the BLOB that occurred
04869 ** before the [BLOB handle] expired are not rolled back by the
04870 ** expiration of the handle, though of course those changes might
04871 ** have been overwritten by the statement that expired the BLOB handle
04872 ** or by other independent statements.
04873 **
04874 ** ^(On success, sqlite3_blob_write() returns SQLITE_OK.
04875 ** Otherwise, an  [error code] or an [extended error code] is returned.)^
04876 **
04877 ** This routine only works on a [BLOB handle] which has been created
04878 ** by a prior successful call to [sqlite3_blob_open()] and which has not
04879 ** been closed by [sqlite3_blob_close()].  Passing any other pointer in
04880 ** to this routine results in undefined and probably undesirable behavior.
04881 **
04882 ** See also: [sqlite3_blob_read()].
04883 */
04884 SQLITE_API int sqlite3_blob_write(sqlite3_blob *, const void *z, int n, int iOffset);
04885 
04886 /*
04887 ** CAPI3REF: Virtual File System Objects
04888 **
04889 ** A virtual filesystem (VFS) is an [sqlite3_vfs] object
04890 ** that SQLite uses to interact
04891 ** with the underlying operating system.  Most SQLite builds come with a
04892 ** single default VFS that is appropriate for the host computer.
04893 ** New VFSes can be registered and existing VFSes can be unregistered.
04894 ** The following interfaces are provided.
04895 **
04896 ** ^The sqlite3_vfs_find() interface returns a pointer to a VFS given its name.
04897 ** ^Names are case sensitive.
04898 ** ^Names are zero-terminated UTF-8 strings.
04899 ** ^If there is no match, a NULL pointer is returned.
04900 ** ^If zVfsName is NULL then the default VFS is returned.
04901 **
04902 ** ^New VFSes are registered with sqlite3_vfs_register().
04903 ** ^Each new VFS becomes the default VFS if the makeDflt flag is set.
04904 ** ^The same VFS can be registered multiple times without injury.
04905 ** ^To make an existing VFS into the default VFS, register it again
04906 ** with the makeDflt flag set.  If two different VFSes with the
04907 ** same name are registered, the behavior is undefined.  If a
04908 ** VFS is registered with a name that is NULL or an empty string,
04909 ** then the behavior is undefined.
04910 **
04911 ** ^Unregister a VFS with the sqlite3_vfs_unregister() interface.
04912 ** ^(If the default VFS is unregistered, another VFS is chosen as
04913 ** the default.  The choice for the new VFS is arbitrary.)^
04914 */
04915 SQLITE_API sqlite3_vfs *sqlite3_vfs_find(const char *zVfsName);
04916 SQLITE_API int sqlite3_vfs_register(sqlite3_vfs*, int makeDflt);
04917 SQLITE_API int sqlite3_vfs_unregister(sqlite3_vfs*);
04918 
04919 /*
04920 ** CAPI3REF: Mutexes
04921 **
04922 ** The SQLite core uses these routines for thread
04923 ** synchronization. Though they are intended for internal
04924 ** use by SQLite, code that links against SQLite is
04925 ** permitted to use any of these routines.
04926 **
04927 ** The SQLite source code contains multiple implementations
04928 ** of these mutex routines.  An appropriate implementation
04929 ** is selected automatically at compile-time.  ^(The following
04930 ** implementations are available in the SQLite core:
04931 **
04932 ** <ul>
04933 ** <li>   SQLITE_MUTEX_OS2
04934 ** <li>   SQLITE_MUTEX_PTHREAD
04935 ** <li>   SQLITE_MUTEX_W32
04936 ** <li>   SQLITE_MUTEX_NOOP
04937 ** </ul>)^
04938 **
04939 ** ^The SQLITE_MUTEX_NOOP implementation is a set of routines
04940 ** that does no real locking and is appropriate for use in
04941 ** a single-threaded application.  ^The SQLITE_MUTEX_OS2,
04942 ** SQLITE_MUTEX_PTHREAD, and SQLITE_MUTEX_W32 implementations
04943 ** are appropriate for use on OS/2, Unix, and Windows.
04944 **
04945 ** ^(If SQLite is compiled with the SQLITE_MUTEX_APPDEF preprocessor
04946 ** macro defined (with "-DSQLITE_MUTEX_APPDEF=1"), then no mutex
04947 ** implementation is included with the library. In this case the
04948 ** application must supply a custom mutex implementation using the
04949 ** [SQLITE_CONFIG_MUTEX] option of the sqlite3_config() function
04950 ** before calling sqlite3_initialize() or any other public sqlite3_
04951 ** function that calls sqlite3_initialize().)^
04952 **
04953 ** ^The sqlite3_mutex_alloc() routine allocates a new
04954 ** mutex and returns a pointer to it. ^If it returns NULL
04955 ** that means that a mutex could not be allocated.  ^SQLite
04956 ** will unwind its stack and return an error.  ^(The argument
04957 ** to sqlite3_mutex_alloc() is one of these integer constants:
04958 **
04959 ** <ul>
04960 ** <li>  SQLITE_MUTEX_FAST
04961 ** <li>  SQLITE_MUTEX_RECURSIVE
04962 ** <li>  SQLITE_MUTEX_STATIC_MASTER
04963 ** <li>  SQLITE_MUTEX_STATIC_MEM
04964 ** <li>  SQLITE_MUTEX_STATIC_MEM2
04965 ** <li>  SQLITE_MUTEX_STATIC_PRNG
04966 ** <li>  SQLITE_MUTEX_STATIC_LRU
04967 ** <li>  SQLITE_MUTEX_STATIC_LRU2
04968 ** </ul>)^
04969 **
04970 ** ^The first two constants (SQLITE_MUTEX_FAST and SQLITE_MUTEX_RECURSIVE)
04971 ** cause sqlite3_mutex_alloc() to create
04972 ** a new mutex.  ^The new mutex is recursive when SQLITE_MUTEX_RECURSIVE
04973 ** is used but not necessarily so when SQLITE_MUTEX_FAST is used.
04974 ** The mutex implementation does not need to make a distinction
04975 ** between SQLITE_MUTEX_RECURSIVE and SQLITE_MUTEX_FAST if it does
04976 ** not want to.  ^SQLite will only request a recursive mutex in
04977 ** cases where it really needs one.  ^If a faster non-recursive mutex
04978 ** implementation is available on the host platform, the mutex subsystem
04979 ** might return such a mutex in response to SQLITE_MUTEX_FAST.
04980 **
04981 ** ^The other allowed parameters to sqlite3_mutex_alloc() (anything other
04982 ** than SQLITE_MUTEX_FAST and SQLITE_MUTEX_RECURSIVE) each return
04983 ** a pointer to a static preexisting mutex.  ^Six static mutexes are
04984 ** used by the current version of SQLite.  Future versions of SQLite
04985 ** may add additional static mutexes.  Static mutexes are for internal
04986 ** use by SQLite only.  Applications that use SQLite mutexes should
04987 ** use only the dynamic mutexes returned by SQLITE_MUTEX_FAST or
04988 ** SQLITE_MUTEX_RECURSIVE.
04989 **
04990 ** ^Note that if one of the dynamic mutex parameters (SQLITE_MUTEX_FAST
04991 ** or SQLITE_MUTEX_RECURSIVE) is used then sqlite3_mutex_alloc()
04992 ** returns a different mutex on every call.  ^But for the static
04993 ** mutex types, the same mutex is returned on every call that has
04994 ** the same type number.
04995 **
04996 ** ^The sqlite3_mutex_free() routine deallocates a previously
04997 ** allocated dynamic mutex.  ^SQLite is careful to deallocate every
04998 ** dynamic mutex that it allocates.  The dynamic mutexes must not be in
04999 ** use when they are deallocated.  Attempting to deallocate a static
05000 ** mutex results in undefined behavior.  ^SQLite never deallocates
05001 ** a static mutex.
05002 **
05003 ** ^The sqlite3_mutex_enter() and sqlite3_mutex_try() routines attempt
05004 ** to enter a mutex.  ^If another thread is already within the mutex,
05005 ** sqlite3_mutex_enter() will block and sqlite3_mutex_try() will return
05006 ** SQLITE_BUSY.  ^The sqlite3_mutex_try() interface returns [SQLITE_OK]
05007 ** upon successful entry.  ^(Mutexes created using
05008 ** SQLITE_MUTEX_RECURSIVE can be entered multiple times by the same thread.
05009 ** In such cases the,
05010 ** mutex must be exited an equal number of times before another thread
05011 ** can enter.)^  ^(If the same thread tries to enter any other
05012 ** kind of mutex more than once, the behavior is undefined.
05013 ** SQLite will never exhibit
05014 ** such behavior in its own use of mutexes.)^
05015 **
05016 ** ^(Some systems (for example, Windows 95) do not support the operation
05017 ** implemented by sqlite3_mutex_try().  On those systems, sqlite3_mutex_try()
05018 ** will always return SQLITE_BUSY.  The SQLite core only ever uses
05019 ** sqlite3_mutex_try() as an optimization so this is acceptable behavior.)^
05020 **
05021 ** ^The sqlite3_mutex_leave() routine exits a mutex that was
05022 ** previously entered by the same thread.   ^(The behavior
05023 ** is undefined if the mutex is not currently entered by the
05024 ** calling thread or is not currently allocated.  SQLite will
05025 ** never do either.)^
05026 **
05027 ** ^If the argument to sqlite3_mutex_enter(), sqlite3_mutex_try(), or
05028 ** sqlite3_mutex_leave() is a NULL pointer, then all three routines
05029 ** behave as no-ops.
05030 **
05031 ** See also: [sqlite3_mutex_held()] and [sqlite3_mutex_notheld()].
05032 */
05033 SQLITE_API sqlite3_mutex *sqlite3_mutex_alloc(int);
05034 SQLITE_API void sqlite3_mutex_free(sqlite3_mutex*);
05035 SQLITE_API void sqlite3_mutex_enter(sqlite3_mutex*);
05036 SQLITE_API int sqlite3_mutex_try(sqlite3_mutex*);
05037 SQLITE_API void sqlite3_mutex_leave(sqlite3_mutex*);
05038 
05039 /*
05040 ** CAPI3REF: Mutex Methods Object
05041 **
05042 ** An instance of this structure defines the low-level routines
05043 ** used to allocate and use mutexes.
05044 **
05045 ** Usually, the default mutex implementations provided by SQLite are
05046 ** sufficient, however the user has the option of substituting a custom
05047 ** implementation for specialized deployments or systems for which SQLite
05048 ** does not provide a suitable implementation. In this case, the user
05049 ** creates and populates an instance of this structure to pass
05050 ** to sqlite3_config() along with the [SQLITE_CONFIG_MUTEX] option.
05051 ** Additionally, an instance of this structure can be used as an
05052 ** output variable when querying the system for the current mutex
05053 ** implementation, using the [SQLITE_CONFIG_GETMUTEX] option.
05054 **
05055 ** ^The xMutexInit method defined by this structure is invoked as
05056 ** part of system initialization by the sqlite3_initialize() function.
05057 ** ^The xMutexInit routine is called by SQLite exactly once for each
05058 ** effective call to [sqlite3_initialize()].
05059 **
05060 ** ^The xMutexEnd method defined by this structure is invoked as
05061 ** part of system shutdown by the sqlite3_shutdown() function. The
05062 ** implementation of this method is expected to release all outstanding
05063 ** resources obtained by the mutex methods implementation, especially
05064 ** those obtained by the xMutexInit method.  ^The xMutexEnd()
05065 ** interface is invoked exactly once for each call to [sqlite3_shutdown()].
05066 **
05067 ** ^(The remaining seven methods defined by this structure (xMutexAlloc,
05068 ** xMutexFree, xMutexEnter, xMutexTry, xMutexLeave, xMutexHeld and
05069 ** xMutexNotheld) implement the following interfaces (respectively):
05070 **
05071 ** <ul>
05072 **   <li>  [sqlite3_mutex_alloc()] </li>
05073 **   <li>  [sqlite3_mutex_free()] </li>
05074 **   <li>  [sqlite3_mutex_enter()] </li>
05075 **   <li>  [sqlite3_mutex_try()] </li>
05076 **   <li>  [sqlite3_mutex_leave()] </li>
05077 **   <li>  [sqlite3_mutex_held()] </li>
05078 **   <li>  [sqlite3_mutex_notheld()] </li>
05079 ** </ul>)^
05080 **
05081 ** The only difference is that the public sqlite3_XXX functions enumerated
05082 ** above silently ignore any invocations that pass a NULL pointer instead
05083 ** of a valid mutex handle. The implementations of the methods defined
05084 ** by this structure are not required to handle this case, the results
05085 ** of passing a NULL pointer instead of a valid mutex handle are undefined
05086 ** (i.e. it is acceptable to provide an implementation that segfaults if
05087 ** it is passed a NULL pointer).
05088 **
05089 ** The xMutexInit() method must be threadsafe.  ^It must be harmless to
05090 ** invoke xMutexInit() multiple times within the same process and without
05091 ** intervening calls to xMutexEnd().  Second and subsequent calls to
05092 ** xMutexInit() must be no-ops.
05093 **
05094 ** ^xMutexInit() must not use SQLite memory allocation ([sqlite3_malloc()]
05095 ** and its associates).  ^Similarly, xMutexAlloc() must not use SQLite memory
05096 ** allocation for a static mutex.  ^However xMutexAlloc() may use SQLite
05097 ** memory allocation for a fast or recursive mutex.
05098 **
05099 ** ^SQLite will invoke the xMutexEnd() method when [sqlite3_shutdown()] is
05100 ** called, but only if the prior call to xMutexInit returned SQLITE_OK.
05101 ** If xMutexInit fails in any way, it is expected to clean up after itself
05102 ** prior to returning.
05103 */
05104 typedef struct sqlite3_mutex_methods sqlite3_mutex_methods;
05105 struct sqlite3_mutex_methods {
05106   int (*xMutexInit)(void);
05107   int (*xMutexEnd)(void);
05108   sqlite3_mutex *(*xMutexAlloc)(int);
05109   void (*xMutexFree)(sqlite3_mutex *);
05110   void (*xMutexEnter)(sqlite3_mutex *);
05111   int (*xMutexTry)(sqlite3_mutex *);
05112   void (*xMutexLeave)(sqlite3_mutex *);
05113   int (*xMutexHeld)(sqlite3_mutex *);
05114   int (*xMutexNotheld)(sqlite3_mutex *);
05115 };
05116 
05117 /*
05118 ** CAPI3REF: Mutex Verification Routines
05119 **
05120 ** The sqlite3_mutex_held() and sqlite3_mutex_notheld() routines
05121 ** are intended for use inside assert() statements.  ^The SQLite core
05122 ** never uses these routines except inside an assert() and applications
05123 ** are advised to follow the lead of the core.  ^The SQLite core only
05124 ** provides implementations for these routines when it is compiled
05125 ** with the SQLITE_DEBUG flag.  ^External mutex implementations
05126 ** are only required to provide these routines if SQLITE_DEBUG is
05127 ** defined and if NDEBUG is not defined.
05128 **
05129 ** ^These routines should return true if the mutex in their argument
05130 ** is held or not held, respectively, by the calling thread.
05131 **
05132 ** ^The implementation is not required to provided versions of these
05133 ** routines that actually work. If the implementation does not provide working
05134 ** versions of these routines, it should at least provide stubs that always
05135 ** return true so that one does not get spurious assertion failures.
05136 **
05137 ** ^If the argument to sqlite3_mutex_held() is a NULL pointer then
05138 ** the routine should return 1.   This seems counter-intuitive since
05139 ** clearly the mutex cannot be held if it does not exist.  But the
05140 ** the reason the mutex does not exist is because the build is not
05141 ** using mutexes.  And we do not want the assert() containing the
05142 ** call to sqlite3_mutex_held() to fail, so a non-zero return is
05143 ** the appropriate thing to do.  ^The sqlite3_mutex_notheld()
05144 ** interface should also return 1 when given a NULL pointer.
05145 */
05146 #ifndef NDEBUG
05147 SQLITE_API int sqlite3_mutex_held(sqlite3_mutex*);
05148 SQLITE_API int sqlite3_mutex_notheld(sqlite3_mutex*);
05149 #endif
05150 
05151 /*
05152 ** CAPI3REF: Mutex Types
05153 **
05154 ** The [sqlite3_mutex_alloc()] interface takes a single argument
05155 ** which is one of these integer constants.
05156 **
05157 ** The set of static mutexes may change from one SQLite release to the
05158 ** next.  Applications that override the built-in mutex logic must be
05159 ** prepared to accommodate additional static mutexes.
05160 */
05161 #define SQLITE_MUTEX_FAST             0
05162 #define SQLITE_MUTEX_RECURSIVE        1
05163 #define SQLITE_MUTEX_STATIC_MASTER    2
05164 #define SQLITE_MUTEX_STATIC_MEM       3  /* sqlite3_malloc() */
05165 #define SQLITE_MUTEX_STATIC_MEM2      4  /* NOT USED */
05166 #define SQLITE_MUTEX_STATIC_OPEN      4  /* sqlite3BtreeOpen() */
05167 #define SQLITE_MUTEX_STATIC_PRNG      5  /* sqlite3_random() */
05168 #define SQLITE_MUTEX_STATIC_LRU       6  /* lru page list */
05169 #define SQLITE_MUTEX_STATIC_LRU2      7  /* lru page list */
05170 
05171 /*
05172 ** CAPI3REF: Retrieve the mutex for a database connection
05173 **
05174 ** ^This interface returns a pointer the [sqlite3_mutex] object that 
05175 ** serializes access to the [database connection] given in the argument
05176 ** when the [threading mode] is Serialized.
05177 ** ^If the [threading mode] is Single-thread or Multi-thread then this
05178 ** routine returns a NULL pointer.
05179 */
05180 SQLITE_API sqlite3_mutex *sqlite3_db_mutex(sqlite3*);
05181 
05182 /*
05183 ** CAPI3REF: Low-Level Control Of Database Files
05184 **
05185 ** ^The [sqlite3_file_control()] interface makes a direct call to the
05186 ** xFileControl method for the [sqlite3_io_methods] object associated
05187 ** with a particular database identified by the second argument. ^The
05188 ** name of the database "main" for the main database or "temp" for the
05189 ** TEMP database, or the name that appears after the AS keyword for
05190 ** databases that are added using the [ATTACH] SQL command.
05191 ** ^A NULL pointer can be used in place of "main" to refer to the
05192 ** main database file.
05193 ** ^The third and fourth parameters to this routine
05194 ** are passed directly through to the second and third parameters of
05195 ** the xFileControl method.  ^The return value of the xFileControl
05196 ** method becomes the return value of this routine.
05197 **
05198 ** ^If the second parameter (zDbName) does not match the name of any
05199 ** open database file, then SQLITE_ERROR is returned.  ^This error
05200 ** code is not remembered and will not be recalled by [sqlite3_errcode()]
05201 ** or [sqlite3_errmsg()].  The underlying xFileControl method might
05202 ** also return SQLITE_ERROR.  There is no way to distinguish between
05203 ** an incorrect zDbName and an SQLITE_ERROR return from the underlying
05204 ** xFileControl method.
05205 **
05206 ** See also: [SQLITE_FCNTL_LOCKSTATE]
05207 */
05208 SQLITE_API int sqlite3_file_control(sqlite3*, const char *zDbName, int op, void*);
05209 
05210 /*
05211 ** CAPI3REF: Testing Interface
05212 **
05213 ** ^The sqlite3_test_control() interface is used to read out internal
05214 ** state of SQLite and to inject faults into SQLite for testing
05215 ** purposes.  ^The first parameter is an operation code that determines
05216 ** the number, meaning, and operation of all subsequent parameters.
05217 **
05218 ** This interface is not for use by applications.  It exists solely
05219 ** for verifying the correct operation of the SQLite library.  Depending
05220 ** on how the SQLite library is compiled, this interface might not exist.
05221 **
05222 ** The details of the operation codes, their meanings, the parameters
05223 ** they take, and what they do are all subject to change without notice.
05224 ** Unlike most of the SQLite API, this function is not guaranteed to
05225 ** operate consistently from one release to the next.
05226 */
05227 SQLITE_API int sqlite3_test_control(int op, ...);
05228 
05229 /*
05230 ** CAPI3REF: Testing Interface Operation Codes
05231 **
05232 ** These constants are the valid operation code parameters used
05233 ** as the first argument to [sqlite3_test_control()].
05234 **
05235 ** These parameters and their meanings are subject to change
05236 ** without notice.  These values are for testing purposes only.
05237 ** Applications should not use any of these parameters or the
05238 ** [sqlite3_test_control()] interface.
05239 */
05240 #define SQLITE_TESTCTRL_FIRST                    5
05241 #define SQLITE_TESTCTRL_PRNG_SAVE                5
05242 #define SQLITE_TESTCTRL_PRNG_RESTORE             6
05243 #define SQLITE_TESTCTRL_PRNG_RESET               7
05244 #define SQLITE_TESTCTRL_BITVEC_TEST              8
05245 #define SQLITE_TESTCTRL_FAULT_INSTALL            9
05246 #define SQLITE_TESTCTRL_BENIGN_MALLOC_HOOKS     10
05247 #define SQLITE_TESTCTRL_PENDING_BYTE            11
05248 #define SQLITE_TESTCTRL_ASSERT                  12
05249 #define SQLITE_TESTCTRL_ALWAYS                  13
05250 #define SQLITE_TESTCTRL_RESERVE                 14
05251 #define SQLITE_TESTCTRL_OPTIMIZATIONS           15
05252 #define SQLITE_TESTCTRL_ISKEYWORD               16
05253 #define SQLITE_TESTCTRL_PGHDRSZ                 17
05254 #define SQLITE_TESTCTRL_SCRATCHMALLOC           18
05255 #define SQLITE_TESTCTRL_LAST                    18
05256 
05257 /*
05258 ** CAPI3REF: SQLite Runtime Status
05259 **
05260 ** ^This interface is used to retrieve runtime status information
05261 ** about the performance of SQLite, and optionally to reset various
05262 ** highwater marks.  ^The first argument is an integer code for
05263 ** the specific parameter to measure.  ^(Recognized integer codes
05264 ** are of the form [SQLITE_STATUS_MEMORY_USED | SQLITE_STATUS_...].)^
05265 ** ^The current value of the parameter is returned into *pCurrent.
05266 ** ^The highest recorded value is returned in *pHighwater.  ^If the
05267 ** resetFlag is true, then the highest record value is reset after
05268 ** *pHighwater is written.  ^(Some parameters do not record the highest
05269 ** value.  For those parameters
05270 ** nothing is written into *pHighwater and the resetFlag is ignored.)^
05271 ** ^(Other parameters record only the highwater mark and not the current
05272 ** value.  For these latter parameters nothing is written into *pCurrent.)^
05273 **
05274 ** ^The sqlite3_status() routine returns SQLITE_OK on success and a
05275 ** non-zero [error code] on failure.
05276 **
05277 ** This routine is threadsafe but is not atomic.  This routine can be
05278 ** called while other threads are running the same or different SQLite
05279 ** interfaces.  However the values returned in *pCurrent and
05280 ** *pHighwater reflect the status of SQLite at different points in time
05281 ** and it is possible that another thread might change the parameter
05282 ** in between the times when *pCurrent and *pHighwater are written.
05283 **
05284 ** See also: [sqlite3_db_status()]
05285 */
05286 SQLITE_API int sqlite3_status(int op, int *pCurrent, int *pHighwater, int resetFlag);
05287 
05288 
05289 /*
05290 ** CAPI3REF: Status Parameters
05291 **
05292 ** These integer constants designate various run-time status parameters
05293 ** that can be returned by [sqlite3_status()].
05294 **
05295 ** <dl>
05296 ** ^(<dt>SQLITE_STATUS_MEMORY_USED</dt>
05297 ** <dd>This parameter is the current amount of memory checked out
05298 ** using [sqlite3_malloc()], either directly or indirectly.  The
05299 ** figure includes calls made to [sqlite3_malloc()] by the application
05300 ** and internal memory usage by the SQLite library.  Scratch memory
05301 ** controlled by [SQLITE_CONFIG_SCRATCH] and auxiliary page-cache
05302 ** memory controlled by [SQLITE_CONFIG_PAGECACHE] is not included in
05303 ** this parameter.  The amount returned is the sum of the allocation
05304 ** sizes as reported by the xSize method in [sqlite3_mem_methods].</dd>)^
05305 **
05306 ** ^(<dt>SQLITE_STATUS_MALLOC_SIZE</dt>
05307 ** <dd>This parameter records the largest memory allocation request
05308 ** handed to [sqlite3_malloc()] or [sqlite3_realloc()] (or their
05309 ** internal equivalents).  Only the value returned in the
05310 ** *pHighwater parameter to [sqlite3_status()] is of interest.  
05311 ** The value written into the *pCurrent parameter is undefined.</dd>)^
05312 **
05313 ** ^(<dt>SQLITE_STATUS_MALLOC_COUNT</dt>
05314 ** <dd>This parameter records the number of separate memory allocations.</dd>)^
05315 **
05316 ** ^(<dt>SQLITE_STATUS_PAGECACHE_USED</dt>
05317 ** <dd>This parameter returns the number of pages used out of the
05318 ** [pagecache memory allocator] that was configured using 
05319 ** [SQLITE_CONFIG_PAGECACHE].  The
05320 ** value returned is in pages, not in bytes.</dd>)^
05321 **
05322 ** ^(<dt>SQLITE_STATUS_PAGECACHE_OVERFLOW</dt>
05323 ** <dd>This parameter returns the number of bytes of page cache
05324 ** allocation which could not be satisfied by the [SQLITE_CONFIG_PAGECACHE]
05325 ** buffer and where forced to overflow to [sqlite3_malloc()].  The
05326 ** returned value includes allocations that overflowed because they
05327 ** where too large (they were larger than the "sz" parameter to
05328 ** [SQLITE_CONFIG_PAGECACHE]) and allocations that overflowed because
05329 ** no space was left in the page cache.</dd>)^
05330 **
05331 ** ^(<dt>SQLITE_STATUS_PAGECACHE_SIZE</dt>
05332 ** <dd>This parameter records the largest memory allocation request
05333 ** handed to [pagecache memory allocator].  Only the value returned in the
05334 ** *pHighwater parameter to [sqlite3_status()] is of interest.  
05335 ** The value written into the *pCurrent parameter is undefined.</dd>)^
05336 **
05337 ** ^(<dt>SQLITE_STATUS_SCRATCH_USED</dt>
05338 ** <dd>This parameter returns the number of allocations used out of the
05339 ** [scratch memory allocator] configured using
05340 ** [SQLITE_CONFIG_SCRATCH].  The value returned is in allocations, not
05341 ** in bytes.  Since a single thread may only have one scratch allocation
05342 ** outstanding at time, this parameter also reports the number of threads
05343 ** using scratch memory at the same time.</dd>)^
05344 **
05345 ** ^(<dt>SQLITE_STATUS_SCRATCH_OVERFLOW</dt>
05346 ** <dd>This parameter returns the number of bytes of scratch memory
05347 ** allocation which could not be satisfied by the [SQLITE_CONFIG_SCRATCH]
05348 ** buffer and where forced to overflow to [sqlite3_malloc()].  The values
05349 ** returned include overflows because the requested allocation was too
05350 ** larger (that is, because the requested allocation was larger than the
05351 ** "sz" parameter to [SQLITE_CONFIG_SCRATCH]) and because no scratch buffer
05352 ** slots were available.
05353 ** </dd>)^
05354 **
05355 ** ^(<dt>SQLITE_STATUS_SCRATCH_SIZE</dt>
05356 ** <dd>This parameter records the largest memory allocation request
05357 ** handed to [scratch memory allocator].  Only the value returned in the
05358 ** *pHighwater parameter to [sqlite3_status()] is of interest.  
05359 ** The value written into the *pCurrent parameter is undefined.</dd>)^
05360 **
05361 ** ^(<dt>SQLITE_STATUS_PARSER_STACK</dt>
05362 ** <dd>This parameter records the deepest parser stack.  It is only
05363 ** meaningful if SQLite is compiled with [YYTRACKMAXSTACKDEPTH].</dd>)^
05364 ** </dl>
05365 **
05366 ** New status parameters may be added from time to time.
05367 */
05368 #define SQLITE_STATUS_MEMORY_USED          0
05369 #define SQLITE_STATUS_PAGECACHE_USED       1
05370 #define SQLITE_STATUS_PAGECACHE_OVERFLOW   2
05371 #define SQLITE_STATUS_SCRATCH_USED         3
05372 #define SQLITE_STATUS_SCRATCH_OVERFLOW     4
05373 #define SQLITE_STATUS_MALLOC_SIZE          5
05374 #define SQLITE_STATUS_PARSER_STACK         6
05375 #define SQLITE_STATUS_PAGECACHE_SIZE       7
05376 #define SQLITE_STATUS_SCRATCH_SIZE         8
05377 #define SQLITE_STATUS_MALLOC_COUNT         9
05378 
05379 /*
05380 ** CAPI3REF: Database Connection Status
05381 **
05382 ** ^This interface is used to retrieve runtime status information 
05383 ** about a single [database connection].  ^The first argument is the
05384 ** database connection object to be interrogated.  ^The second argument
05385 ** is an integer constant, taken from the set of
05386 ** [SQLITE_DBSTATUS_LOOKASIDE_USED | SQLITE_DBSTATUS_*] macros, that
05387 ** determines the parameter to interrogate.  The set of 
05388 ** [SQLITE_DBSTATUS_LOOKASIDE_USED | SQLITE_DBSTATUS_*] macros is likely
05389 ** to grow in future releases of SQLite.
05390 **
05391 ** ^The current value of the requested parameter is written into *pCur
05392 ** and the highest instantaneous value is written into *pHiwtr.  ^If
05393 ** the resetFlg is true, then the highest instantaneous value is
05394 ** reset back down to the current value.
05395 **
05396 ** ^The sqlite3_db_status() routine returns SQLITE_OK on success and a
05397 ** non-zero [error code] on failure.
05398 **
05399 ** See also: [sqlite3_status()] and [sqlite3_stmt_status()].
05400 */
05401 SQLITE_API int sqlite3_db_status(sqlite3*, int op, int *pCur, int *pHiwtr, int resetFlg);
05402 
05403 /*
05404 ** CAPI3REF: Status Parameters for database connections
05405 **
05406 ** These constants are the available integer "verbs" that can be passed as
05407 ** the second argument to the [sqlite3_db_status()] interface.
05408 **
05409 ** New verbs may be added in future releases of SQLite. Existing verbs
05410 ** might be discontinued. Applications should check the return code from
05411 ** [sqlite3_db_status()] to make sure that the call worked.
05412 ** The [sqlite3_db_status()] interface will return a non-zero error code
05413 ** if a discontinued or unsupported verb is invoked.
05414 **
05415 ** <dl>
05416 ** ^(<dt>SQLITE_DBSTATUS_LOOKASIDE_USED</dt>
05417 ** <dd>This parameter returns the number of lookaside memory slots currently
05418 ** checked out.</dd>)^
05419 **
05420 ** ^(<dt>SQLITE_DBSTATUS_CACHE_USED</dt>
05421 ** <dd>This parameter returns the approximate number of of bytes of heap
05422 ** memory used by all pager caches associated with the database connection.)^
05423 ** ^The highwater mark associated with SQLITE_DBSTATUS_CACHE_USED is always 0.
05424 **
05425 ** ^(<dt>SQLITE_DBSTATUS_SCHEMA_USED</dt>
05426 ** <dd>This parameter returns the approximate number of of bytes of heap
05427 ** memory used to store the schema for all databases associated
05428 ** with the connection - main, temp, and any [ATTACH]-ed databases.)^ 
05429 ** ^The full amount of memory used by the schemas is reported, even if the
05430 ** schema memory is shared with other database connections due to
05431 ** [shared cache mode] being enabled.
05432 ** ^The highwater mark associated with SQLITE_DBSTATUS_SCHEMA_USED is always 0.
05433 **
05434 ** ^(<dt>SQLITE_DBSTATUS_STMT_USED</dt>
05435 ** <dd>This parameter returns the approximate number of of bytes of heap
05436 ** and lookaside memory used by all prepared statements associated with
05437 ** the database connection.)^
05438 ** ^The highwater mark associated with SQLITE_DBSTATUS_STMT_USED is always 0.
05439 ** </dd>
05440 ** </dl>
05441 */
05442 #define SQLITE_DBSTATUS_LOOKASIDE_USED     0
05443 #define SQLITE_DBSTATUS_CACHE_USED         1
05444 #define SQLITE_DBSTATUS_SCHEMA_USED        2
05445 #define SQLITE_DBSTATUS_STMT_USED          3
05446 #define SQLITE_DBSTATUS_MAX                3   /* Largest defined DBSTATUS */
05447 
05448 
05449 /*
05450 ** CAPI3REF: Prepared Statement Status
05451 **
05452 ** ^(Each prepared statement maintains various
05453 ** [SQLITE_STMTSTATUS_SORT | counters] that measure the number
05454 ** of times it has performed specific operations.)^  These counters can
05455 ** be used to monitor the performance characteristics of the prepared
05456 ** statements.  For example, if the number of table steps greatly exceeds
05457 ** the number of table searches or result rows, that would tend to indicate
05458 ** that the prepared statement is using a full table scan rather than
05459 ** an index.  
05460 **
05461 ** ^(This interface is used to retrieve and reset counter values from
05462 ** a [prepared statement].  The first argument is the prepared statement
05463 ** object to be interrogated.  The second argument
05464 ** is an integer code for a specific [SQLITE_STMTSTATUS_SORT | counter]
05465 ** to be interrogated.)^
05466 ** ^The current value of the requested counter is returned.
05467 ** ^If the resetFlg is true, then the counter is reset to zero after this
05468 ** interface call returns.
05469 **
05470 ** See also: [sqlite3_status()] and [sqlite3_db_status()].
05471 */
05472 SQLITE_API int sqlite3_stmt_status(sqlite3_stmt*, int op,int resetFlg);
05473 
05474 /*
05475 ** CAPI3REF: Status Parameters for prepared statements
05476 **
05477 ** These preprocessor macros define integer codes that name counter
05478 ** values associated with the [sqlite3_stmt_status()] interface.
05479 ** The meanings of the various counters are as follows:
05480 **
05481 ** <dl>
05482 ** <dt>SQLITE_STMTSTATUS_FULLSCAN_STEP</dt>
05483 ** <dd>^This is the number of times that SQLite has stepped forward in
05484 ** a table as part of a full table scan.  Large numbers for this counter
05485 ** may indicate opportunities for performance improvement through 
05486 ** careful use of indices.</dd>
05487 **
05488 ** <dt>SQLITE_STMTSTATUS_SORT</dt>
05489 ** <dd>^This is the number of sort operations that have occurred.
05490 ** A non-zero value in this counter may indicate an opportunity to
05491 ** improvement performance through careful use of indices.</dd>
05492 **
05493 ** <dt>SQLITE_STMTSTATUS_AUTOINDEX</dt>
05494 ** <dd>^This is the number of rows inserted into transient indices that
05495 ** were created automatically in order to help joins run faster.
05496 ** A non-zero value in this counter may indicate an opportunity to
05497 ** improvement performance by adding permanent indices that do not
05498 ** need to be reinitialized each time the statement is run.</dd>
05499 **
05500 ** </dl>
05501 */
05502 #define SQLITE_STMTSTATUS_FULLSCAN_STEP     1
05503 #define SQLITE_STMTSTATUS_SORT              2
05504 #define SQLITE_STMTSTATUS_AUTOINDEX         3
05505 
05506 /*
05507 ** CAPI3REF: Custom Page Cache Object
05508 **
05509 ** The sqlite3_pcache type is opaque.  It is implemented by
05510 ** the pluggable module.  The SQLite core has no knowledge of
05511 ** its size or internal structure and never deals with the
05512 ** sqlite3_pcache object except by holding and passing pointers
05513 ** to the object.
05514 **
05515 ** See [sqlite3_pcache_methods] for additional information.
05516 */
05517 typedef struct sqlite3_pcache sqlite3_pcache;
05518 
05519 /*
05520 ** CAPI3REF: Application Defined Page Cache.
05521 ** KEYWORDS: {page cache}
05522 **
05523 ** ^(The [sqlite3_config]([SQLITE_CONFIG_PCACHE], ...) interface can
05524 ** register an alternative page cache implementation by passing in an 
05525 ** instance of the sqlite3_pcache_methods structure.)^
05526 ** In many applications, most of the heap memory allocated by 
05527 ** SQLite is used for the page cache.
05528 ** By implementing a 
05529 ** custom page cache using this API, an application can better control
05530 ** the amount of memory consumed by SQLite, the way in which 
05531 ** that memory is allocated and released, and the policies used to 
05532 ** determine exactly which parts of a database file are cached and for 
05533 ** how long.
05534 **
05535 ** The alternative page cache mechanism is an
05536 ** extreme measure that is only needed by the most demanding applications.
05537 ** The built-in page cache is recommended for most uses.
05538 **
05539 ** ^(The contents of the sqlite3_pcache_methods structure are copied to an
05540 ** internal buffer by SQLite within the call to [sqlite3_config].  Hence
05541 ** the application may discard the parameter after the call to
05542 ** [sqlite3_config()] returns.)^
05543 **
05544 ** ^(The xInit() method is called once for each effective 
05545 ** call to [sqlite3_initialize()])^
05546 ** (usually only once during the lifetime of the process). ^(The xInit()
05547 ** method is passed a copy of the sqlite3_pcache_methods.pArg value.)^
05548 ** The intent of the xInit() method is to set up global data structures 
05549 ** required by the custom page cache implementation. 
05550 ** ^(If the xInit() method is NULL, then the 
05551 ** built-in default page cache is used instead of the application defined
05552 ** page cache.)^
05553 **
05554 ** ^The xShutdown() method is called by [sqlite3_shutdown()].
05555 ** It can be used to clean up 
05556 ** any outstanding resources before process shutdown, if required.
05557 ** ^The xShutdown() method may be NULL.
05558 **
05559 ** ^SQLite automatically serializes calls to the xInit method,
05560 ** so the xInit method need not be threadsafe.  ^The
05561 ** xShutdown method is only called from [sqlite3_shutdown()] so it does
05562 ** not need to be threadsafe either.  All other methods must be threadsafe
05563 ** in multithreaded applications.
05564 **
05565 ** ^SQLite will never invoke xInit() more than once without an intervening
05566 ** call to xShutdown().
05567 **
05568 ** ^SQLite invokes the xCreate() method to construct a new cache instance.
05569 ** SQLite will typically create one cache instance for each open database file,
05570 ** though this is not guaranteed. ^The
05571 ** first parameter, szPage, is the size in bytes of the pages that must
05572 ** be allocated by the cache.  ^szPage will not be a power of two.  ^szPage
05573 ** will the page size of the database file that is to be cached plus an
05574 ** increment (here called "R") of about 100 or 200.  SQLite will use the
05575 ** extra R bytes on each page to store metadata about the underlying
05576 ** database page on disk.  The value of R depends
05577 ** on the SQLite version, the target platform, and how SQLite was compiled.
05578 ** ^R is constant for a particular build of SQLite.  ^The second argument to
05579 ** xCreate(), bPurgeable, is true if the cache being created will
05580 ** be used to cache database pages of a file stored on disk, or
05581 ** false if it is used for an in-memory database. The cache implementation
05582 ** does not have to do anything special based with the value of bPurgeable;
05583 ** it is purely advisory.  ^On a cache where bPurgeable is false, SQLite will
05584 ** never invoke xUnpin() except to deliberately delete a page.
05585 ** ^In other words, calls to xUnpin() on a cache with bPurgeable set to
05586 ** false will always have the "discard" flag set to true.  
05587 ** ^Hence, a cache created with bPurgeable false will
05588 ** never contain any unpinned pages.
05589 **
05590 ** ^(The xCachesize() method may be called at any time by SQLite to set the
05591 ** suggested maximum cache-size (number of pages stored by) the cache
05592 ** instance passed as the first argument. This is the value configured using
05593 ** the SQLite "[PRAGMA cache_size]" command.)^  As with the bPurgeable
05594 ** parameter, the implementation is not required to do anything with this
05595 ** value; it is advisory only.
05596 **
05597 ** The xPagecount() method must return the number of pages currently
05598 ** stored in the cache, both pinned and unpinned.
05599 ** 
05600 ** The xFetch() method locates a page in the cache and returns a pointer to 
05601 ** the page, or a NULL pointer.
05602 ** A "page", in this context, means a buffer of szPage bytes aligned at an
05603 ** 8-byte boundary. The page to be fetched is determined by the key. ^The
05604 ** mimimum key value is 1.  After it has been retrieved using xFetch, the page 
05605 ** is considered to be "pinned".
05606 **
05607 ** If the requested page is already in the page cache, then the page cache
05608 ** implementation must return a pointer to the page buffer with its content
05609 ** intact.  If the requested page is not already in the cache, then the
05610 ** behavior of the cache implementation should use the value of the createFlag
05611 ** parameter to help it determined what action to take:
05612 **
05613 ** <table border=1 width=85% align=center>
05614 ** <tr><th> createFlag <th> Behaviour when page is not already in cache
05615 ** <tr><td> 0 <td> Do not allocate a new page.  Return NULL.
05616 ** <tr><td> 1 <td> Allocate a new page if it easy and convenient to do so.
05617 **                 Otherwise return NULL.
05618 ** <tr><td> 2 <td> Make every effort to allocate a new page.  Only return
05619 **                 NULL if allocating a new page is effectively impossible.
05620 ** </table>
05621 **
05622 ** ^(SQLite will normally invoke xFetch() with a createFlag of 0 or 1.  SQLite
05623 ** will only use a createFlag of 2 after a prior call with a createFlag of 1
05624 ** failed.)^  In between the to xFetch() calls, SQLite may
05625 ** attempt to unpin one or more cache pages by spilling the content of
05626 ** pinned pages to disk and synching the operating system disk cache.
05627 **
05628 ** ^xUnpin() is called by SQLite with a pointer to a currently pinned page
05629 ** as its second argument.  If the third parameter, discard, is non-zero,
05630 ** then the page must be evicted from the cache.
05631 ** ^If the discard parameter is
05632 ** zero, then the page may be discarded or retained at the discretion of
05633 ** page cache implementation. ^The page cache implementation
05634 ** may choose to evict unpinned pages at any time.
05635 **
05636 ** The cache must not perform any reference counting. A single 
05637 ** call to xUnpin() unpins the page regardless of the number of prior calls 
05638 ** to xFetch().
05639 **
05640 ** The xRekey() method is used to change the key value associated with the
05641 ** page passed as the second argument. If the cache
05642 ** previously contains an entry associated with newKey, it must be
05643 ** discarded. ^Any prior cache entry associated with newKey is guaranteed not
05644 ** to be pinned.
05645 **
05646 ** When SQLite calls the xTruncate() method, the cache must discard all
05647 ** existing cache entries with page numbers (keys) greater than or equal
05648 ** to the value of the iLimit parameter passed to xTruncate(). If any
05649 ** of these pages are pinned, they are implicitly unpinned, meaning that
05650 ** they can be safely discarded.
05651 **
05652 ** ^The xDestroy() method is used to delete a cache allocated by xCreate().
05653 ** All resources associated with the specified cache should be freed. ^After
05654 ** calling the xDestroy() method, SQLite considers the [sqlite3_pcache*]
05655 ** handle invalid, and will not use it with any other sqlite3_pcache_methods
05656 ** functions.
05657 */
05658 typedef struct sqlite3_pcache_methods sqlite3_pcache_methods;
05659 struct sqlite3_pcache_methods {
05660   void *pArg;
05661   int (*xInit)(void*);
05662   void (*xShutdown)(void*);
05663   sqlite3_pcache *(*xCreate)(int szPage, int bPurgeable);
05664   void (*xCachesize)(sqlite3_pcache*, int nCachesize);
05665   int (*xPagecount)(sqlite3_pcache*);
05666   void *(*xFetch)(sqlite3_pcache*, unsigned key, int createFlag);
05667   void (*xUnpin)(sqlite3_pcache*, void*, int discard);
05668   void (*xRekey)(sqlite3_pcache*, void*, unsigned oldKey, unsigned newKey);
05669   void (*xTruncate)(sqlite3_pcache*, unsigned iLimit);
05670   void (*xDestroy)(sqlite3_pcache*);
05671 };
05672 
05673 /*
05674 ** CAPI3REF: Online Backup Object
05675 **
05676 ** The sqlite3_backup object records state information about an ongoing
05677 ** online backup operation.  ^The sqlite3_backup object is created by
05678 ** a call to [sqlite3_backup_init()] and is destroyed by a call to
05679 ** [sqlite3_backup_finish()].
05680 **
05681 ** See Also: [Using the SQLite Online Backup API]
05682 */
05683 typedef struct sqlite3_backup sqlite3_backup;
05684 
05685 /*
05686 ** CAPI3REF: Online Backup API.
05687 **
05688 ** The backup API copies the content of one database into another.
05689 ** It is useful either for creating backups of databases or
05690 ** for copying in-memory databases to or from persistent files. 
05691 **
05692 ** See Also: [Using the SQLite Online Backup API]
05693 **
05694 ** ^Exclusive access is required to the destination database for the 
05695 ** duration of the operation. ^However the source database is only
05696 ** read-locked while it is actually being read; it is not locked
05697 ** continuously for the entire backup operation. ^Thus, the backup may be
05698 ** performed on a live source database without preventing other users from
05699 ** reading or writing to the source database while the backup is underway.
05700 ** 
05701 ** ^(To perform a backup operation: 
05702 **   <ol>
05703 **     <li><b>sqlite3_backup_init()</b> is called once to initialize the
05704 **         backup, 
05705 **     <li><b>sqlite3_backup_step()</b> is called one or more times to transfer 
05706 **         the data between the two databases, and finally
05707 **     <li><b>sqlite3_backup_finish()</b> is called to release all resources 
05708 **         associated with the backup operation. 
05709 **   </ol>)^
05710 ** There should be exactly one call to sqlite3_backup_finish() for each
05711 ** successful call to sqlite3_backup_init().
05712 **
05713 ** <b>sqlite3_backup_init()</b>
05714 **
05715 ** ^The D and N arguments to sqlite3_backup_init(D,N,S,M) are the 
05716 ** [database connection] associated with the destination database 
05717 ** and the database name, respectively.
05718 ** ^The database name is "main" for the main database, "temp" for the
05719 ** temporary database, or the name specified after the AS keyword in
05720 ** an [ATTACH] statement for an attached database.
05721 ** ^The S and M arguments passed to 
05722 ** sqlite3_backup_init(D,N,S,M) identify the [database connection]
05723 ** and database name of the source database, respectively.
05724 ** ^The source and destination [database connections] (parameters S and D)
05725 ** must be different or else sqlite3_backup_init(D,N,S,M) will file with
05726 ** an error.
05727 **
05728 ** ^If an error occurs within sqlite3_backup_init(D,N,S,M), then NULL is
05729 ** returned and an error code and error message are store3d in the
05730 ** destination [database connection] D.
05731 ** ^The error code and message for the failed call to sqlite3_backup_init()
05732 ** can be retrieved using the [sqlite3_errcode()], [sqlite3_errmsg()], and/or
05733 ** [sqlite3_errmsg16()] functions.
05734 ** ^A successful call to sqlite3_backup_init() returns a pointer to an
05735 ** [sqlite3_backup] object.
05736 ** ^The [sqlite3_backup] object may be used with the sqlite3_backup_step() and
05737 ** sqlite3_backup_finish() functions to perform the specified backup 
05738 ** operation.
05739 **
05740 ** <b>sqlite3_backup_step()</b>
05741 **
05742 ** ^Function sqlite3_backup_step(B,N) will copy up to N pages between 
05743 ** the source and destination databases specified by [sqlite3_backup] object B.
05744 ** ^If N is negative, all remaining source pages are copied. 
05745 ** ^If sqlite3_backup_step(B,N) successfully copies N pages and there
05746 ** are still more pages to be copied, then the function resturns [SQLITE_OK].
05747 ** ^If sqlite3_backup_step(B,N) successfully finishes copying all pages
05748 ** from source to destination, then it returns [SQLITE_DONE].
05749 ** ^If an error occurs while running sqlite3_backup_step(B,N),
05750 ** then an [error code] is returned. ^As well as [SQLITE_OK] and
05751 ** [SQLITE_DONE], a call to sqlite3_backup_step() may return [SQLITE_READONLY],
05752 ** [SQLITE_NOMEM], [SQLITE_BUSY], [SQLITE_LOCKED], or an
05753 ** [SQLITE_IOERR_ACCESS | SQLITE_IOERR_XXX] extended error code.
05754 **
05755 ** ^(The sqlite3_backup_step() might return [SQLITE_READONLY] if
05756 ** <ol>
05757 ** <li> the destination database was opened read-only, or
05758 ** <li> the destination database is using write-ahead-log journaling
05759 ** and the destination and source page sizes differ, or
05760 ** <li> The destination database is an in-memory database and the
05761 ** destination and source page sizes differ.
05762 ** </ol>)^
05763 **
05764 ** ^If sqlite3_backup_step() cannot obtain a required file-system lock, then
05765 ** the [sqlite3_busy_handler | busy-handler function]
05766 ** is invoked (if one is specified). ^If the 
05767 ** busy-handler returns non-zero before the lock is available, then 
05768 ** [SQLITE_BUSY] is returned to the caller. ^In this case the call to
05769 ** sqlite3_backup_step() can be retried later. ^If the source
05770 ** [database connection]
05771 ** is being used to write to the source database when sqlite3_backup_step()
05772 ** is called, then [SQLITE_LOCKED] is returned immediately. ^Again, in this
05773 ** case the call to sqlite3_backup_step() can be retried later on. ^(If
05774 ** [SQLITE_IOERR_ACCESS | SQLITE_IOERR_XXX], [SQLITE_NOMEM], or
05775 ** [SQLITE_READONLY] is returned, then 
05776 ** there is no point in retrying the call to sqlite3_backup_step(). These 
05777 ** errors are considered fatal.)^  The application must accept 
05778 ** that the backup operation has failed and pass the backup operation handle 
05779 ** to the sqlite3_backup_finish() to release associated resources.
05780 **
05781 ** ^The first call to sqlite3_backup_step() obtains an exclusive lock
05782 ** on the destination file. ^The exclusive lock is not released until either 
05783 ** sqlite3_backup_finish() is called or the backup operation is complete 
05784 ** and sqlite3_backup_step() returns [SQLITE_DONE].  ^Every call to
05785 ** sqlite3_backup_step() obtains a [shared lock] on the source database that
05786 ** lasts for the duration of the sqlite3_backup_step() call.
05787 ** ^Because the source database is not locked between calls to
05788 ** sqlite3_backup_step(), the source database may be modified mid-way
05789 ** through the backup process.  ^If the source database is modified by an
05790 ** external process or via a database connection other than the one being
05791 ** used by the backup operation, then the backup will be automatically
05792 ** restarted by the next call to sqlite3_backup_step(). ^If the source 
05793 ** database is modified by the using the same database connection as is used
05794 ** by the backup operation, then the backup database is automatically
05795 ** updated at the same time.
05796 **
05797 ** <b>sqlite3_backup_finish()</b>
05798 **
05799 ** When sqlite3_backup_step() has returned [SQLITE_DONE], or when the 
05800 ** application wishes to abandon the backup operation, the application
05801 ** should destroy the [sqlite3_backup] by passing it to sqlite3_backup_finish().
05802 ** ^The sqlite3_backup_finish() interfaces releases all
05803 ** resources associated with the [sqlite3_backup] object. 
05804 ** ^If sqlite3_backup_step() has not yet returned [SQLITE_DONE], then any
05805 ** active write-transaction on the destination database is rolled back.
05806 ** The [sqlite3_backup] object is invalid
05807 ** and may not be used following a call to sqlite3_backup_finish().
05808 **
05809 ** ^The value returned by sqlite3_backup_finish is [SQLITE_OK] if no
05810 ** sqlite3_backup_step() errors occurred, regardless or whether or not
05811 ** sqlite3_backup_step() completed.
05812 ** ^If an out-of-memory condition or IO error occurred during any prior
05813 ** sqlite3_backup_step() call on the same [sqlite3_backup] object, then
05814 ** sqlite3_backup_finish() returns the corresponding [error code].
05815 **
05816 ** ^A return of [SQLITE_BUSY] or [SQLITE_LOCKED] from sqlite3_backup_step()
05817 ** is not a permanent error and does not affect the return value of
05818 ** sqlite3_backup_finish().
05819 **
05820 ** <b>sqlite3_backup_remaining(), sqlite3_backup_pagecount()</b>
05821 **
05822 ** ^Each call to sqlite3_backup_step() sets two values inside
05823 ** the [sqlite3_backup] object: the number of pages still to be backed
05824 ** up and the total number of pages in the source database file.
05825 ** The sqlite3_backup_remaining() and sqlite3_backup_pagecount() interfaces
05826 ** retrieve these two values, respectively.
05827 **
05828 ** ^The values returned by these functions are only updated by
05829 ** sqlite3_backup_step(). ^If the source database is modified during a backup
05830 ** operation, then the values are not updated to account for any extra
05831 ** pages that need to be updated or the size of the source database file
05832 ** changing.
05833 **
05834 ** <b>Concurrent Usage of Database Handles</b>
05835 **
05836 ** ^The source [database connection] may be used by the application for other
05837 ** purposes while a backup operation is underway or being initialized.
05838 ** ^If SQLite is compiled and configured to support threadsafe database
05839 ** connections, then the source database connection may be used concurrently
05840 ** from within other threads.
05841 **
05842 ** However, the application must guarantee that the destination 
05843 ** [database connection] is not passed to any other API (by any thread) after 
05844 ** sqlite3_backup_init() is called and before the corresponding call to
05845 ** sqlite3_backup_finish().  SQLite does not currently check to see
05846 ** if the application incorrectly accesses the destination [database connection]
05847 ** and so no error code is reported, but the operations may malfunction
05848 ** nevertheless.  Use of the destination database connection while a
05849 ** backup is in progress might also also cause a mutex deadlock.
05850 **
05851 ** If running in [shared cache mode], the application must
05852 ** guarantee that the shared cache used by the destination database
05853 ** is not accessed while the backup is running. In practice this means
05854 ** that the application must guarantee that the disk file being 
05855 ** backed up to is not accessed by any connection within the process,
05856 ** not just the specific connection that was passed to sqlite3_backup_init().
05857 **
05858 ** The [sqlite3_backup] object itself is partially threadsafe. Multiple 
05859 ** threads may safely make multiple concurrent calls to sqlite3_backup_step().
05860 ** However, the sqlite3_backup_remaining() and sqlite3_backup_pagecount()
05861 ** APIs are not strictly speaking threadsafe. If they are invoked at the
05862 ** same time as another thread is invoking sqlite3_backup_step() it is
05863 ** possible that they return invalid values.
05864 */
05865 SQLITE_API sqlite3_backup *sqlite3_backup_init(
05866   sqlite3 *pDest,                        /* Destination database handle */
05867   const char *zDestName,                 /* Destination database name */
05868   sqlite3 *pSource,                      /* Source database handle */
05869   const char *zSourceName                /* Source database name */
05870 );
05871 SQLITE_API int sqlite3_backup_step(sqlite3_backup *p, int nPage);
05872 SQLITE_API int sqlite3_backup_finish(sqlite3_backup *p);
05873 SQLITE_API int sqlite3_backup_remaining(sqlite3_backup *p);
05874 SQLITE_API int sqlite3_backup_pagecount(sqlite3_backup *p);
05875 
05876 /*
05877 ** CAPI3REF: Unlock Notification
05878 **
05879 ** ^When running in shared-cache mode, a database operation may fail with
05880 ** an [SQLITE_LOCKED] error if the required locks on the shared-cache or
05881 ** individual tables within the shared-cache cannot be obtained. See
05882 ** [SQLite Shared-Cache Mode] for a description of shared-cache locking. 
05883 ** ^This API may be used to register a callback that SQLite will invoke 
05884 ** when the connection currently holding the required lock relinquishes it.
05885 ** ^This API is only available if the library was compiled with the
05886 ** [SQLITE_ENABLE_UNLOCK_NOTIFY] C-preprocessor symbol defined.
05887 **
05888 ** See Also: [Using the SQLite Unlock Notification Feature].
05889 **
05890 ** ^Shared-cache locks are released when a database connection concludes
05891 ** its current transaction, either by committing it or rolling it back. 
05892 **
05893 ** ^When a connection (known as the blocked connection) fails to obtain a
05894 ** shared-cache lock and SQLITE_LOCKED is returned to the caller, the
05895 ** identity of the database connection (the blocking connection) that
05896 ** has locked the required resource is stored internally. ^After an 
05897 ** application receives an SQLITE_LOCKED error, it may call the
05898 ** sqlite3_unlock_notify() method with the blocked connection handle as 
05899 ** the first argument to register for a callback that will be invoked
05900 ** when the blocking connections current transaction is concluded. ^The
05901 ** callback is invoked from within the [sqlite3_step] or [sqlite3_close]
05902 ** call that concludes the blocking connections transaction.
05903 **
05904 ** ^(If sqlite3_unlock_notify() is called in a multi-threaded application,
05905 ** there is a chance that the blocking connection will have already
05906 ** concluded its transaction by the time sqlite3_unlock_notify() is invoked.
05907 ** If this happens, then the specified callback is invoked immediately,
05908 ** from within the call to sqlite3_unlock_notify().)^
05909 **
05910 ** ^If the blocked connection is attempting to obtain a write-lock on a
05911 ** shared-cache table, and more than one other connection currently holds
05912 ** a read-lock on the same table, then SQLite arbitrarily selects one of 
05913 ** the other connections to use as the blocking connection.
05914 **
05915 ** ^(There may be at most one unlock-notify callback registered by a 
05916 ** blocked connection. If sqlite3_unlock_notify() is called when the
05917 ** blocked connection already has a registered unlock-notify callback,
05918 ** then the new callback replaces the old.)^ ^If sqlite3_unlock_notify() is
05919 ** called with a NULL pointer as its second argument, then any existing
05920 ** unlock-notify callback is canceled. ^The blocked connections 
05921 ** unlock-notify callback may also be canceled by closing the blocked
05922 ** connection using [sqlite3_close()].
05923 **
05924 ** The unlock-notify callback is not reentrant. If an application invokes
05925 ** any sqlite3_xxx API functions from within an unlock-notify callback, a
05926 ** crash or deadlock may be the result.
05927 **
05928 ** ^Unless deadlock is detected (see below), sqlite3_unlock_notify() always
05929 ** returns SQLITE_OK.
05930 **
05931 ** <b>Callback Invocation Details</b>
05932 **
05933 ** When an unlock-notify callback is registered, the application provides a 
05934 ** single void* pointer that is passed to the callback when it is invoked.
05935 ** However, the signature of the callback function allows SQLite to pass
05936 ** it an array of void* context pointers. The first argument passed to
05937 ** an unlock-notify callback is a pointer to an array of void* pointers,
05938 ** and the second is the number of entries in the array.
05939 **
05940 ** When a blocking connections transaction is concluded, there may be
05941 ** more than one blocked connection that has registered for an unlock-notify
05942 ** callback. ^If two or more such blocked connections have specified the
05943 ** same callback function, then instead of invoking the callback function
05944 ** multiple times, it is invoked once with the set of void* context pointers
05945 ** specified by the blocked connections bundled together into an array.
05946 ** This gives the application an opportunity to prioritize any actions 
05947 ** related to the set of unblocked database connections.
05948 **
05949 ** <b>Deadlock Detection</b>
05950 **
05951 ** Assuming that after registering for an unlock-notify callback a 
05952 ** database waits for the callback to be issued before taking any further
05953 ** action (a reasonable assumption), then using this API may cause the
05954 ** application to deadlock. For example, if connection X is waiting for
05955 ** connection Y's transaction to be concluded, and similarly connection
05956 ** Y is waiting on connection X's transaction, then neither connection
05957 ** will proceed and the system may remain deadlocked indefinitely.
05958 **
05959 ** To avoid this scenario, the sqlite3_unlock_notify() performs deadlock
05960 ** detection. ^If a given call to sqlite3_unlock_notify() would put the
05961 ** system in a deadlocked state, then SQLITE_LOCKED is returned and no
05962 ** unlock-notify callback is registered. The system is said to be in
05963 ** a deadlocked state if connection A has registered for an unlock-notify
05964 ** callback on the conclusion of connection B's transaction, and connection
05965 ** B has itself registered for an unlock-notify callback when connection
05966 ** A's transaction is concluded. ^Indirect deadlock is also detected, so
05967 ** the system is also considered to be deadlocked if connection B has
05968 ** registered for an unlock-notify callback on the conclusion of connection
05969 ** C's transaction, where connection C is waiting on connection A. ^Any
05970 ** number of levels of indirection are allowed.
05971 **
05972 ** <b>The "DROP TABLE" Exception</b>
05973 **
05974 ** When a call to [sqlite3_step()] returns SQLITE_LOCKED, it is almost 
05975 ** always appropriate to call sqlite3_unlock_notify(). There is however,
05976 ** one exception. When executing a "DROP TABLE" or "DROP INDEX" statement,
05977 ** SQLite checks if there are any currently executing SELECT statements
05978 ** that belong to the same connection. If there are, SQLITE_LOCKED is
05979 ** returned. In this case there is no "blocking connection", so invoking
05980 ** sqlite3_unlock_notify() results in the unlock-notify callback being
05981 ** invoked immediately. If the application then re-attempts the "DROP TABLE"
05982 ** or "DROP INDEX" query, an infinite loop might be the result.
05983 **
05984 ** One way around this problem is to check the extended error code returned
05985 ** by an sqlite3_step() call. ^(If there is a blocking connection, then the
05986 ** extended error code is set to SQLITE_LOCKED_SHAREDCACHE. Otherwise, in
05987 ** the special "DROP TABLE/INDEX" case, the extended error code is just 
05988 ** SQLITE_LOCKED.)^
05989 */
05990 SQLITE_API int sqlite3_unlock_notify(
05991   sqlite3 *pBlocked,                          /* Waiting connection */
