05992   void (*xNotify)(void **apArg, int nArg),    /* Callback function to invoke */
05993   void *pNotifyArg                            /* Argument to pass to xNotify */
05994 );
05995 
05996 
05997 /*
05998 ** CAPI3REF: String Comparison
05999 **
06000 ** ^The [sqlite3_strnicmp()] API allows applications and extensions to
06001 ** compare the contents of two buffers containing UTF-8 strings in a
06002 ** case-independent fashion, using the same definition of case independence 
06003 ** that SQLite uses internally when comparing identifiers.
06004 */
06005 SQLITE_API int sqlite3_strnicmp(const char *, const char *, int);
06006 
06007 /*
06008 ** CAPI3REF: Error Logging Interface
06009 **
06010 ** ^The [sqlite3_log()] interface writes a message into the error log
06011 ** established by the [SQLITE_CONFIG_LOG] option to [sqlite3_config()].
06012 ** ^If logging is enabled, the zFormat string and subsequent arguments are
06013 ** used with [sqlite3_snprintf()] to generate the final output string.
06014 **
06015 ** The sqlite3_log() interface is intended for use by extensions such as
06016 ** virtual tables, collating functions, and SQL functions.  While there is
06017 ** nothing to prevent an application from calling sqlite3_log(), doing so
06018 ** is considered bad form.
06019 **
06020 ** The zFormat string must not be NULL.
06021 **
06022 ** To avoid deadlocks and other threading problems, the sqlite3_log() routine
06023 ** will not use dynamically allocated memory.  The log message is stored in
06024 ** a fixed-length buffer on the stack.  If the log message is longer than
06025 ** a few hundred characters, it will be truncated to the length of the
06026 ** buffer.
06027 */
06028 SQLITE_API void sqlite3_log(int iErrCode, const char *zFormat, ...);
06029 
06030 /*
06031 ** CAPI3REF: Write-Ahead Log Commit Hook
06032 **
06033 ** ^The [sqlite3_wal_hook()] function is used to register a callback that
06034 ** will be invoked each time a database connection commits data to a
06035 ** [write-ahead log] (i.e. whenever a transaction is committed in
06036 ** [journal_mode | journal_mode=WAL mode]). 
06037 **
06038 ** ^The callback is invoked by SQLite after the commit has taken place and 
06039 ** the associated write-lock on the database released, so the implementation 
06040 ** may read, write or [checkpoint] the database as required.
06041 **
06042 ** ^The first parameter passed to the callback function when it is invoked
06043 ** is a copy of the third parameter passed to sqlite3_wal_hook() when
06044 ** registering the callback. ^The second is a copy of the database handle.
06045 ** ^The third parameter is the name of the database that was written to -
06046 ** either "main" or the name of an [ATTACH]-ed database. ^The fourth parameter
06047 ** is the number of pages currently in the write-ahead log file,
06048 ** including those that were just committed.
06049 **
06050 ** The callback function should normally return [SQLITE_OK].  ^If an error
06051 ** code is returned, that error will propagate back up through the
06052 ** SQLite code base to cause the statement that provoked the callback
06053 ** to report an error, though the commit will have still occurred. If the
06054 ** callback returns [SQLITE_ROW] or [SQLITE_DONE], or if it returns a value
06055 ** that does not correspond to any valid SQLite error code, the results
06056 ** are undefined.
06057 **
06058 ** A single database handle may have at most a single write-ahead log callback 
06059 ** registered at one time. ^Calling [sqlite3_wal_hook()] replaces any
06060 ** previously registered write-ahead log callback. ^Note that the
06061 ** [sqlite3_wal_autocheckpoint()] interface and the
06062 ** [wal_autocheckpoint pragma] both invoke [sqlite3_wal_hook()] and will
06063 ** those overwrite any prior [sqlite3_wal_hook()] settings.
06064 */
06065 SQLITE_API void *sqlite3_wal_hook(
06066   sqlite3*, 
06067   int(*)(void *,sqlite3*,const char*,int),
06068   void*
06069 );
06070 
06071 /*
06072 ** CAPI3REF: Configure an auto-checkpoint
06073 **
06074 ** ^The [sqlite3_wal_autocheckpoint(D,N)] is a wrapper around
06075 ** [sqlite3_wal_hook()] that causes any database on [database connection] D
06076 ** to automatically [checkpoint]
06077 ** after committing a transaction if there are N or
06078 ** more frames in the [write-ahead log] file.  ^Passing zero or 
06079 ** a negative value as the nFrame parameter disables automatic
06080 ** checkpoints entirely.
06081 **
06082 ** ^The callback registered by this function replaces any existing callback
06083 ** registered using [sqlite3_wal_hook()].  ^Likewise, registering a callback
06084 ** using [sqlite3_wal_hook()] disables the automatic checkpoint mechanism
06085 ** configured by this function.
06086 **
06087 ** ^The [wal_autocheckpoint pragma] can be used to invoke this interface
06088 ** from SQL.
06089 **
06090 ** ^Every new [database connection] defaults to having the auto-checkpoint
06091 ** enabled with a threshold of 1000 pages.  The use of this interface
06092 ** is only necessary if the default setting is found to be suboptimal
06093 ** for a particular application.
06094 */
06095 SQLITE_API int sqlite3_wal_autocheckpoint(sqlite3 *db, int N);
06096 
06097 /*
06098 ** CAPI3REF: Checkpoint a database
06099 **
06100 ** ^The [sqlite3_wal_checkpoint(D,X)] interface causes database named X
06101 ** on [database connection] D to be [checkpointed].  ^If X is NULL or an
06102 ** empty string, then a checkpoint is run on all databases of
06103 ** connection D.  ^If the database connection D is not in
06104 ** [WAL | write-ahead log mode] then this interface is a harmless no-op.
06105 **
06106 ** ^The [wal_checkpoint pragma] can be used to invoke this interface
06107 ** from SQL.  ^The [sqlite3_wal_autocheckpoint()] interface and the
06108 ** [wal_autocheckpoint pragma] can be used to cause this interface to be
06109 ** run whenever the WAL reaches a certain size threshold.
06110 */
06111 SQLITE_API int sqlite3_wal_checkpoint(sqlite3 *db, const char *zDb);
06112 
06113 /*
06114 ** Undo the hack that converts floating point types to integer for
06115 ** builds on processors without floating point support.
06116 */
06117 #ifdef SQLITE_OMIT_FLOATING_POINT
06118 # undef double
06119 #endif
06120 
06121 #ifdef __cplusplus
06122 }  /* End of the 'extern "C"' block */
06123 #endif
06124 #endif

06139 #ifndef _SQLITE3RTREE_H_
06140 #define _SQLITE3RTREE_H_

06142 
06143 #ifdef __cplusplus
06144 extern "C" {
06145 #endif
06146 
06147 typedef struct sqlite3_rtree_geometry sqlite3_rtree_geometry;
06148 
06149 /*
06150 ** Register a geometry callback named zGeom that can be used as part of an
06151 ** R-Tree geometry query as follows:
06152 **
06153 **   SELECT ... FROM <rtree> WHERE <rtree col> MATCH $zGeom(... params ...)
06154 */
06155 SQLITE_API int sqlite3_rtree_geometry_callback(
06156   sqlite3 *db,
06157   const char *zGeom,
06158   int (*xGeom)(sqlite3_rtree_geometry *, int nCoord, double *aCoord, int *pRes),
06159   void *pContext
06160 );
06161 
06162 
06163 /*
06164 ** A pointer to a structure of the following type is passed as the first
06165 ** argument to callbacks registered using rtree_geometry_callback().
06166 */
06167 struct sqlite3_rtree_geometry {
06168   void *pContext;                 /* Copy of pContext passed to s_r_g_c() */
06169   int nParam;                     /* Size of array aParam[] */
06170   double *aParam;                 /* Parameters passed to SQL geom function */
06171   void *pUser;                    /* Callback implementation user data */
06172   void (*xDelUser)(void *);       /* Called by SQLite to clean up pUser */
06173 };
06174 
06175 
06176 #ifdef __cplusplus
06177 }  /* end of the 'extern "C"' block */
06178 #endif
06179 
06180 #endif  /* ifndef _SQLITE3RTREE_H_ */
